Title:
I booked an economy flight from Cape Town to Johannesburg.

When we boarded the plane, the staff noticed that a family, with two small children, had not booked seats for the children.

As they were going to sit near me, a flight attendant asked if I would be willing to give my seat to one of the children.

I agreed, and after seated the same flight attendant asked again if I was willing to move. I said I was happy to do so to help the family, and then they moved me to business class!

I was impressed with their concern for the family’s comfort & travelling experience.

And appreciated their generous gesture of moving me to business class.

During the flight the where attentive, friendly and helpful. Overall, I had a great experience flying with SAA and will definitely consider booking with them again in the future.

Title:
Do not fly with South African Airways especially if you are outside of South Africa. I have been booking trips from New York and they are impossible to contact and now they have made it impossible to pay for tickets.

They closed their U.S 1-800 customer service number during COVID so the only way to contact them is through the South African number. They aren't on WhatsApp so I have to pay foreign call fees every time I talk to customer service. I called them regarding an unused ticket that should receive credit towards a new flight. Every time I talked to them the connection was terrible and they would tell me something different or would tell me to call back at a different time. I finally got to someone that tried to help but she said it would be an $85 fee in order to use the ticket credit. The new ticket only cost about $105. This is ridiculous since most airlines these days are not charging a cancellation fee for using flight credit. I decided to go with it anyway to just get the whole thing over with, but then the payment link they sent me didn't work and they told me that the only way I'd be able to pay for the ticket is to go to the airport with the credit card.

I've reserved tickets with South African Airways multiple times in the past and most of the time their site has errors when you try to put in credit card info. I've called before and provided the card information in order to pay for the ticket and everything went fine. Now they're saying that they've changed their policy and providing card info over the phone is fraud. So they've literally made it impossible to fly with them since I can't pay for the ticket.

Horrible customer service (the people on the phone were nice but incapable of doing anything helpful because of company policy) and impossible for international travelers.

Title:
AVOID AT ALL COSTS. CRIMINALS.

My wife and I were returning from our honeymoon, and were robbed as we returned back to the US. My advice - and what I'll personally do next I visit Africa (which is a truly amazing continent) - is to pay more to avoid South African Aiways, at all costs.

We had checked our large bags and had the appropriate amount of carry-on's (which we did / had no issue for 6 other flights during the trip) and two employees near the gate begged us and forced us to gate-check our bags. We had valuables in all, and so we had to take a risk with one- unfortunately, that resulted in us losing $700 worth of apparel and goods.

The worst part is the fact that we had the appropriate amount / size of carry-on luggage, and the employees effectively intimidated us and forcefully demanded a bag -- commenting that there was no room left on the packed flight (re: overhead space). Without exaggeration- my wife and I had and empty seat next to us and ENTIRE OVERHEAD BINS EMPTY - completely empty - for the entire flight. Yet, we were told there was absolutely no overhead room on this packed flight.

As soon as we sat down for takeoff, we knew we were *screwed*. While we did not let if ruin the most incredible honeymoon ever, we were very upset and disappointed when we found our bag plundered upon arrival. An absolute joke and pathetic company- which makes the stigma even worse in an environment known to be dominated by corruption and crime. A true shame.

All I can hope for now, is to help others with this review- avoid SA Airways however possible.

Title:
Run away from booking with the company. They have no respect for customers. I had booked a flight from Perth to Johannesburg that was supposed to depart at 11.45pm and arrive at 4am the next day. Just a month before, they have decided to change the schedule by MORE THAN 9 HOURS. As a result, I would have to change my connecting flight and spend the night in Johannesburg. SSA has taken NO responsibility for this change. I asked to be compensated, or get my hotel paid, but they don’t care. In the EU or the US, they would have to provide me with 600$ compensation because any normal person caring for customers consider this unacceptable. This is what SSA does:
- Don’t give compensation
- Don’t provide accommodation for the extra night they have created
- Unable to give information on how much would be refunded for the 1 flight that got reschedule!! They told me they could not calculate that and I had to write an email and I would get a reply in 34 working days!! I was appalled. After sending me through 4 different services of course.
- Unable to provide a spot on a different flight
I am a frequent traveler, and this is by far the worse customer service I have seen in my life. They actually signed the Montreal convention by which they are compelled to cover the damages caused by the schedule change, but they do not respect their engagement. They scam their customers instead. They said they announced the change more than 30 days before the flight so they don’t owe me anything. Yes, 34 days before. Unbelievable. They said they could only fully refund the tickets, including the way in which I don’t want to change. Do they really expect me to find a flight just a month before?? When the prices have double or tripled?? Especially when they are the only company connecting these 2 cities and the other flights have a step over in Doha and 3 times longer. But they don’t care and they don’t do anything. I strongly discourage anyone to book with this company, unless you want to have your travel plans completely screwed at the last minute. This is not a professional company, with an appalling customer service.

Title:
My husband and I were on our honeymoon to South Africa and had the absolute worst experience with this airline, essentially ruining the last portion of our honeymoon.
We wanted to extend our stay one more day, called the airline to change our flight and this was the beginning of our issues. The rep who booked our new flight recorded the wrong credit card number and instead of notifying us- they canceled our flight back home. It wasn't until a few hours before our flight that we realized this, which sent us into a panic.

We called the customer service line several times without resolution. We were placed on hold for hours without anyone picking up the line. We were finally then told a "team leader" or supervisor would give us a call with an answer or to help us within the hour. No one ever called us back. All we received out of this was extremely rude and dismissive individuals who didn't have an answer or couldn't help with anything. We missed our morning safari trying to figure out how to fix what should've been a very simple situation. They also charged us double the price compared to what another representative had quoted us on, and this airline refused to honor what another rep had quoted.

I rarely write bad reviews, but I truly don't want anyone else experiencing what we experienced through this process. So do yourselves a favor and DO NOT BOOK THIS AIRLINE. I'm unfortunately not surprised they are going bankrupt. Also do your research and look up recent news on this airline. This alone will make the decision easy not to book if you want to get to your destination safely.
qwuub: DO NOT book with this airline

Title: Flying from Johannesburg to London Heathrow, we had requested a gluten-free dinner for my wife. When this was served, we noticed that the biscuits to accompany the cheese were labelled 'Wholewheat.' Checking the ingredients confirmed that the main ingredient was, in fact, wheat. This could have had very serious consequences. We summoned the flight attendant; she shouted down the length of the plane to a more senior colleague, 'A woman here is making a complaint.' The senior colleague marched up, snatched the biscuits and the wrapper, and walked off without a word of apology (or replacement).On returning home, we wrote to South African Airways UK office. As we had received no reply nearly four weeks later, I again wrote to South African Airways UK office. I received a reply from their 'Customer Care Executive' saying that their catering manager in Johannesburg was in the process of contacting their caterers, Skychefs, and would contact me again when they had had a response. Five weeks later, we have heard nothing.If this had involved a nut allergy, there could have been a fatality. Mistakes do happen, but apart from serving food that was potentially dangerous, South African Airways failed on several counts:1) the behaviour of the flight attendant shouting something that was untrue down the       plane was totally unacceptable2) the more senior flight attendant rudely snatching the offending food without     apology was even more unacceptable3) failure to answer our complaint after nine weeks demonstrates a total failure of     Customer Care Department in not addressing a very serious error on their part.I hope that management see this review and deign to reply in a timely and adequate manner.

Title:
My wife and I have been flying SAA for the last 25 years or so and have never, repeat never had cause to complain. I have heard of reports of dissatisfaction including from friends siting old aircraft but I have yet to experience this. Their Voyager with free Companion Ticket is an excellent offering, allowing a companion to fly at approx 25% of normal all inclusive ticket price. Using the Companion ticket offering has allowed us to travel business class. What an excellent service! The most up to date seating with lie flat compartmentalised beds in a 1-2-1 layout, just like Emirates. I loved being addressed by name and discussing the wine and food before ordering. However I have found their admin a bit challenging on occasions and their website has room for improvement. I do hope that they get over their maladministration and that business rescue does just that, otherwise I fear my next companion ticket for 2020 may fly away.
It is advisable to shrink wrap your checked bags when routing through Johannesburg to avoid pilfering. Remember SAA do not run the Airports and cannot be blamed for any airport baggage loss.

Title:
Flown on SA453 today from JHB to DBN(10am)
Considering the tough times faced by the airline they excelled today.
The cabin crew went out of their way to ensure the comfort of passengers. Basically the crew tried to do something out of nothing as the airline is cash strapped and is in bad shape due to various factors. The pilot was phenomenal. He managed to keep the aircraft under control as there was a severe storm in DBN. His experience and skill was clearly notable. We asu passengers keep on critising the airline but nobody talks about their sparkling safety record and the amount of seasoned pilots that is in their arsenal.

I say SAA has huge potential and as a fellow South African will support this airline back to winning its ways again.

What surprised me is that the crew's attitude was outstanding especially considering the tough economic times and turmoil they(SAA) are facing, in fact nobody would even notice the predicament the airline is facing as the great service from the staff was superb.

Let's get this right SAA. Us South Africans will stand together and support you. Let's get back to winning ways again and earn that respect back.

Well done and keep It up!

Title: This was my first time flying SAA. Bought my ticket just a few days prior to my travel due to the fact that I was traveling to my mother's funeral, so granted the price was a high. I booked my flight through the SAA website. SAA had me fly United from Austin TX to IAD (Dulles) where I got the SAA plane. So, as much as SAA allows 2 checked bags free, United only allows 1 checked bag and $100 for a second bag! And thus my frustration commenced. So since I had brought 2 bags to the airport with me.....I paid the $100. The united flight was fine, the flight attendants were polite which is my normal experience with United as I fly them a lot for business. After my 5 hour layover at Dulles airport, I boarded my SAA flight. The first thing that struck me was that it was so dated which made it seem kinda dirty too. I was disappointing but I let it go, I just needed to get to my destination. Then it came to the food/drink service. The flight attendants were not very welcoming to the point were they were actually outright rude to some passengers. I actually saw one flight attendant actually roll her eyes at a passenger! Seriously?! It doesn't cost anything to even just smile when offering a drink to a passenger! And speaking of drinks, when they initially offer you a drink, all they say is "would you like something to drink? we have juice and water" they don't tell you that they actually have wine (limited as that choice was) as an option. For a 16 hour flight, I'd say that is important to know! The food also left a lot to be desired. Stale rolls and iffy beef stew that ended up making 3 people sick to their stomach. Oh and to top it all off...they went on strike while I was in Lusaka. I had to hear that on the news as I sat in a bank lobby one afternoon just a few days before I was due to travel back to the US. There was no email or any other form of communication directly to me from SAA,  essentially leaving me in a state of panic as to how I was going to get back home. In conclusion, I will never be flying SAA again. Back to Emirates and Ethiopian Airlines when traveling to Zambia.

Title:
On Wednesday 18 September we arrived at East London airport to book into flight SA480 to Oliver Tambo Airport and flight SA280 to Perth, Australia.

To our dismay the system refused to print my husband's boarding passe for the JHB-Perth leg of our flight.

The SAA staff member Rogas Polota tried everything. Then he called on colleague Kgaogelo Mabuya to assist. They asked for physical evidence of Derek's Australian visas.

Unfortunately Derek didn't have his letter with him so the help of Lundi Rula, "the Visa Champion" was enlisted. These three SAA or East London Airport officials helped my husband set up his laptop and find the relevant letter. In desperation Mr Rula contacted the Australian Embassy/Visa Zone and was able to solve the problem,. Derek's surname had been spelled with three "L's" -- HILLL. Without further ado the boarding pass was issued.

We are very grateful to Rogas Polota, Kgaogelo Mabuya and Lundi Rula. Without their help we would not have been able to visit our children and grandchildren who we had not seen for four years. Throughout the 45 minute ordeal they were friendly, positive, efficient and determined to solve the problem. They really did go the extra thousand miles for us.

The actual flight was very full, but the crew were friendly, helpful and efficient. The food was fine.

I sent this information to SAA and to the Manager of EL Airport. I hope that they have given recognition to Kgaogelo Mabuya, Rojas Rolota and Lundi Rula for excellent service.

This was the first leg on an international flight path to Europe and the baggage allowance was 23kg.I had 2 kg over that allowance and was willing to pay overweight for the two extra kilos, as would be the practice with other airlines, but SAA charge you a full oversize bag, not for the actual overweight which is very sharp practice. Title:
My husband and I took advantage of the special deal South African Airways was offering for flights between October and December, which was half or more cheaper than flights with other airlines. Although we were not looking forward to the 17-hour flight from Washington, DC to Johannesburg, then a 2-hour flight to Cape Town, we thought we could weather it. We did survive the flight, but it was undoubtedly the most uncomfortable flight in economy class that we have ever had.

The primary discomfort was lack of leg room, which seemed to be less than any other airline we've flown. Even worse, when passengers seated in front of us reclined, we couldn't reach down to get what we had stowed under those seats. In essence, we felt trapped and had to sit sideways the entire flight. I realize that Economy Class is what it is, but this was the worst we have experienced in terms of comfort.

I would advise potential basic economy class travelers to consider upgrading to the bulkhead seats for more legroom, although you risk being in a row with an infant in a bassinet.

Potential passengers should also know that when the plane stops in Accra, Ghana, passengers are not permitted to exit the plane. Standing in the aisles while in Accra is also not feasible because airline staff are passing back and forth to clean, gather blankets and headphones, and so forth. Officials from the Ghana airport also board the plane to check passports, then new passengers board for Cape Town. It was extremely frustrating to know we were on the ground but still trapped in the plane.

On the positive side, the food was generally good and served with good South African wine, although one beef meal after the stop in Ghana was full of fat and gristle in an unappetizing gravy. The plane was clean, and check-in and boarding were quick and easy.

On an ending note, don't be fooled by the airline's tease to bid on a business class seat up to 36 hours before your flight if there are business seats available. When the time came to bid, the minimum bid allowed was $1300, which is added to your original ticket price. A better method for the airline would be to hold a lottery to award up to 2 business class upgrades, but then the airline wouldn't make its additional money for unsold seats, would it?
qwuub: Uncomfortable for 17 hours over, 18 hours back
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: We flew SAA to Johannesburg from LAX for a Safari and sightseeing trip with our kids.  On the outbound flight we tried to bid on an upgrade to Business Class but we’re not successful. As a result we flew in economy on the long overnight flight through Ghana to Joburg.  The seats were pretty uncomfortable and we were t able to sleep very well.      On the return flight, we increased the amount we bid to upgrade to Business and they accepted our offer.  As we later learned upon boarding, there were almost no other passengers in Business so almost any bid would have been enough.  Their little tool to decide how much to bid was definitely misleading and caused us to pay more than we needed to.       We settled in to our seats at the bulkhead for the first leg of the flight to Ghana and on takeoff we heard water falling somewhere in the galley in front of us.  Shortly after, the flight attendant asked my wife to lift up her feet and she placed a blanket under her footrest.  She thought she was being nice but soon learned that the blanket was wet when she put her foot down.  The attendant then put a plastic bag and another blanket under her but that didn’t work either and the carpet under both our feet was soaking wet.  The blankets we were using soon became wet and the forward cabin began to smell musty.  We had to endure this treatment for the entire 6+ hour flight to Ghana.       When we arrived in Ghana we sat on the tarmac for two hours waiting for refueling and the local maintenance crew tried to figure out where the water was coming from.  They mopped up the galley and asked us to switch seats a few rows back and that solved the wet carpet problem.  However, the smell in the cabin remained for the balance of the trip to Dulles.       When we asked the airline to refund our upgrade fee, they gave us a polite response that they would look into it and get back to us.  That was over two months ago and they have completely ignored all of my subsequent emails and calls.  Definitely won’t fly with SAA again.

Title:
Because I checked in early for my flight from Victoria Falls to Johannesburg, I got a great seat selection for both of my flights with South African Airways. The connecting flight was from Johannesburg to Heathrow and was scheduled at eleven and a half hours overnight. I was seated in the right aisle seat of the middle four seats of the aircraft at the bulkhead. Another gentleman was seated in the left aisle seat, and we shared the two vacant seats between us. Bonus plus. The flight, service and comfort of my flight were great. Upon boarding, they give you a small, pouch that contains earplugs, an eyeshade, stereo system earplugs, a pair of socks, and hand wipes. This was most beneficial to me since I had stupidly packed mine in my checked bag, and I hoped to get some zeds on board.

The negative of the flight was the late departure of almost an hour, for some undisclosed reason. No time was recovered on our very long flight. I have been on many flights that had a late departure, that regained most of that lost time during much shorter trips. Consequently, we were an hour late arriving at Heathrow. This wouldn’t be a big deal if I didn’t have another connecting flight.

That was to Toronto, and I only had two hours and five minutes between flights, which was now cut to one hour. Upon my panicked disembarkation, I was told that there were six other people in the same predicament. I was greatly relieved and appreciated that we were then escorted to airport security. Unfortunately, we found an enormous lineup in front of us. Another late arriving flight was in the queue in front us. They were also on my same connecting flight. They numbered about forty.

Heathrow security had two separate inspection stations, however only one was open, of course. Nightmare! There were only four other people behind me when I finally passed through security. Sadly I also needed a boarding pass for my ongoing flight, as the Johannesburg agent was not allowed to preprint it for me, for a now forgotten reason. Air Canada did that expeditiously and I scrambled aboard as the last passenger. Surprisingly, our baggage caught the flight too. Well done.

After takeoff and settling in, I was realized that I had lost my SDHC card during the airport security ritual of possession purging etc. I have since registered it for lost and found online, but have not been lucky. Most of my photos have not been lost since I back them up to my iPad daily. Some are gone forever. In future I will empty all my pockets into my backpack before I get to the security station, to ensure that I don’t leave it in their tray. A tough lesson to learn.

Title: My wife's phone rang this morning three times in short succession.  My daughter had been vacationing in Africa, and was stranded in Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe.  South African Airways is on strike.  Alternatively we booked her from VFA to Addis Ababa on Ethiopian, and then to Dulles, IAD.  On further research I learned that South African Airways posted a 145 million "pound" loss in 2017, and then stopped posting their financials.  The airline is state-owned.  The nation of South Africa was just downgraded by Moody's to "negative".  Simply, they don't have sufficient tax revenues to support a failing airline in South Africa.  Efforts to curb spending by the airline, to save itself, included 900 layoffs.  A strike ensued, which will probably destroy the airline, and any hope of recovery.  Recommendation: if you're traveling to Africa, book only on international airlines, do not rely on airlines owned and operated by their host countries.  Even if the local airline is an "affiliate" of British Airways, or American Airlines, has the resources to get you out if needed.
qwuub: Daughter stranded in Zimbabwe, en route to South America.

Title: Recent travels to, around, and from southern Africa had me on SAA several times. The flight from JFK to Johannesburg was OK. FAs were pleasant and polite and tried there best to make things right when the IFE did not work at all. The plane was freezing, but a FA got them to turn up the thermostat to a comfortable level. Shorter hops in southern Africa were acceptable. The same CANNOT be said for the return flight from Cape Town to JFK, especially the long leg from Johannesburg to JFK. I have never seen such rude, unfriendly, aloof, hostile-looking flight attendants aboard any aircraft. There was nothing pleasant about any of the four in my section of Economy--no smiles nor any warmth--just cold indifference bordering on hostility. Where does SAA find these people, and why are they hired to work with the flying public? Shortly after takeoff, drinks were served as if the FA was angry, and the "meal" (mostly inedible) service was done just as angrily. After the meal was served, FAs disappeared and only reappeared to again perform another grudging meal service for breakfast (also mostly inedible) shortly before arrival. This was the full extent of the cabin crew's involvement for a nearly 16-hour flight. Another point, and I hasten to say that I don't believe in objectifying women in any way. But the cabin crew were all very overweight, and they could not walk down the aisle of the plane without their hips and thighs hitting passengers seated on the aisle, of which I was one. I wondered how agile they could be in case of an emergency. Not to put too fine a point on it, but IFE options were outdated, and the touch screens were unresponsive much of the time. SAA was my fastest option to get to southern Africa, and all my flights were on time. But based on my experience from JNB to JFK, I would not fly them again regardless.

Title: There are a couple of things about South African Air that make it a MUST  for my husband and I when we fly to Africa.   1.   In economy seating there are only 2 seats on  the window (vs. three).   This makes long distance travel in coach so much more pleasant.   It is just the two of us - no inconvenience of a third person like them needing to get in or out, taking over the armrest, etc.    2.  When you purchase an economy ticket from South African Air direct (unless it is some really discounted ticket) you become eligible to "bid" to upgrade to Business.    My husband and I used this process on this most recent trip.  We purchased the economy tickets a year in advance and when we got the email saying we were eligible we looked into it and decided we would be ok in coach.   When it got within a few weeks of the trip and we realized we had over 30 hours of travel ahead of us we decided to give the bidding process a try.   There is a minimum bid and a maximum bid and everything in between.   It gives you an idea of the dollar amount needed to be a weak, good, strong or excellent bid.   You also only bid on the legs of flight you are interested in upgrading.  So for example we were only interested in the longest leg of flight from JFK to Joburg.  We did not mind flying coach on the shorter flight to Entebbe.   That worked out great and our "strong" bid was accepted.   This saved us money because of being about to single out certain legs of the flight to go business and leaving the other as coach.   A few days before our return flight we were exhausted after 3 weeks of safari and we decided we "had" to be upgraded for the longest leg of the flight home.  We put in the amount needed to be considered and "excellent" bid and again were upgraded.   The biggest positive about this - the upgrade option was far cheaper than if we had purchased round trip business class for the trip.   Only one small negative - you don't find out until 24 hours before your flight if your bid has been accepted.  Your credit card is not charged unless your bid is accepted.    I have no experience with how low you can bid and still be granted the upgrade.  I've read a few articles on looking to see how many seats in Business class have sold on the flight and determine if they are likely to sell them all at market value.   Oh one more tidbit, you can enter your bid as soon as you get the email that says you are eligible but you allowed to alter the bid 3 times before the flight.  So like in our case, we had bid less on the return trip initially but a few days before the trip home decided we really wanted to upgrade.  So we went in and increased the bid.

Title:
We recently visited South Africa on holiday and had two bad flights with SSA. This review is of our return flight from JNB to HKG.

During our original flight from HKG to JNB we sat in the plane, delayed for 3.5 hours as they struggled to compute fuel needs for the heavy cargo load they were attempting to carry. Eventually they had to offload the large cargo payload so that we could finally take off.

Sadly, on the flight back from JNB to HKG, we again sat in the plane on the tarmac, unable to take off due to reverse throttle and engine problems. Engineers worked on the plane for 4 hours while we sat with no entertainment, often without air conditioning. At that point they simply cancelled the flight, put us up in nearby hotel and flew us home the following day.

Our eventual outbound flight departed on time the next morning. We arrived at our rescheduled time in HKG fine as well. Flight was average, seat comfort what you can expect of the older fleet used by SAA. Entertainment system nearly in shambles, similar to our flight from HKG to JNB. Headphones didn't work, touch screen didn't work, remote connection to the system very slow. System crashed three times while watching movies.

In flight meals were ok, better than what we experienced on the flight from HKG to JNB. The curry chicken wasn't bad. Flight attendants were friendly and worked hard during the flight. Can not fault them for their efforts. Luggage made its way to the carousel in Hong Kong in a timely manner.

In the end, two bad flights with SAA on this trip to South Africa, making it really difficult to consider using them again in the future even if they do offer the most convenient flights and affordable seats for travel to southern African destinations from HK.
qwuub: Flight cancelled after we sat over 4 hours in the plane on the tarmac

Title:
It all started quite favourably with a good check-in and published departure time met. However after only a short time the seats became very uncomfortable - very hard seat and head rests in the wrong position for me - this made it hard to rest your head back and caused neck pain.

We were served drinks but unbelievably they had run out of (or had under stocked) tonic water so our G&T's could only be served with 'bitter lemon' - not so good. Later a member of cabin crew made an announcement that a second bar service was imminent but they had run out of most drinks - it may have been easier to say what they did have in stock - never encountered this before on any airline.

The return flight was slightly better in terms of bar stock but as vegetarians who had ordered a 'special meal' we weren't offered wine with our meal. The meals were all very much below par on both flights with the outbound breakfast being inedible - I think it was a traditional South African dish called pap which resembled wallpaper paste with 3 what looked like dates on top - the whole dish was very salty and my wife was forced to eject the unknown object - terrible and not great at 6.00am after a restless night. The breakfast on return was equally 'odd' - spinach, a sturdy tomato puree (quite tasty) with three fried rings of aubergine served with fruit and a bread roll (no butter).

Not the best flight with the cabin crew being just average in terms of making you feel 'special' and looked after. There was no sale of alcohol / tobacco on board.

Ironically we had two domestic flights to/from Capetown on which the service, ambience, snack / drinks and comfort was far superior, it just seemed that the long haul trip was noticeably poor.
qwuub: Uncomfortable, Poor Food and ran out of many drinks.

Title:
We recently flew direct with South African Airways from Hong Kong (HKG) to Johannesburg (JNB) for a visit to trip to South Africa.

Flight was booked online, payment processed and flight confirmation email received in a timely manner. Check-in and boarding at HKG were both fine. Unfortunately, prior to take-off, we had to sit on the tarmac for 3.5 hours while crew attempted to calculate fuel requirements, apparently, it seemed we were taking a very large cargo payload. After nearly 4 hours, they decided to unload a considerable amount of cargo so that the flight could depart.

After the long delay, luckily shorter than the 18 hour delay experienced on the return leg of our flight, we were finally in the air. Flight was uneventful. The entertainment system didn't work well, responding quite slowly to the remote control and not at all to the touch screen. In-flight meals were mediocre, neither finished. Cup noodles taken between scheduled meals was best thing served.

Leg space average, seats not as comfortable as what we usually experience with long-haul carriers, resulting in less restful flight. Toilets were in bad shape, being quite dirty and unpleasant on both occasions that we attempted to use them. Upon arrival, luggage arrived on the carrousel in a timely fashion and we were on our way out of O.R. Tambo airport.

In the end, didn't find this to be a good flight in pretty much regard. Sadly, our return flight from JNB to HKG 10 days later was perhaps even worse with a massive 18 hour delay but more on that experience with the next review. Have to say, really difficult to see us using SAA again anytime soon after flights like these.
qwuub: Nearly 4 hour delay while we sat in the plane waiting to depart

Title:
It was a nice flight. It wasn't a long flight.
However when I booked it I personally took too long and so ended up in business class because that was the only thing available.

When arriving at the airport in LVI I thought I was glad I made that mistake as the queue to check in was incredibly long. The business class check in only had 2 ladies in front of me and my friend. However the wait was definitely too long. There were 2 staff members checking people in - well really, only one. The other was doing something else more along the lines of ignoring everyone.
A woman was standing near the queue and asking everyone that got in line with us if they were indeed in biz class and we showed her our emails/online boarding info.

Eventually the lone man helping customers for our area finished and we were ushered up past the two women in front of us in the queue. Apparently they did not have biz class seats but were refusing the get out of the line.

Our check in process was quick and so then we progressed to the next security check and into the airport proper. It was a very simple check in but no special greeting as usually happens with upgraded class seats. No special welcome or lounge information was provided.

The boarding process was somewhat chaotic. If you were boarding first then you had to push past everyone else trying to board but while they were denied boarding because it wasn't their turn yet, they would block access to the service agents trying to find biz class boarders. Basically, you have to learn to be a little bit pushy.

The staff on the flight was very friendly. Nothing that stood out in particular but it was still a nice flight. A short one too. The food that was served didn't look too grand but it didn't taste bad at all.

I would fly South African again if I had the opportunity.
I was in seat 3A.
crvsd: Kumi M wrote a review Sep 2019
qwuub: Pretty nice for a first time

Title:
The flight was operated on behalf of SAA by SA Express using an Embraer E190.
The typical 2x2 configuration in economy class makes for narrow seats and with the flight nearly full was I in for 4 long hours.
Having flown repeatedly with Ethiopian over the past couple of weeks, where in economy class on the 1 hr 45 min flight to Addis a full meal is served, I was in for a shock when a meagre lunch box was handed out, containing ONE sandwich, a piece of cheese, a bisquit, a small chocolate, some dried fruits and a small piece of pastry.
WHAT? On a four hour flight? This is cutting cost at the wrong end of the stick and for my part I will not fly with them again.
The crew, especially Maxine, was very friendly, their drink service efficient - unlike my last flight with them when I had to hustle for tea - and swift to arrange a refill.
What should be announced on these flights into Johannesburg is an explanation of the procedure for passengers flying on a domestic service to their final destination.
I knew the drill, which is to collect the bags - though labelled through - go through customs and then hand them in again at SAA or in my case Mango. I had to literally run to make my flight, others I understood on arrival were not so lucky.
qwuub: Friendly crew BUT the catering on a 4 hour flight defies logic!

Title: There are 2 interesting parts of this flight: first the landing in Wallis Bay, Namibia to refuel about half way through the journey. You don't leave the plane but can observe the Kalahari Desert and the fairly bleak setting of Wallis Bay nonetheless. You set off again after about 20-30 minutes for St Helena. As a remote island, after a long time of flying over an ocean, a brown speck hoves in to view and the plane approaches in an arc, flying in past the rather alarmingly sharp looking King and Queen Rock to land on the short runway in front of the impressive glass-fronted terminal. St Helena Airport is notoriously prone to inclement weather: strong crosswinds and, worse, fog. This can lead to the delay or even cancellation of the weekly flight to or from Johannesburg - though I was fortunate and the landing was smooth and my return flight not affected. There is no in flight entertainment so make sure you have a book! You are however fed and the service is good.

Title:
I went with an open mind, as I have not flown South African Airways in a very long time. I flew from Cape Town to Johannesburg which was fine although I was told that I could not check my luggage through to Washington DC because I had a longer layover than 5 hours in Johannesburg. After re-checkin of my luggage in Johannesburg (which was apparently unnecessary as the Johannesburg agent said it could have been checked all the way through from Cape Town), I went to the SAA lounge. I was quite surprised at the drop in quality, as I recalled the lounge being very nice the last time I was there. The lounge was okay but paled in comparison to other airline lounges. Generally,I did not find the lounge check-in staff very helpful or knowledgeable. In fact, one person was extremely unprofessional especially when I asked about my flight which was delayed because of technical difficulties (the pilot announced a plane change). Although,I was relieved to be on an operational plane as the week before a plane on the same route had an emergency landing on the same route. Of course, I missed my connection travelling on to Canada, and then the rebooked later flight was delayed because of a missing pilot!

I flew one way business class with British Airways and Qatar airways to South Africa and the flight experiences were far superior! I do not recommend South African Airways at all!

Now for the good ..... The cabin crew were excellent, the food was good and the wine list amazing. Also, my rebooked connecting ticket on a later flight was ready for me upon arrival.
qwuub: Disappointed with business class flights with South African Airways - Johannesburg to Washington DC!

Title: My first time flying SAA Airllink.  Overall the seat and service were fine.  In fact, the food and beverage service is superior to US airlines.  My rating is for the confusing baggage rules on SAA Airlink.  The rules are different between mainline SAA and SAA Airlink.  Before departing the US, I read the rules on the Airlink website and thought I understood the rules.  I am an experienced traveler and have two advanced degrees, so I'd like to think I can read and  comprehend English.  Airlink has a weight concept and piece concept.  I thought the passenger could choose the concept that best served them.  My understanding was that I could check 1 20 kg luggage for free and pay $30 USD for a second 20 kg luggage.  This was spelled out in the section on piece concept.  However, I found out at check in that my flight used the weight concept, not the piece concept.  Therefore, my second 20 kg luggage would be charged $10 per kg x 20 kg.  Additionally the carry on suitcases had a limit of 8 kg.  Anything over 8 kg was charged $10 / kg.  Overall my family and I were faced with over $400 in excess baggage fees.  After 45 minutes talking to the SAA manager at the airport, he did me a favor and only charged me only $200.Please understand the baggage and weight limits before you depart the US or you may be in for an unpleasant surprise.  The SAA and SAA Airlink websites are very confusing.  I can't recommend this airline.  Fly British Airways / Comair if possible.  They allow 2 23 kg luggage.

Title:
I am very disappointed with the overall quality and service of the SAA business class flights from OR Tambo to JFK:

1. QUALITY

- The entertainment system glitched throughout the entire flight to JFK. This was not the worst part; it seems the system is somehow linked to the seat recline function, so the passengers' seat function controls didn't work several times throughout the 17-hour flight (for up to 15-20 minutes per glitch period). Some people were stuck in a reclined position while others were stuck upright when it was time to sleep.

- On the returning flight, the TV screens were hardly responsive to touch and were very frustrating to use.

- The seats are hard and uncomfortable. Worse still, if a passenger is seated next to a window, they can't step around or over their seatmate when the latter is in a reclined position. This means they have to wake up their seatmate to go to the bathroom, etc. On Ethiopian Airlines, the seats are soft and wide, and there is more space around and between seats.

- The seat spaces are fairly cramped. For both SAA flights, I had to store my handbag in the overhead compartment for takeoff and landing. On Ethiopian Airlines, there are more surrounding compartments and features (personal coat hanger, etc.) to store a passenger's personal items, as well as more seat features and functions.

- The seat recline function is rickety and makes a lot of noise when in use. Even with customized earplugs, I would wake up whenever my seatmate used her seat recline function. On other airlines, this function is smooth and effortless.

2. FOOD

- On the flight to JFK, they ran out of eggs for breakfast, and it seemed that at least half of the passengers complained about not getting eggs. This has never happened to me before on any other flights, including economy class ones.

- On the returning flight for lunch, they ran out of salmon. (This didn't affect me personally, but did affect my seatmate.)

- On the departing flight, the flight attendant took away my untouched serving of butter and then, when I asked for butter later, said that each passenger is allocated only 1 serving of butter. This is utterly absurd.

- Apart from the desserts, the food is not that much better than what's served in economy class.

3. FLIGHT ATTENDANTS

- For most of the departing flight, there was only one overworked flight attendant serving our section, which meant that the service was very slow. The passenger who I sat next to was equally appalled by the service and noted that after the meal service, the rest of the flight attendants changed into their pyjamas and disappeared for most of the flight. Also, the flights attendants were not always prompt and sometimes forgot to offer hot towels, blankets, etc.

- The same thing happened on my returning flight (though not to the same effect, and I must say that my returning flight was much better in terms of service, quality, food, etc.).

4. LOUNGES

- The lounge in OR Tambo is okay but a little chaotic, and the food looked unappetizing. I spent less than 10 minutes there even though I had over an hour to spare until boarding time.

- The SWISS lounge for SAA business class flyers in JFK is awful. The food was okay, but the atmosphere was cold and, even worse, the staff were rude and distant. I left that lounge very quickly and returned to the main waiting area of the airport.

---

Above are specific complaints, but in general, the business class experience was certainly not worth the price of the tickets. In fact, I initially wanted to fly via Qatar, which is renowned for its quality, for almost exactly the same price. However, I ended up choosing SAA so that I could be on the same flight as a relative. Rest assured that I won't be making the same mistake again, and will not be able to recommend SAA business class to anyone else.
crvsd: Isabelle Anne Abraham wrote a review Aug 2019
qwuub: Subpar Business Class Experience on SAA

Title:
We flew Economy Class on South African Airway’s Air Link between Hoedspruit and Johannesburg on an Embraer 190, a prop-jet. This late-morning 1-hour flight proved to be a repeat in reverse of the excellent flight we took from Johannesburg two days earlier. Then, we looked forward to going on safari in Kruger National Park. Now, we looked back on sighting the Big 5 and much, much more.

The small plane was clean and appeared to be well maintained. Our seats in the 2x2 configuration felt a bit cramped but were quite tolerable for the short flight. Immediately after takeoff, delightful flight attendants came down the aisle with the beverage service and an offer of a maple Danish or a cheese cross bun. Based on my earlier experience, I went for the Danish and was not disappointed.

Air currents caused occasional bumps, but I never felt uncomfortable. Boarding went smoothly and the arrival process of taking a bus to the gate was orderly with other passengers assisting my husband, who had mobility issues. We left and arrived on time.

My experience with Air Link far exceeded my expectations.
qwuub: Another Excellent Flight on Air Link

Title:
We flew Business Class in an Embraer 190 on SAA’s Air Link between Johannesburg and Antananarivo. This gave us access to the Business Class Lounge before boarding, which was much more comfortable than waiting at the gate. The boarding process, which involved taking a bus to the plane on the tarmac and ascending the stairs, went smoothly. I would estimate that about 90 percent of the passengers on the full flight were heading to Madagascar’s wilderness, based on gear and hiking boots.

Our clean, well-maintained section of the plane had six seats in a 2 x 1 configuration with ample space in the overhead bins. I found the seats to be comfortable with good legroom. The flight attendant was pleasant and attentive. She served an amazingly good lunch. It consisted of delicious-and-tender cold marinated beef, pasta, salad, herb crackers and cheese, topped off with vanilla pudding and chocolates.

We departed on time and arrived early. The flight took only 2 hours and 35 minutes.

Title:
OK, I get it. I understand that measures need to be taken to prevent diseases from being transmitted from some countries to others. But I question whether it is necessary to spray the cabins with the passengers sitting in their seats. This happened before takeoff on our flight between Antananarivo and Johannesburg on an Embraer 170.

A flight attendant announced that this was about to happen and that the spray was totally harmless. But I knew it would aggravate my chemical sensitivities, based on my reaction to this procedure in the past, and immediately covered my face with a jacket. This helped a bit, but my skin tingled for at least an hour into the 3-hour flight. If I had known about this spraying well in advance, I would have boarded with a mask to wear.

We flew Business Class and were the only passengers in the six-seat cabin. The flight attendant essentially ignored us, except to serve lunch. We opted for ostrich, which proved to be tender and delicious. The side salads were also tasty.

The flight departed and arrived on schedule and the boarding process proceeded smoothly.

Title:
I phoned the Mango/SAA call centre prior to flying to find out baggage weight and fees. They were helpful, informative, friendly and attentive.

I received outstanding service at the Mango kiosk at King Shaka airport. I was served by a youngish, quiet gentleman in either the second or third counter.

I arrived in time for my flight and was checked in for both my Durban and Johannesburg flight by this pleasant young man. He asked my seat preference and if I would like to send my luggage ahead. He did let me know the flight was delayed and assured me I would make my connecting flight. After checking in, I went to the waiting area.

I think the flight was then further delayed because after an hour, the gentleman came and collected me! He put me on the next flight to Johannesburg and resent my luggage ahead.

I had delightful walk without luggage through OR Tambo and a stress-free 17 hour flight.

The American SAA staff at JFK New York were not half as efficient or helpful.

The cabin crew on both flights were South African and absolutely charming and caring.

The food provided on the Mango and SAA departing flights were much better than the food on my return flight from New York.

I can honestly say I received world class service from the entire South African team and was genuinely surprised because I had an economy tickets. Just wish fellow passengers were more considerate in terms of litter and the loos!

The seats were quite comfortable and fully adjustable. The food was top shelf-something I never thought I would say about airline food. The staff were the most competent and professional staff I have ever experienced on a plane.

The lounge at Tambo airport is spectacular. It has a bar, hot and cold buffet, breakfast bar, quiet room, entertainment room, conference room and showers. It made the five hour layover quite pleasant.

For long-haul flights, I will never fly economy again. My experiences with SAA I have changed the way I fly. Way to go!

Title:
This is an email that I sent out at the end of March. It is now MAY 13th...close 2 MONTHS later and I have resent it multiple times to 2 SAA customer service emails, called multiple times, faxed it and still have not yet received a reply or even an acknowledgement!!

I am a Canadian who was on a trip to South Africa for 2 weeks. I had a wonderful time and then my trip ended with a very disappointing experience with South African Airways. I had a flight booked from Johannesburg to London (flight SA 234) with a final destination of Toronto the third week of March 2019. I checked myself in as well as a bag of luggage and went through security. I then went to the gate and the SAA employees at the gate saw me running and said that the gates had just closed at 8:40pm (flight was leaving at 8:55pm) and that they were going to offload my luggage now. The plane was still there and I asked for them to please help me either get on the flight or help me with next steps in getting back to Canada. The employees were dismissive. They were unwilling to help me get on that flight, obtain my luggage OR book a new flight and were extremely abrupt and unhelpful considering that I was in a foreign country alone and according to them ultimately needed to book a new flight for the next day, getting my home 24 hours later than expected. After being re-directed multiple times, I finally ended up at a SAA check-in desk with 1 employee available and the rest of desks were empty. I told the employee my situation and he told me that there was no way to help me out at this point and to book a hotel and come back tomorrow. He also would not help me book a new flight, said it was not possible to get my luggage back at this point and was extremely rude and patronizing in his demeanour. At this point, it was around 9:15pm and the airport had another flight leaving to Europe a few hours later which I was requesting to get on. It was evident he was not willing to help me out at all and made me feel unsafe, stranded and even more worried than I was before. Due to this interaction, I ended up booking a new flight with KLM/Delta to get home promptly and safely which was leaving at 11:55pm to Amsterdam and would have me back in Toronto, Canada the next day as originally expected. I have included both flight itineraries below for your reference and am requesting a full refund for the newly booked flight due to this extremely disappointing and anxiety provoking experience with the South African Airlines Employees.
qwuub: No reply to incident for 1.5 months!!!

Title:
After many hours of travel abroad I would often look forward to jumping onto an SAA plane, to seeing familiar faces and to enjoying the comfort of SAA business class which for many years was amongst the best in the world. Regrettably, this was not my experience on a recent return flight. Perhaps it is because I had just flown on a Cathay Dragon flight from Shanghai to Hong Kong on 10 May. The service on that flight was excellent! In particular the staff were polite and pleasant throughout the flight. The aircraft was modern and new. So, you can imagine how contrasting it was to board an SAA flight on an old aircraft that was already delayed, and to be greeted by glum faces. The pursor in particular looked grumpy. He refused to take my jacket indicating that other staff would do that. It was rare to see him smile for most of the flight. Other staff tried hard to please but the passion was just not there. I wondered if these were people just there to earn a living on an airline that is enjoying less and less support in recent times. Low staff morale was evident in comparison to other international airlines. The competition is fierce with Qatar, Singapore Airlines, Emirates and others leading the field. Yet, SAA prices are higher than their superior competitors!

There are only 3 toilets in business class and towards the end of the flight I was not allowed entry to a toilet in the front section. The grumpy pursor explained that it was blocked for crew.... however shortly after I was directed to the two occupied toilets at the back, 5 other foreigners were allowed access to the front toilet????

My breakfast was served very differently from previous flights. The tray with yoghurt, cereal and fruit was not served at all. Instead, i received the main course only. A croissant was served but without jam. I had to ask for items that previously were done automatically.

Needless to say the Hong Kong flight arrived late in JHB, the luggage arrived late and I had a few minutes to race from the international terminal to domestic to board. There was no place for my hand luggage which had to be sent to the hold. Probably because other passengers had been allowed on board with more luggage than is allowed...My checked luggage is in JHB. I am still awaiting its arrival, hoping it has not been pilfered at JHB international airport. Strangely these were not my experiences or concerns in Shanghai or Hong Kong airports where everything worked seemlessly! Such a pity that SAA is failing to save itself at one of the darkest moments in its economic history!
qwuub: Bad Attitude at an altitude is harmful to airlines
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:
This was our return flight to Australia from South Africa. The flight to South Africa was 11 hours and very tiring (impossible to sleep). This return flight was scheduled for 9 hours - already looking good with a shorter flight time. Although the flight is not as long, it is still generally tiring since the flight leaves 9pm (South Africa time) and lands 6am (South Africa time) in Perth.
Like all airlines, a few days before departure SAA offers you to make a bid for an upgrade to Business Class.
This has always been a 'bucket list' for us (having never flown anything other than cattle class in the past) and we decided to make a bid - which was accepted. Hooray!!This was such a suprise for my daughter who was so excited with everything - not only the extra leg room.
Being offered champagne or orange juice when you first take your seat is a nice touch. After drinks are served, meals quickly follow. Meals are served as entrees, main and dessert.
Service is sensational and the food is well presented and reasonably good. We loved every minute of it.
Off course, having a bed that reclines is wonderful.
Breakfast was served about 1 1/2 hours before we landed in Perth.
The added bonus was that we were through customs in no time at all - a good experience all round!!!
Tick on the bucket list!

Title:
This was our first flight to South Africa. On our way to Cape Town, we flew from IAD to CPT with a fuel/clean up stop in Accra, Ghana (45-60 min). From Accra we flew another ~6 hours to Johannesburg where we deplaned, re-checked our bags, passed through customs, and then got our transfer flight to CPT. The plane we flew in from IAD to Jo-burg was new, had a lot of room and had an area in the bulk head where parents could attach a supplied crib for their babies. I thought that was a nice perk. Each seat had inflight entertainment and US plug ports and USB ports to charge phones. Our flight attendant, Nomsa, was extremely courteous and kind. She was with us from IAD to Accra before a different crew boarded in Accra.

Our return to the US was good as well, however we were on a more dated aircraft. The airline entertainment was finicky, though we managed to get through a movie. There were no ports for charging. Each time SA catered to my diet and were able to server vegetarian/vegan meals. I did put the request in prior to the flight, however. As with most airlines, if you don't make the request ahead of time, you can't guarantee they can meet your dietary requests. I also appreciated the goodie bag in economy all flights (outbound and return) that included socks, earplugs, eye covers, and a toothbrush and toothpaste. They also had pillows, blankets and a headset for all economy travelers. All staff were courteous and helpful. If I fly SA again, I'd just want to be sure to be on a newer plane due to the inflight entertainment and lack of USB ports.

We also reserved bulkhead and exit row seating in order to get extra leg room.
qwuub: Overall good experience IAD to CPT and CPT to JFK on return
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:
We try to fly Star Alliance where we can and a planned holiday in Zimbabwe and Botswana. All flights were business class.

We left Auckland on SA7061 to Perth on 3 March (operated by Air NZ), followed by SA281 to Johannesburg. The plane for this flight was dated. The seats very uncomfortable, the inflight entertainment almost non-existent and unwatchable on screens of poor quality. The flight crew were not friendly and service was perfunctory. The meal service was barely edible. During the 6 hour layover at OR Tambo International Airport we used the SAA Lounge. Staff in the lounge were surly and unhelpful. The food service was minimal.

On the return journey, the flight from Maun to Johannesburg was pleasant and the cabin crew attentive and helpful, as well as apologetic for the fact that the flight was delayed.

It was difficult to imagine that the return flight from Johannesburg to Perth could be worse than the flight to Africa. But it was. For all of the reasons above. And more.

On both flights the business class cabin crew we came into contact with were all men. They appeared to be lost somewhere in the 1960s regarding attitudes and service of female passengers.

We fly frequently in business class on Star Alliance and other airlines. The overall experience with SAA was not at a business class level. The cost of the flights was also well in excess of flights of similar duration on other routes.

We had a wonderful holiday in Africa and have already made plans to return. We will not be returning with SAA.
qwuub: Perth to Johannesburg Return - don't do it!!

Title:
SAA seriously needs to review its training policies and take a page from Singapore Airlines since they are both in Star Alliance. With SIA despite having flown economy numerous times, I can safely say, they are still VERY comfortable. Alas none can be said for SAA. The seats are cramped and the cushioning on the seats are thin, making any form of rest impossible.

The inflight entertainment touchscreen display was unpredictable, requiring numerous taps on the screen to get it to respond, or not at all. It is a very frustrating experience. Friends of mine who were seated in front me, could not get their screens to work at all, and when they raised the issue with the flight attendant, they merely shrugged and apologized, and that was it. Too bad seems to be the silent communication coming from them. When I had a similar experience on SIA a few years ago, they not only moved my seat to a working monitor but also gave me vouchers to use with their shopping service.

The flight attendants were pretty sassy and not in the cute and fun way. Most seems to be stressed and frustrated, and they rarely smile. When my friends and I compared notes, we all agree that the crew seems to be an unhappy lot.

Food wise, it was nothing to rave about. In fact, they announced the menu options available, and the cargo load of their availability. I.e. Vegetarian is 10%, chicken is 40% and beef is 50%. So if you are vegetarian and did not indicate so prior to boarding, good luck. While this is not entirely a deal breaker, it feels like a lack of effort compared to other airlines who will go all out to get you the meal you want, some even improvised to create something just so they know their passenger is fed. Not SAA.

Another problem is the lack of options. SAA only has business and economy for the JFK flight. It will be nice if they can invest in creating a premium economy class that is less than business but more than economy. This is because the price difference between economy and business pretty extremely. So having a premium economy sweet spot for a long haul flight like JFK- JNB will be really nice.

Title:
My SAA experience has to be seen in the context that they only provided the last leg of a Star Alliance/Egyptair flight from Cyprus to Cape Town via Cairo and Johannesburg.This review includes time in both JNB and CPT airports where what went wrong was, strictly speaking, a matter for the airport not the airline. A national airline such as SAA does however have a lot of power to influence things. They do not bother!

JNB is the only airport in the world of which I am aware which will not check your luggage through to final destination. I need a wheelchair. The driver had to push me and all of my luggage between terminals. 1 star!

Insanely, there are separate wheelchair operations for the international and domestic terminals at JNB. I Was delivered to the domestic terminal by the excellent assistant who met me from the plane. I then had to wait 45 minutes before there was another wheelchair available to take me to the lounge. 1 star!

Business class on the domestic flight to CPT was excellent. 5 stars!

CPT has a large number of female wheelchair pushers. They are very good. Nelson Mandela would have been proud. 5 stars for supporting diversity!

The SAA return from CPT to JNB was 90 minutes late. There is no excuse for that on a short flight on the natlonal airline between the country’s 2 largest cities. Despite similarly good service on board to the 1st leg that merits 1 star!

We were promised that, as there were 17 passengers transferring from SAA to Egyptair that Egyptair would wait for us. Remember that both SAA and Egyptair are Star Alliance members. They did not do so. They left on time. All 3 wheelchair passengers missed the flight despite the pushers running the whole way, as did 4 others. 1 star!

Egyptair, illegally, left for Cairo without offloading the luggage for the 7 people who had missed the flight. It took 5 days for my luggage to get from Cairo to Cyprus. Minus 10 stars, though for Egyptair not SAA.

It took till 1AM for the excellent SAA employee who was left to sort out my affairs to do so. Money was no object. There was no Egyptair flight the next day. She booked me on a business class one way flight from JNB to Larnaca in Cyprus via Dubai on Emirates. Not cheap. She also booked me into the most expensive hotel at JNB, the Intercontinental, which is only 50 metres from the front door of the terminal. 5 stars!

SAA still managed to mess up every piece of paperwork they could.Just one example, when I tried to check in on Emirates, I could not do so. They eventually discovered that SAA had booked me 2 separate flights on the same plane from JNB to Dubai and nothing at all to get me from Dubai to Cyprus. 1 star.

Lots of 5 stars and lots of 1 stars. The only fair overall rating is to split the difference and give the overall experience 3 stars!
qwuub: FROM THE SUBLIME TO THE RIDICULOUS
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: My daughter was advised not to fly back to Australia after a serious bout of gastroenteritis. Eventually after no luck and different advice, my daughter went to the airport and was treated with the utmost contempt. Not only did they reject her doctor’s letter and proof of antibiotic medication and other bought, they did not want to let her on the flight and could not ensure where her luggage would arrive! I am absolutely astounded after being told by our doctor that she should under no circumstances fly as a risk to herself and other passengers, that her letter was totally disregarded and she was treated with contempt. This treatment is totally unacceptable and I will not rest until further action has been taken to ensure it does not happen to other poor sick fliers. This was the email I sent to customer service at SAA and have had no reply at all. I definitely do not recommend flying SAA as there is no customer service and the staff are incompetent.

Title:
I flew out of Buffalo to JFK on March 1st to catch a flight to Johannesburg then in to Livingstone. I knew going in that we were on an older plane going, but I did not expect it to be as bad as it was. We were delayed out of JFK for no apparent reason which meant we had to run through the Johannesburg airport to catch our connection. We barely made it. For the first hour of the long haul flight it was ok. Dinner was served at noon and it was delicious. The flight attendants were kind and courteous. No issues there. Once we got past that is when it took a turn. The seat was like sitting on a piece of wood with no padding and the seats are very narrow. I’m not a huge guy but not a little guy and I was getting squeezed by the arm rests the whole time. It was impossible to get comfortable sitting back in the seat because my tailbone was on fire. When the person in front of you reclined any prayer of leg room went out the window. I ended up using my neck pillow on the seat as a donut to sit on, it was that bad. About 6pm local time EST they shut the lights off and “put everyone to bed” then they came around 8 with a dried out half sandwich for dinner. That was the last time we saw a flight attendant until breakfast. If you wanted something to drink you had to go find a sleeping attendant near the galley to get it. It was impossible to stay hydrated on this flight. The entertainment was horrible! The touch screen was as responsive as a gen 1 iPad and the selection was awful. I could only watch Invictus so many times lol. Breakfast came around an hour before the flight ended and seemed decent but I was so sick at that point from lack of sleep and dehydration I decided throwing up in the bathroom was a better option. Once we made it to Johannesburg the flight on SAA from there to Livingstone was fine. Nicer plane, smooth ride, no issues.

The return trip home to Dulles from Johannesburg was a bit easier. It was a newer plane and had a better entertainment system. The seats were a bit more comfortable but the cabin temp was all over the place. Neither of the planes had individual vents or any charging ports at all. Luckily we had battery packs with us.
The operating procedure for the attendants was the same, there for a bit and then non existent. About the middle of the night I asked for water and they were out with 5 hours left on a 17 hour flight. How do you run out of water?

Overall, my mission trip was amazing, but I will avoid SAA at all costs.
crvsd: Michael D wrote a review Mar 2019
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:
What a pleasure writing to you 😊

I believe in giving credit when credit is due. People always have the means to complain about service but never really complement on good service.

I flew SAA on the 18th of January 2019 on flight SA372 from Cape Town to Johannesburg on very short notice as my father suddenly passed away in the Free State.

When I boarded the plane, to my utmost astonishment, I was the only passenger on the aircraft, that made me smile from a day that was dreadful...

And then... The service I had received from the staff was super! (Senior Purser, Vusi Lunga and his assistant) - picture attached- They had found out of my dad's passing in some way and all came and gave their condolences. Even the Captin over the intercom gave his condolences.

I was so surprised at the attention to detail that I had been served with. The host that that served me, when placing the napkin down, made 100% sure that the logo faced me, the softdrink I received had the logo facing me and even the glass was presented in line with the napkin.

The friendliness and passion that I was served in was immaculate! I've been working in hospitality for many years, and I pick up on small details that people usually miss, but not on this flight.

It was the most pleasant 2 hours of my day and I would really like to thank each and every person that was on that flight to make it so spectacular!

I have never flown with SAA yet, but after this experience, you can be guaranteed that you have a regular passenger that will be using your services, and I will tell everyone about the great service!!

SAA is my new way to fly!

Title:
This was our first time flying SAA ever, from what I have heard they are great for affordable flights to and from South Africa as well as within SA. If that is your only concern you are 100% set to go.

For those of you whome like travel comforts, this may not be the airline for you. Prior to our travel I researched SAA quite a bit, their website boasts luxury and creature comforts even for economy passengers, what we received for both 14+ hour flights was horrendous:
1. there were no USB ports to charge your phone, so attempting your own audio without a portable battery is out.
2. The screens were older than most of the passengers, remember the old screens you have to look at from just the right angle to see the picture, yupp that is what you get; on a plus side they do have updated movies but that was about the only plus. (We Traveled in Jan 2018 and had access to titles like Dead Pool 2, Crazy Rich Asians, Darkest Minds etc.
3. The seats were so dated they still had a dual port headphone jack so you are not able to use your own to watch said movies, and the arm rests only went up about 3/4 of the way, so if you want to snuggle up to a traveling companion or stretch across multiple seats to sleep, good luck there as well.
If you are thinking in participating in their step up Program to get into business class, I would caution against it, here's why - I requested the link be emailed to me because we were undecided on if we were going to upgrade our seats. We had a total of four with SAA and decided to bid to upgrade the last two legs; two hours from Cape Town, and 16 hours from JoBerg to JFK. I submitted the request and provided my card details as required and throughout the whole process was promised no charges would be taken unless the upgrade was processed. Turns out to be 100% false.
While traveling in SA from the states my mobile service was not great (getting multiple emails at once even though they were sent at different times), so I sent the email with my request and was advised should we receive the upgrade we would receive a confirmation email and our card would be charged. Upon arrival at the airport I had not received and email yet but was able to login to my account and see my card had been charged. I thought great! Better seats, maybe better screens, for sure at least a USB port to charge my cell.
We arrive to the check in counter and low and behold they had taken the money from my account but REFUSED to give me the seats, the reps at the airport stated we have to contact customer care becuase even though they can see the chrage on my statement that says SAA Step Up Program, it has to reflect the change in their system. So after 30 minutes on hold we gave up our fight in fear of missing the flight and decided and email to SAA explaining what happened would get the refund processed and ensure no similar issue for the longer flight. Again, unfortunately we were 100% wrong upon check in we were told again we only had economy seats even though I showed the rep my statement showing the $3000+ chrage on my card. We were told we were out of luck because customer service was closed and would have to wait until they open, which just so happened to be while we would be in the air.

So as a cautionary tale be careful in setting your expectations, they are not likely to meet them.
qwuub: Most Outdated Airline I have ever been on.

Title:
We travel a lot, to all corners of the world, and its always business class so we have experienced the offerings of many airlines and frankly our experience on SAA 308 was not good.

To those who commute from North America to South Africa and vice versa haev all experienced the nightmare of 2 nights in the air regardless of class traveled. Only 2 airlines offer a one night optoin - SAA from the US and KLM through Europe. We have done the latter and it a very good connection, excellent experience and equipment. This time we opted for the SAA option flying from Dulles.

Our flight from Toronto was delayed and we were the last to board after a mad scramble across the airport. Luckily the flight was delayed by 45 minutes so we were not too embarrassed. However that was where the service problems kicked in and let the airline down badly.

Despite the delay, we were not offered the customary champagne nor the hand towels. Sounds silly and a bit snobbish but we pay a premium for the creature comforts. After take off, the pilot came over the intercom system and welcomed passengers and invited us to sit back and relax and enjoy the flight. It seemed the flight attendants took the matter to heart for it was almost 1 hour before the first drinks arrived. Having been through what we endured, it seemed like an eternity.

The meal was very good and we managed to catch an hour's sleep before we landed in Dakar. After 90 minutes on the ground we were airborne again but since we were exhausted we fell asleep before take off.

Title: Checked-in at JNB with a few hours to spare. Travelling as part of a Group Tour but the others all in economy class. After check-in, went to the (rather average) Business Class Lounge and relaxed. The flight was due to depart at 1010hrs and boarding was supposed to begin around 09.40. At the required time we began to make our way to the gate, but noticing that the 'Now Boarding' sign was NOT displayed, we took our time. The gate was downstairs (a bus to the aircraft) and as we came down the escalator the sign above the gate began to show "Boarding". As we approached the gate - passports and Boarding Passes in hand, the gate attendant turned the sign to "Closed" and turned around to physically close the gate. Even though we pleaded to be allowed to board the waiting bus (our fellow group members were onboard the bus waiting to travel to the aircraft), the female attendant simply said "you're late, flight is closed and your bags are being taken off". This despite the fact that the clock in the departure lounge clearly showed the time to be 1005 - 5 minutes before the flight was due to close. Over the course of the next few hours we had to make several phone calls to Australia to try and get help. SAA were only interested in letting us travel 24 hours later - which was not an option for us as the group were due to leave Nairobi for a game park early the next day. So...we had to travel on an Air Kenya flight - economy class - and spend more than AU$700 per person for the fare JNB-NBO. A complaint has been made to SAA and has been acknowledged (more than 3 months ago) but we have heard absolutely nothing from them since. However, we HAVE heard from various sources that they often close the gate early to try and retain an on-time departure record. All-in-all the attitude of every member of staff we encounter that day was appalling - nobody seemed to care and nobody wanted to even try to help. We will certainly never consider flying with South African Airways again. Their "Customer Service" seems to be completely non-existant.
qwuub: The worst experience in more than 50 years of international travel
