Title:
Just have to tell this story about the service from an SAA agent on our recent trip to South Africa.

It was my 10th time in SA. I’m an American married to a South African, so we come home every year to see family and friends. We booked our air flights on Expedia, and found ourselves at the Cape Town airport (CPT) on January 5th, headed back to JNB, with an itinerary that read “Hahn” as the airlines. I quickly realized that there is no such airlines. We asked for help and were told maybe it was Mango or Safair, but after going to both of those airline counters, we were told that we were not booked on either airline. We did not know what to do. It was 5:00 AM, and we were meant to fly at 6:40 AM. We decided to ask a woman at the SAA counter, if possibly we were on that airline. Sadly, we were not… but what happened next was nothing short of amazing!

She took it upon herself to figure out what had happened to our reservations and what flight we were on. I handed her our itinerary and my phone (which had info on it), and she took off, literally running around the airport, trying to find a solution. We watched with tired eyes as she ran from one end of the counters to the other, inquiring with multiple airlines. Meanwhile, we were losing hope, and believed we would simply have to buy new tickets, and try to take it up with Expedia when we returned to the USA.

After about 15 minutes, she returned with a printout, and like a miracle, had FOUND OUR FLIGHT!!! We were in fact flying on Safair, but not until 8:35 AM. Being both tired and stressed, I burst into tears of joy. She’d saved us! And, we weren’t even flying SAA!!! Who would help a customer that was not even their customer?

I thanked her profusely and asked her to write down her name. If I am reading it correctly, her name is Gloria Julius. She is clearly great at her job and customer service, and we would love for her to be acknowledged, recognized, and maybe rewarded by SAA.

Title:
Staff on the plane are friendly so I can't really complain about the flight. Not the best current and up to date entertainment system, but this is a minor issue in the greater scheme of life.

The ground staff on the other hand, especially at the ticket desk, leave much to be desired. SAA changed our connecting flight through Sao Paulo so that there was an hour to catch our connecting flight to Johannesburg. We previously argued with SAA over the phone that this change was unreasonable and that something would go wrong, but they insisted that this was the only flight they could change us to.

We arrived in Sao Paulo from Buenos Aires (yes - that flight was delayed), had to run to get through security to reach our next flight, and of course, upon landing in Johannesburg, our bags were still in Sao Paulo. Not the end of the world, as we were arriving back home. We were told the bags would be delivered to my office the following day.

Despite several phone calls the next day, in which I confirmed on two separate occasions that my address was in Durban and SAA confirmed both bags were safely in customs in Johannesburg and would be on the next flight to Durban, during the third phone call, I was told that my bag was on its way to Cape Town and that they cannot locate my husbands bag. Yet two hours earlier, I had confirmed the address and SAA had confirmed both bags were in Johannesburg. SAA then explained they could not initiate the track and trace process for my husband's missing bag until 7 days had passed. This makes no sense when SAA has confirmed that they themselves cannot locate my husband's bag.

The worst part of this experience is the attitude of the Sales Desk at Johannesburg International Airport. When the ground staff informed us at Johannesburg Airport that the bags were still in Sao Paulo, they advised that there were available seats on the earlier flight to Durban, and that we should speak to their ticket department about moving our domestic flight earlier due to the inconvenience of losing our bags. The staff member and her supervisor at the ticket sales desk were probably the rudest people we have come across at SAA. They both refused to make eye contact with us when we explained our situation and wanted us to buy a new ticket (despite the later flight we had tickets for being more expensive than the earlier flight). The supervisor rudely told us that if we had an issue we should call the customer complaints hotline, and that they would contact her and she would still not put us onto an earlier flight as it was against SAA's policy.

After giving up and swearing never to use SAA again, we walked to the check in counter where we chatted to the staff there. Well can you believe that they took 30 seconds to listen to us, informed us there was a plane leaving in 20 minutes, called the employee at the gate to check if there were remaining seats, printed our new tickets and told us to run to catch the flight (at NO extra cost). Instead of the staff at the ticket desk arguing for 20 minutes about paying for a flight in 2 hours time, they could have provided great customer service in finding a solution and given us more than enough time to catch an earlier flight instead of again having to run through security to catch a flight.

All in all, very mixed feelings about SAA. Their ground staff need to be properly trained on how to handle customers, though to be fair, the staff at the check in counter were great. As South Africans, we were rather embarrassed with the calibre of people representing our national airlines to visitors, especially when things went wrong. As for the mystery of the missing bags, we will have to see if we ever get them back!
qwuub: Friendly staff on the plane, rude ground staff, lost luggage.

The refreshments offered are meals and accompanying beverages only and you have to go to the back and ask for anything else as the call buttons either are not working or being ignored. On the plus side, the flight itself was smooth and faster than other airlines that go via Europe on the outbound flight with a 2 hour layover in São Paulo. Title:
LETTER SENT TO SAA
RE: DaicyDemas@flysaa.com, AnnetteWolhuter@flysaa.com
Dear SAA Manager(s),
My wife and I had an unfortunate experience flying SAA Wednesday November 28 (SA362 CPT-JNB).
THE EVENT
As managers you are certain to be aware that the inbound flight to CPT was a delayed departure from JNB on the date specified. While on our flight outbound (delayed 1 hr +6 min), the captain explained on the public announcement system that the delay was due to the aircraft experiencing a FOD (foreign object debris) event earlier in the day which required the replacement/repair of an the engine. He added that the flight crew had been “playing catch-up” all day. It’s therefore reasonable to expect SAA flight managers were fully knowledgeable of the compounding delay impact well before the SA362 flight crew announcement to passengers.
Regardless of the delay flight SA362 was to absorb, gate representatives of your airline assured my wife and I, as well as other connecting customers, that JNB flight connections would be held for connecting customers. This was confirmed by all customers negatively impacted customers at the International Transfer desk in JNB. As you are surely aware, the International Transfer desk is where the unfortunate waylaid customers receive vouchers for unanticipated accommodations and for further ticketing of alternative outbound flights.
After speaking with SAA representatives at the International Transfer desk, my wife and I were given hotel accommodations, food vouchers for the night/morning and a piece of paper that we were to present to a British Airlines representative at the International Transfer desk the following morning to secure boarding passes for the morning flight BA50 (JNB-LHR).
We arrived at the International Transfer desk at 5:05 AM (BA50 scheduled departure time - 8:40 AM) thereby allowing the required 3 hour international check-in time. Unfortunately there was no British Airline attendant present. We communicated this to the SAA representative and she allegedly tried to call British Airline. She informed us, after 10 minutes hidden from the counter that she was unsuccessful. We receiving no further assistance nor any situational advise from the SAA staff. We decided to race to the BA ticket counter in the main terminal to present our piece of paper received from SAA the night before, to obtain boarding passes for Flight BA50. We arrived at the BA check-in counter 5 minutes after the gate was closed (7:45 AM).
The British Airline representative informed us that we were required to have boarding passes 1 hour before departure. We explained that we attempted to obtain boarding passes at the International Transfer desk as instructed by SAA at the International Transfer desk the night before. We explained that a British Airline representative was not there. We were then informed that the only time a BA representative would be scheduled at the International Transfer desk would be in the event another air carrier communicated and coordinated an international customer’s need for a re-booking on a BA flight.
We then returned to the International Transfer desk where we were instructed go to the SAA Ticket Sales desk back in the main terminal. Upon our return, we were offered only a SAA flight to LHR. After 1 hour we were issued boarding passes for the SAA flight from JNB-LHR and instructed to retrieve our own luggage from BINAIR, and that we were responsible for re-checking them onto the JNB-LHR re-assigned SAA flight. We also received meal and day-hotel vouchers from SAA Ticket Sales representatives.
I retrieved our luggage from BINAIR after a 4 hour wait for BINAIR personnel to find our luggage in the airport baggage storage basement. This confirms that it’s reasonable to believe SAA had NO INTENTION to transfer our luggage to the morning BA50 flight.
While at the hotel, browsing the internet, I found our originally planned Virgin Atlantic Airline flight (the day before) was scheduled to depart only 5 minutes after the scheduled SAA departure from JNB-LHR. I was never told of this at the SAA Ticket Sales desk, nor were we offered this option for ticketing re-assignment.
Fully understanding this situation, I explained to the SAA representative at the Ticket Sales desk later that afternoon that we had paid for ‘premium economy” seats on Virgin Atlantic from JNB-LHR. We requested from the SAA representative at the Ticket Sales desk to re-book us on the Virgin Atlantic flight to LHR. Mind you, we had already checked with Virgin Atlantic regarding availability of the flight scheduled to depart 5 minutes after our assigned SAA flight. The BA representative (on the opposite side of the main terminal) informed us that the flight was wide open! Yet, after informing the SAA representative of the BA availability, SAA refused to accommodate our request due to (ask explained by the attending representative) the extreme inconvenience and extra work such a modification would require! Furthermore, even though the cascading effect of the SAA delay was not our (the customer’s) fault, absolutely no compensation was offered for the Virgin Atlantic ‘premium economy’ costs.
CUTTING TO THE QUICK
The unfortunate fact is that CPT South Africa Airline gate personnel were either misinformed by supervisors/managers or knowingly misrepresented information to JNB connecting customers that had connecting flights. It’s quite clear as an industry practice that air carriers not part of the SAA “alliance of carriers” have no obligation to delay scheduled departures for delayed connecting customers from another carrier. Yet, SAA totally misrepresented this fact likely knowing full well our connecting Virgin Atlantic flight to LHR would not delay for us.
Once at JNB, my wife and I, were assured at the International Transfer desk passage a BA flight the following morning. It’s suspect that SAA representatives even made an attempt to make necessary coordination/communication given the British Airlines representative response the following morning.
The proof is clear that SAA had no intention to ticket us aboard the BA50 flight since our luggage took 4 hours to retrieve from the bowels of the airport storage by your contract baggage carrier (BINAIR).
The denied request for re-booking from SAA to Virgin Atlantic (originally scheduled the day before - & on this particular day having known availability) becomes an obvious “POUCHING” maneuver by SAA. Then there is the issue involving the refusal of financial compensation for the cost of premium economy class seating on our originally scheduled flight with Virgin Atlantic.
The practice of LIES & DECEPTIONS demonstrated by South Africa Airline during this unfortunate experience thrust upon numerous connecting customers seems representative of a company-wide standard operating procedure that permeates from top management down.

NEXT STEP
I was employed by the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for 34 years. I’m well acquainted with air traffic, airport operations and various authorities that would have a keen interested of the sub-standard professional practices of your airline. If SAA wishes to avoid further duress beyond a mere customer’s complaint, I will entertain any mitigation efforts.
Happy Holidays,
Mark J. Cool
Flight SA362

Title:
I've been reading the reviews for the last 9 months of this airline because I booked a tour package and this was the airline they use. Based on reviews on Trip Advisor I was dreading it. To my surprise, it was actually very good.

Flew economy from JFK to Johannesburg. Flight was on time. Gate agents were friendly. I made a $1500 bid to upgrade to first class but was rejected even though there were empty seats.

I see complaints about seat quality, but what economy seat for 15 hours is going to be comfortable? Good leg room. No power source.

My monitor worked through out, however it's old and dated. Grainy and older movies. Knowing the monitors didn't always work based on reviews, I loaded up my phone with movies and brought a power brick charger. I just ended up watching my phone's movies. The woman in front of me didn't have a working monitor. Be prepared and plan ahead.

Flight was smooth until we reached Africa, then it was a little bumpy. Service was ok. I'm not looking for a whole bunch when I travel. Attendant did make a small snide comment about my luggage storage when we were getting ready to land, but I'm going to let that pass, as for the the whole flight they were efficient in their jobs.

Breakfast was tasty but the vegetarian dinner was not. It's an airline so I don't expect much.

From JHB to Cape Town I was upgraded to First Class with SAA's step up program for $70. Much nicer. I laid the seat down and slept for two hours. Service was better but I slept through the meal they provided.

Coming back to JFK my bid of $1500 was accepted and I flew first class. Much nicer seat, better service, better food. However, the pilot warned us it would be bumpy when we took off. Smooth for 90 min then bumpy for the rest of the trip. Nothing terrifying, but enough were I couldn't sleep. So I really couldn't enjoy the lay flat bed. Monitors did go out for a bit on take off and they had to reboot the system, so I just went to the phone again for entertainment.

The Premier lounges in Cape Town and Johannesburg were both great.

Bottom line is this: the flight is long both ways. Get yourself mentally prepared for that. Bring back up entertainment. Try to bid up if you can afford it. They got me from NY to Africa and back safely and on time. That's what counts the most.

Title:
It took me 7 years to convince my mother to come for a visit here in Melbourne, she is not keen on flying, and made it clear that should she come, she will only travel on Qantas and not on SAA, so after 7 years of begging her to come, she agreed. We then booked her ticket on Qantas to travel from Cape Town to Melbourne, and she was very happy, but since Qantas does not fly to or from Cape Town, that part of the flight would have to be on another partner airline, which turned out to be SAA.
So, yesterday afternoon my mother departed from Cape Town, nervous but excited, so all seemed to be well, however this morning around 4am I got a call from a very distress mother, calling from Jo’burg and informing me the flight from Cape Town to Jo’burg got delayed, and as a result she missed the Qantas flight to Sydney, but SAA offered to put on the next SAA flight via Perth, at first my mother refused, but after some convincing I managed to get her to agree, my mother handed the phone to the SAA lady who informed me of the new flight details, I took the opportunity to ask her if it would be possible to upgrade my mother to business class, but the lady told me they can’t, since now they are already supplying my mother with a replacement ticket at their cost. We agreed and the SAA lady proceded to book the flight to then realize that my mother’s suitcase was left behind in Cape Town, so not on the flight with my mother, as you can now imagine, my mother was now very anxious, distressed and upset, she will now arrive in Melbourne without her luggage, and not knowing when if and at all it will arrive. I will probably have to take leave from work tomorrow to take my mother to the shops to go and buy some clothes and basics she might need, I am sure SAA will not compensate me for my lost income.

All I can say is, if you are thinking of flying to SA, dont use SAA !, and if you fly with Qantas to Cape Town, insist the book you on British Air (Comair), spare yourself the hassle and stress related with flying SAA.
qwuub: BE Warned anybody thinking of travelling to South Africa on SAA, think TWICE-the wheels are for sure coming of !!!!

Title:
This was a return journey LHR-JNB-HLE-JNB-LHR. It was booked as a through ticket with South African Airlines, though the JNB-HLE leg is run by the 'wholly owned subsidiary' SA Airlink. There is one flight scheduled each weak, on a Saturday. It turns out 'scheduled' is a rather fictional term. Because they have a monopoly, it is a very expensive flight.
St Helena airport has been described as 'the world's most useless airport', and, despite lovely character of the island, and the friendliness of its residents, this statement is sadly true. If you actually get here on the outbound leg, you seem to have very little chance of getting back again. What are called weather delays are frequent, leading to cancellation. While the weather may be the case at the point of cancellation, further attempts to make the flight then happen at 3-4 day intervals if you are lucky, and this time separation is not due to weather, it is due apparently to the fact that Airlink have very few pilots (4, possibly 5) who are capable of landing here, and not enough planes to schedule a flight as they are occupied elsewhere. Thus, after 3 days, another flight was scheduled, but it was cancelled while en route as well. I am still here, with another attempt scheduled 3 days later.
What they then don't tell you is that when you have an onward connection , because it is a 'weather' delay, they can charge you a hefty 'penalty fee' (c. £400 to London) for the privilege of re-arranging the longhaul flight that their own failure has led you to miss. This is even the case if that filght is with South African on a through booking. If you are with another airline then you will have to buy an entirely new ticket most likely, and if you need to travel urgently (as you are already a week late) this could cost you over £1000. If your rearranged flight from St Helena is itself cancelled, as happened this week, you may then get hit with yet another penatly fee, and in principle it seems this could happen again and again, as admitted by the agents here. Given this, how you are meant to be able to secure a confirmed long haul return booking without hundreds and potentially thousands of pounds in costs is unclear to say the least.
Airlink use an agent called Solomons in Jamestown, and even if you have booked with SAA or your own agent, you will hear nothing from them, even when they have your e-mail and phone as part of the booking, as Solomons seem to think they have the right to take over everything. SAA will not respond to e-mails either (phone reception is almost non existent and v expensive on St Helena), and if you can manage to get into their website (limited web access too!) to confirm, check in, etc, no mention is made of this payment, and nothing you can do reveals it, even though the site says you have a confirmed ticket and no outstanding payments. Requests to their agent or to Airlink directly for a printed/e-mailed invoice stating and explaining the cost are met with blank stares. Despite the size of the bill, credit card use is almost non-existent on St Helena - you can pay by faxing a long form to S Africa and hoping, and may also be asked to send photos of both sides of your credit card - in the UK this request would be illegal, and obeying it would void all your rights to credit fraud cover from your bank!! In short, in a week of delay and despite multiple requests, SAA or Airlink have failed to contact me, other than sending one generic e-mail telling me the details of the first re-arranged flight, AFTER that flight had itself been cancelled!! Having cancelled their flights, their website is not updated until several days after, which then means even if you can speak to your airline (including SAA itself) about re-arranging your long haul flight, they will say they can do nothing until they can see that the flight has actually been cancelled.
In short, Airlink, and their relationship with their parent SAA, is a complete and utter dogs dinner, and their 'service' is non-existent. It is perhaps no wonder that it seems to be strongly rumoured that SAA is close to going under. What they are doing appears to be on the borderline of, if not actually, fraudulent
All this is a great shame for St Helena, as the island is beautiful, very friendly and has a lot to offer the more adventurous traveller. However there is no point even thinking you might come here unless you have a 1-2 week buffer after your planned return to take account of the high risk of getting stuck here..
dmrsr: St Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha - Johannesburg
qwuub: Do not attempt this journey unless you have days or weeks available to be delayed

Title:
Terminal 2 at Heathrow has no dedicated SAA lounge but there is a choice of four or five affiliated airline lounges. The ones in Departures B, closest to the gate, are Singapore Airlines or Air Canada.
Embarkation was straightforward and cabin crew pleasant and efficient. My request for sparkling water however was met with "I am afraid we cannot open the bar until after take off". However a bottle did miraculously appear a couple of minutes later.
The new seating on the A330-300 in business class is 1x2x1 so all seats have direct aisle access, a big plus. The seat itself is roomy and has adequate storage for small items but I put my shoes in the overhead bin. SAA provide a small mattress which provides some support from shoulders to hips, a very nice duvet and a generous pillow for when you turn the seat into a flat bed.
Downside of this seat is the limited adjustment of the backrest when seating.
SAA do not allow passengers to access the IFE until some point after take off when cabin crew decide to switch it on. I found that the choice of entertainment was very limited, nothing like as good as Emirates.
Food comprised of dinner and breakfast. Dinner was surprisingly good but breakfast a disappointment although on the return breakfast was not too bad.
Drinks service was good and cabin crew excellent.
There is but one toilet available to business class which is shared with cabin crew.

Title: The A340 has surprising leg room in economy.  We are not tall, but could stretch our legs fully with room to spare.  The seat configuration is 2-4-2, so we find the two seat - window and aisle - the most comfortable.  The seats are rather comfortable.  Comfort is paramount on these 15 + hour non-stop flights.  The flights left on time and arrived on time.  The cabin was kept at a comfortable temperature, and even though both flights were more than 2/3 full, they didn't feel cramped.  I am miserable on long flights because sleep just won't come.  On these flights, I was less miserable than most.  More than half the flight to Johannesburg, and all of the flight to JFK, were in the dark.The cabin service is where SAA falls down big time.  About an hour after takeoff, they served the evening meal - nothing spectacular - but edible.  Then, nothing until about two hours before landing when they served another passable meal.  For the ten hours in between meal services, I think the cabin crew got off the airplane and went to a party.  Maybe a max of two crew members were anywhere around.  To their credit, there was always bottled water, apple juice, and light snacks on the counter in the galleys.  For those lucky souls that can sleep, it made no difference.  The other downside was the somber nature of the cabin crew.  I think they trained with some of our domestic airline crews. In flight entertainment is okay - games, movies, and a moving map that is discouraging to watch,  Suggestions:  If you fly economy, and want to go non-stop to South Africa, this is a good choice.  Take some snacks, a good book, I tunes, or something to pass the time.  I recommend compression stockings.  They really help with long sits.  Get up and move about.  The aircraft has two aisles so you can make a circuit.  Be courteous to the people ahead of you - don't kick the seat, or bounce stuff on the tray table.  When you recline, do just one notch so you don't compress the passenger behind you.  South African customs/immigration is a snap.  When you get back to JFK, be prepared to walk a long ways to get to customs.  Go to the bathroom on the plane before you land.  I think JFK is the pits, but you're stuck with it if you use this flight.Enjoy!  South Africa is AWESOME!
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:

They are quick to hand out food and drinks and again to clean it all away so you can get some sleep. Their staff are professional, friendly and service oriented. Title: We'd booked for our Namibian holiday about 12 months' previously.  When we arrived at the check-in counter two hours before the flight, we were told that they were very sorry but SAA had overbooked and 8 passengers would not be going on that flight.  We were two of them.  The young man whose job it was to deliver this news was very kind and polite and helped us phone to cancel that night's accommodation in Namibia, and took us to the branch office of our car hire place to sort that out.  He also gave us two vouchers for R3000 (AUD$300) to be used on a regional flight within a year, not transferrable, and probably completely useless to us, and a magnificent R70 each (AUD$7) for food and drink for the 12 hours until we could get on a plane.  To be fair, we have flown on SAA many times and this has never happened to us before.  The fact that we had flown with them many times and were members of their Voyager Club should probably have given us some sort of precedence, but perhaps they don't consider loyalty important.So, a warning to all those who think that because their ticket says 'confirmed', it's only the ticket that's confirmed, not the seat on the plane.  In all other respects, SAA has been quite reliable and on time, but when this happens at the beginning of a holiday, it leaves a bad impression.

Title:
Flying South African airways started off as a pleasant experience. The airplane for the international leg of the journey looked new and clean. The air conditioning and cabin pressure felt very appropriate and natural.

The entertainment system was modern with good options. I like the fact that they had few fairly recent and good quality Nollywood movies. There's room for increasing the number of movies though.

The airplane used for second leg from Joburg to Cape Town wasn't so new and had a central entertainment system with just one movie showing. But hey, it was just for 2 hours...

The food served was the usual airline food. Not the best, but fills the stomach.

On my arrival in Joburg, there were arrows and instructions leading local transfers to go get their bags and re-checkin their luggage. On getting my luggage, the cover had disappeared and my luggage had a bit of scratch.

On my return journey, no such instructions or arrows were available. I confirmed from the airport staff at OR Tambo if I had to fetch my luggage and re-checkin; they checked my tickets and said there was no need. But lo and behold, my luggage didn't follow me to Nigeria. When it was tracked, it turned out it was still at OR Tambo. This got me really angry. I got back the luggage after 2 days....The lock had been tampered with and the luggage now looked ugly with scratches and dents.

The eventuality of my return journey sort of destroyed the earlier good impressions which the airline had given me.

Title:
I must admit; I was very apprehensive about flying SAA across the Atlantic... However, my flight turned out to be one of the most enjoyable flights in years!

It all started in the airport where I had a great meal in the FNB Slow Lounge. Not the airline's lounge, but if you can get in. It is really good with fresh food.

Note that this flight is on the A330-300 which is MUCH better than the A330-200 that SAA operates.

As I boarded the aircraft, I was welcomed by the air hostess. She took my jacket and offered to hang it up for me. Smiles all the way.

The new seats a superb! Everyone has isle access due to the 1-2-1 configuration, so no bothering the person next to you. Each seat is designed like a cubicle which offers greater privacy than your standard seat. There is also plenty of space next to the seat on the arm rest where you can store your belongings. The seats include good space on the side where you can keep your shoes and other goods. The screens are big and have both a remote and a touch-screen options and the seat is a complete lie-flat seat.

The service on the flight was possibly some of the best that I have experienced as an adult. The cabin controller made one feel that there was nothing that you could not have. Foor example, the wine selection; I could not decide which wine to have, so the stewardess said "why decide? Lets do a wine tasting and then you can choose"? So she brought 3 glasses and poured the options that I was considering. From there, I could decide which one I wanted with lunch.

Granted, it was a day flight, I still got a good rest in. The food was good and there was plenty of mineral water (I flew with Emirates in June and they tried to ration me on the water- I drink a lot, but you would expect them to have enough for the few people that do drink a lot of water). I had about 2.5l on the flight.

A note: There was a bit of dirt that was not cleaned under the remote in the arm rest. Small things like that can be quite irritating. And if you are going for a 100% great experience, then 99% would be a fail (Management Theory of 99%)

The pilots were also great! What a smooth landing.

Upon disembarking, the said stewardess thanked every single passenger in the cabin personally and by name! And when I saw many of the reactions, I knew that I was not the only one to have had such a great experience.

Value for money- it was also a super option!
crvsd: Mike C wrote a review Oct 2018

After checking back in we were offered a letter confirming the overnight flight stop with a 25% discount on our next flight with SAA only and no code shares valid for 12 months. Once on board a newly constituted flight, SA9260, we thought that arrangements would be made by SAA to inform its code share partners that passengers would not make their connecting flights. Title:
Our flight on South African Airways was a connecting flight from Houston to Johannesburg through United Airlines, and via Wahington DC

We found the flight to Johannesburg to be a pleasant one. The flight was @ 17 hours, with an hour stop in Accra, Ghana. The check in, that included passport checks, was very easy. The staff was very accommodating and made the overnight flight quite comfortable. They were constantly serving us dinner, drinks, and more. Because the flight was an overnight one, we were supplied with blankets, socks, tooth brushes, toothpaste, as well as eye masks....in the economy section!

The aircraft was a new one, with comfortable seats with adequate leg room. It was equipped with very good entertainment options like movies, games, etc. that also made for a comfortable flight.

Because there was a stop in Accra, Ghana, the original flight staff changed. The staff was not as attentive as the original one, but there were no problems and we made it to Johannesburg without incident.

I would definitely recommend South African Airlines to anyone traveling to Africa.
qwuub: First Flight on South African Airways

Title:
I have to admit I was disappointed with SAA. The aeroplane between Heathrow and Johannesburg is fairly new with the cabin nice and clean and some of the nicest economy toilets I’ve seen in a long time.

However the seats are really narrow and the legroom probably the smallest I’ve ever experienced in long haul. It’s so small that even as a size 10 I felt like I was constantly touching the gentleman in the seat next to me which made me feel very uncomfortable. I couldn’t get comfortable at all as the area is so tight. Having taken an overnight flight both ways this really had an impact with the least sleep I’ve had on a flight in ages.

The pros are you still get an amenity pack with eye mask, socks and toothbrush & paste which was good and something you don’t get on a lot of airlines these days.

Although the cabin crew offer plenty of drinks before and during dinner service including bottles of water, which is great, they offer absolutely nothing again until breakfast. Therefore there’s about 7 hours with no access to drinks unless you go to the crew area or press the service button so I was very dehydrated at the end of the flight.

I don’t think I would chose to fly with SAA again.

Title: Our flight was due to leave Hoedspruit at 2.30pm.  Reception at our Game Reserve rang SAA at 9.30am to check the flight was still operational (apparently they need to do this on a daily basis as SAA is so unreliable).  Advised everything was in order we left and drove to the airport, checked in and deposited our luggage.  At 2.15pm we were advised the flight was delayed at least 2 hours.  This caused concern as we had a connecting flight to Dubai departing at 7.10pm.  Given that the plane was now not leaving until 4.30pm – plus a 1 hour flight – plus waiting for our luggage to be unloaded – plus getting from the domestic terminal to the international terminal and checking in – we were really worried.  The staff at Hoedspruit advised us Johannesburg were aware of the situation and ground staff would be waiting to assist us.At last we arrived at Johannesburg, were ushered off the plane and onto a bus for the ride to the terminal.  Half the passengers were on the first bus and the other half waited for a second bus.  The second bus arrived and the rest of the passengers boarded and the bus left.  What were we doing? The bus driver was chatting to a friend!  In the end the passengers started to yell at him to stop talking and get us to the terminal – a few passengers actually approached the ground crew and told them to get the bus driver to stop talking and get us to the terminal.We finally arrived at the terminal, retrieved our luggage (at this time I noticed the black strap around my suitcase was missing but as we had to rush to make our connecting flight I didn’t give this much thought).  We literally ran through the airport to the international terminal, checked in, lodged our luggage and arrived at the boarding gate just in time to join the queue to board.  Yes, the gate had opened and boarding had commenced – we were very lucky. Our Emirates flight left Johannesburg on time. When we arrived in Dubai and retrieved our luggage I found the black strap from my suitcase inside the suitcase.  I thought Customs must have opened my bag to check for something, that was until I went to put my jacket on (my jacket which was packed in my suitcase) and found 2 packets of Dunhill cigarettes and a man’s watch inside my jacket pocket.  I would really like an explanation as to how my suitcase was opened, my jacket removed, articles placed in my jacket pocket and then the jacket returned to my suitcase – with whoever did this leaving their cigarettes and watch in the pocket. Avoid this airline at all costs!

Title: Our first flight from Cairo was due to depart at 10.50pm on Sunday. Two weeks before our vacation began we were advised this flight had changed from 10.50pm to 10.30am the same day.  This caused problems as we had already booked a day tour in Cairo (non-refundable).  Our options were to take this flight, leave a day earlier or leave a day later.  None of these options were suitable to us – we couldn’t leave a day earlier as we were still on tour in Egypt, we couldn’t leave a day later as our South African Safari started that day, so we were left with no alternative but to accept this change.  Unfortunately, this flight had us arriving in Johannesburg at 6.30pm and our connecting flight didn’t depart until 9.50am the following morning – which meant a 16 hour wait in the airport terminal after an 8 hour flight (as well as the 3 hours at the airport required before check-in) a total of 27 hours on the go!.  Our travel agent contacted the SAA representative and tried to obtain some sort of contribution to an overnight hotel or even a meal voucher.  Advice came back that no contribution would be considered however if we didn’t want to accept this flight SAA would issue a full refund without charging any penalty fees.  Great Customer Service – NOT!We found a hotel near the airport (at our own expense).  The following morning we arrived at Johannesburg Airport – our luggage was unloaded from the Shuttle Bus and a man in a blue uniform and wearing a lanyard around his neck with a sign “Porter” took our bags and asked what airline we were travelling with.  He then took us to the SAA check-in counter.  After checking in he then told us there was a 200 Rand fee for taking our luggage and assisting with the check-in.  Obviously this is a scam however we didn’t know it at the time so we reluctantly paid.  After talking with other people we were told this is a common scam conducted at the airport and even though the airline staff are aware of this, they (or any security personnel) don’t do anything to stop it.  OK, we put this down to a learning experience for us.  Our flight to Hoedspruit was due to depart at 9.50am.  We arrived at the gate at approximately 8.45am.  Looking at the Airline Departure Board we found our flight but the notice next to it said delayed til 10.20 so we went and had a cup of tea.  Watching the Departure Board all the time the notice still said delayed.  After 30 or 40 minutes we went back to the gate to wait.  There was a ground staff member sitting down using her mobile phone (obviously something very important like Facebook or twitter).  Two (2) other families arrived at the gate and we started talking about the delay.  After a while I approached the staff member regarding the delay and was told the plane had departed on time.  She further advised Johannesburg was a ‘silent’ airport with no boarding announcements and that she was screaming (her word) for all passengers to board.To cut a long story short, we were told our luggage had been removed from the plane and we would need to claim it and then re-book another flight.  We would also need to pay for either an upgrade or a new ticket.  When we protested that it wasn’t our fault as the Departure Board still said the flight was delayed we were told we shouldn’t be looking at the Board as the departure time was on our boarding pass. Seriously? We travel extensively so I feel we can speak with considerable knowledge and experience when we say the Departure Board is used to convey information to passengers such as flight delays, change of boarding gates etc.  To have a staff member tell us we shouldn’t be looking at the Departure Board but just our boarding pass is ludicrous! Now, we have re-claimed our luggage, gone to the desk and re-booked the next flight to Hoedspruit, paid a nominal fee (thanks to the gentleman at the ticket counter who was the only staff member to offer any form of courtesy and customer service) we have again checked in and dropped off our luggage and proceeded to the departure gate even though we had a couple of hours to wait.Boarding time arrived and we were told the plane had been delayed 15 minutes, (we didn’t even bother looking at the Departure Board).  Another 20 minutes passed and we were ushered to a waiting bus to take us out to the plane.  On to the 2 buses we crammed (6 seats and 80 passengers) and stood there in the heat (15 metres away from the air-conditioned terminal with plenty of seats) for another 30 minutes.  At last we left – drove to the plane, boarded and flew to Hoedspruit!

Title: WORST flight in recent memory. The plane was old and in need of refurbishment. No outlets to charge gadgets, plus no outlets at the gate (where we were penned in for security screening purposes) led to everyone being in a mood most foul. The flight was THREE hours late leaving Joburg so they could try to get the entertainment system working. They even talked about us switching to another plane which would have been a nightmare. Eventually they got the entertainment system mostly working, and off we went - finally. My seatmate had business meetings in Dakar (our connection) and we were so late, he and his colleague nearly cancelled them. They groused that the airline is in bankruptcy (true?) and is the worst. I believe them. Bad as all this was, the worst part was the crew on the first leg. Surly and rude; I've never encountered a crew so dreadful, and I fly a fair amount. The lead in economy class barked at us over the intercom periodically, commanding us to SIT DOWN NOW! and other charming, customer friendly admonitions. At some point in the middle of the flight, I woke up parched and realized I needed water to take my medication. I wandered back to the galley. I asked the flight attendent who was working our side of economy. She looked at me blankly like a deer in the headlights and did not respond. That left Mr Charming to bark at me: "GO SIT DOWN!" No water of course. He then came on the intercom to yell at everyone that the seatbelts sign was on and to sit down. This was not a flight with much if any turbulence; I think they just mainly used it to manage us. There was another flight attendent who was wearing so much after shave you could smell him from the far aisle of the plane. I cannot tell you how happy I was when we finally landed in Dakar and this cranky bunch deplaned. The last leg was relatively uneventful. Once I got back, I emailed SAA customer service to tell them my experience with the flight crew. I've been back nearly three weeks and have heard ZERO from SAA. Guess this is how they operate? I wouldn't fly them again. There must be better options.
qwuub: NO response to my email to Customer Service!

Title:
I recently had a series of three bad experiences on Mango Airlines owing to undue delays in departures, one after the other. I therefore decided to use SAA instead, at higher cost. After three subsequent SAA flights I was very satisfied. They were on time, comfortable seating and legroom, pleasant experience altogether. Until today's return flight (Monday 10 September 2018) from Durban King Shaka to OR Tambo on SAA flight SA578.

I had already checked in 24 hours ahead of time, online, for convenience to airline and myself. I arrived into the terminal building at Durban King Shaka 30 minutes before departure, when flight boarding had only just started. Hastily made my way through Security checkpoint and towards the departure gate (A10). Upon arrival at the boarding gate, at seventeen (17) minutes before departure time to be exact, I found to my utter surprise that the gate officials were packing up and closing the gate! They claimed that I ‘was late’, and that boarding was complete - even if I had been already uploaded, and in time, arriving seventeen (17) minutes before scheduled departure time at the gate. They said that I had been offloaded from the flight, and that my boarding pass has a note (in FINE print) that the airline closes the gate fifteen (15) minutes before departure.

IF there was such a stringent and inflexible rule for whatever reason, I, for one, have never seen it rigidly applied in all of my multitude of flying experiences, locally and worldwide - not with me nor with anybody else.

1. There was no notice to me at the pre-Security checkpoint where my boarding pass was scanned into the system, i.e. that I must rush, or that I am at risk of being offloaded.
2. The SAA ground staff gate officials said that I will have to go back through Security and purchase a new ticket. This was the last SAA flight for the day so it would have had to be another airline.
3. They did not even make the slightest of attempts to call for an exception with the specific SAA flight controller or the commanding officer of the aircraft, to still allow me on the flight. There was AMPLE time to accommodate me (even as a last remaining already-checked-in passenger). If they had done that, the flight would still have left on time (even ahead of time if that is what this was all about).
4. I was forced to back-track, back through Security, and buy another ticket from Mango, on their last (and reportedly fully booked) flight to OR Tambo. They kindly assisted and managed to somehow get me a seat, although I had to pay full ticket price.

My questions are simple:

1. WHY? Why would SAA treat their customers who has a fully paid and valid ticket at ca. R1200 cost (one way), and who are already checked in, in this manner?
2. How did my arrival at the boarding gate, seventeen (17) minutes before scheduled departure time, inconvenience the flight, its passengers or its crew? It would have taken me one (1) minute to get from boarding gate to aircraft door entrance.
3. Is this where SAA’s customer service levels and standards have dropped to, i.e. to NOT go the extra mile when customers need it most?

I will be putting in a claim to SAA to recompense me for my financial loss and this highly unsatisfactory, unfair and quite arrogant treatment. I will wait to see how they respond, before I decide to fly with SAA again.

PS. I have learned that Mango Airlines has since upped their game and are mostly back to on-time departures again.
qwuub: Be warned! SAA offloads you prematurely at boarding gate

Title:
For a long flight, the trip was remarkably easy. The service, food and wine were all fantastic and were highlights of the flight.

The seat was a standard business class size seat which fully reclined and had more adjustment options than I knew what to do with. There was a plug for charging devices, an adjustable reading light and an optional privacy divider between you and your neighbor. Passengers are also provided with a kit with toothbrush, hairbrush, lotion, ear plugs, eye cover, etc. It was comfortable enough and a long enough flight to get at least a reasonable amount of sleep.

On the downside, it is a bit of an older plane, so the entertainment system is dated and I noticed some people having difficulties with the functionality of their seats.

Bottom line: If you are looking for a new, luxurious plane, this flight is not for you. However, if you can look past the older equipment, the convenience of the direct flight and the excellent food and service make this a great option.

Title:
We had a 2 hour layover in JNB and missed our flight due to delays and poor instructions my SAA staff. Our JFK-JNB flight was delayed by nearly an hour. The pilot insisted this was unusual and here was nothing they could do but in looking at flight stats, it’s obvious that this flight is often delayed.

We didn’t “make up the delay in the air” and were promised that ground crew would be at the plane to assist those of us with connections. There was no one there, or along the customs route sonwe continued to the luggage drop off where they refused to take our luggage and directed us to the SA Airlink desk upstairs were we waited, watching the minutes tick away until we were called to the ticket agent only to be told that since we had our boarding passes they should have taken our luggage downstairs or allowed us to carry our luggage on since we only had 35 minutes to make our flight at that point. Now we had 20 and could try to run. Which we did, and the bus to the plane had already left and the gate was closed.

We ended up having to go back to SA Airlink and rebooking.

We had 5 domestic flights during and all closed the gate 15-25 minutes before the flight to load the bus, all flights were half empty, all served a light meal, even for flights that were only an hour. Special meal requests were not honored and no gluten free meal was provided for my travel companion. The provided meal was reliably delicious (roti, sandwiches, chicken salad etc). Seats were small.

SAA did not honor seat requsts booked through their codeshare partner (Jet Blue) and we were stuck in middle seats for the way home. Jet Blue connecting flights were delays because of weather on both returning and departing flights, weeks apart, so I would recommend the IAD-JNB route instead. I will be flying through the Middle East or Europe next time.

Being a Gold member of the Star Alliance air travel program, I received complimentary priority boarding, which gave me a good opportunity to store my backpack and arrange things for the flight. I selected the airline primarily for the flight duration time, price, my experience flying with South African Airways, and the benefits of flying with a Star Alliance, airline partner. He had two bags on his hand and couldn't take the boarding pass out of his pocket to show it for a third time. Keep in mind that before going up the steps we had just shown the boarding passes to another agent. He was so awfully rude to us that other passengers seated in business class told the agent to calm down. Unfortunately, he was the flight attendant for business class. We had requested vegetarian meals months before but because of this so-called "upgrade" done a few days prior, they had not brought in our vegetarian meals to business class, so we were left without meals as well. Title:
Swiss Flight for 2 persons in Business, both Star Alliance Frequent travel members of Miles and More for many years, origin in Malaga – Zurich – Johannesburg – Victoria Falls, and return same airline and Star Alliance. One person has to continue his journey to London - Bogota – Pereira at arrival in Zurich.
The flight down to VF was excellent and we really enjoy our well organized trip and holidays. The nightmare stared at the return flight:
• Same conditions and same Alliance StarAlliance. At the airport after check in to Johannesburg, SA 040 following to the Check in employee was on time so we checked our Luggage to be send trough to Malaga.
• All of the sudden SA040 was shown as Diverted in Transit area, but no more comments
• No further information for more than 2 hours, no airline employee to speak with no info, Passenger where obliges to get out of the Transit area and find out at the StarAlliance airline what was going on, but with chance you got a smile and a quick response, “ I am not in control of the Situation, Johannesburg is taking care, so please wait…..” after 3 hours the information that the flight will arrive at 16.00 h and will depart around 18.00h, our connecting flight to Europe gone.
• Finally we are allowed to eat something after several trips through customs, security checks and Airline office
• At 18.00h the Airline lands, at the same time all passengers are requested to join the gate for an important information, Airline employees announces that the company has send a smaller plain and 48 passengers must stay in the city, the remaining will be sorted out to take the flight to Johannesburg.
• We were lucky, as our agency in Spain did arrange for us an option with KLM from Johannesburg to Amsterdam the same night, to continue to Zurich, but as we lost the connections we were oblige to stay overnight in Zurich, one person had to head to Rome – to go to Malaga, the other on luckier as he could change his flight to the next day to Pereira via London.
• Our luggage arrived one with the passenger the other one 7 days later in Malaga.
• No employee from Swiss, was able to arrange any hotel, nor any cover on first necessary hygiene items nor in Johannesburg, nor in Zurich.
Claim Case no. 1807-LX-12684 is still open since over 30 days. After several correspondences to Swiss no answer, just a word saying that they passed the claim to their Sub contacted company South African Airlines, member of StarAlliance.
The delay and the consequences, including telephone charges to Spain in order to change tickets, hotels, first hygiene items, one exchange clothes, Euros 1.484,60 not counting the Daily for 2 lost days at 250 Euro for 2 persons 1.000 Euro. Only the tickets alone in B-Class over 5.900 euro.

The claim is very well based: European Airlines have alliances, agreements within Europa and other the world. If you purchase a ticket with Swiss, Lufthansa MEMBER of STARALLIANCE, is the ORIGIN company in charge for delays, substitutions, claims, etc.
In our CASE no. 1807-LX-12684 Swiss and STARALLIANCE is in charge but still try to avoid the problem passing the matter to their partner company. After many claims no one is moving.
Unfortunate, Scoundrel, Cold and Arrogant

Title:
SAA is in the process of upgrading their long haul fleet and currently operate a really good, brand new, Business Class product from JNB to Washington D.C. Which I am dying to try!

I booked a last minute Business Class rewards ticket through United. What I love about this flight is that it is the only nonstop direct option from JNB to JFK. I take this route a lot to visit family in SA. Although, usually via London, Amsterdam or Paris. So to jump a direct nonstop flight back to NYC was a real treat!

Checking in at O. R. Tambo is awesome! There is a private “Voyager Platinum” checking in desk that I didn’t even know about. My driver from the Four Seasons dropped me there. What a lovely surprise.
Security and passport control can be busy, but this was smooth today.
The Voyager lounge is huge and offers a decent selection of food and refreshments. I grabbed a quick bite and a glass of bubbly before boarding. Boarding for the USA can be complicated but today it went seamlessly.

The Business Class seats on this A340-600 are in a 2-2-2 configuration. Which can be tricky if flying solo - which I was. I had selected a center aisle seat, ensuring I had direct aisle access and avoiding having to jump over a sleeping stranger. Or worse, have them jump over me.

Let’s be clear this is an older seat. But it does lay flat and it has plenty of room. There was a really cool Brazilian lady seated next to me who worked for the UN and we ended up having awesome conversation!
The food was decent - not remarkable. But most importantly, I had a great night’s sleep. A solid 8 hours. Which on a 15 hour flight can make a huge difference. I’m 6’2” and always appreciate a good night’s sleep on a plane! The entertainment system is really outdated and low quality. Which is a drag.
I fly Virgin Upper Class, Air France and KLM Business Class to and from South Africa a lot. These are great products - but for a direct nonstop flight. This SAA flight rocks.
qwuub: SAA Business Class - still the best Nonstop JNB - JFK
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:

I spent many phone calls to Lufthansa and South African airways in Germany, however nobody was responsible, and no help was offered. It seems we are only money-providers for some airlines, but not valuable customers. Title:
Our flight from Johannesburg to Perth was not a happy experience, despite being in Business Class. The seats are very old fashioned, and while they recline - with difficulty - they are not very comfortable; the overnight bedding, while clean, did not improve the comfort - and we had to set it up ourselves as business class crew did not bother (plus we had to fold it away prior to arrival). Food was very disappointing - a dried out salad for dinner, wine was Ok, breakfast most disappointing with tasteless egg offering (the chakalaka beans were the sole redeeming factor). Even worse was the coffee on offer - obviously instant coffee of a type not seen in Australia since about 1978. Service was woeful with trays being thrust upon you before table was set up; minimal empathy with passengers, and no understanding of modern service expectations.
This leg of our flights (commencing on 26th July) contrasted with SAA flights to and from Dar es Salaam on which the service was very good, and the food and wines on offer were very acceptable. Our initial flight from Perth To Johannesburg (27th June) featured OK service, and good food and wine.
qwuub: Patchy service and the cabin crew from hell
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:
This is the second time I have travelled to Africa on SAA, and this time around was much like the first. Friendly staff, cramped uncomfortable seats (economy).
What on earth gives with those armrests? It only folds to the vertical, so once folded up, it's even more in the way than if it was left down! The seats are designed by Recaro, but clearly the designer never actually sat in the seat. They are rock hard, narrow even for my skinny butt, and poorly shaped. No footrest either.
I can put up with most inconveniences on a long flight, but those seats take the cake. They are truly awful. Arriving at my destination with a sore back, and butt is not my idea of a good time.
Having said that the staff are friendly and courteous and do their best.
The cabin is not cleaned properly; I found filth in the recess where the remote control goes. The toilet had brown stains under the seat.
The inflight entertainment is basic and old fashioned. No USB for recharging devices.
I love Africa and plan to travel there again in the future, but next time will be with a different airline. Those seats are a horror story.

Title:
As a Physically Challenged frequent flyer I was forced to choose SAA as my prefered airline EMIRATES, was too expensive due to me departing at the start of school holidays (SAA 316 departed 22 June 2018 ).
Returning home i was boarded virtually last whereas other airlines normally board their assisted passengers first. This is ludicrous as when boarding last we struggle to place our luggage close at hand.
Never once was I asked if I required assistance from any of the Airport nor on-board Staff.
I generally never eat on board and when flying EMIRATES they will ask you why you not eating and Diplomatically offer you a snack or fruit but never on this flight. The snack offering was poor and as South Africa produces world-class fruit its strange I could not get an apple or any fresh fruit. As for the UAE yoghurt offered, it was terrible and meant to taste like strawberries which I could hardly taste.
Whilst taking a walk around the plane after flying about 6-7 hours I saw a staff member emerge from their upstairs sleeping area in his pyjamas and proudly walked around in the galley. This is UNPROFESSIONAL to say the least.
I've decided in future never to fly SAA again and choose another date irrespective of the price.
I tried unsuccessfully to secure a seat closer to the washrooms as behind these seats I can store my Prosthetic Leg as 13 hours without having to remove my prosthesis causes skin rashes which then take days to dry & heal. I've flown Emirates, Qatar, Singapore and Cathay all long flights and they ALWAYS accomodate me.

South African flights between JNB and JFK are direct. The shortest route. That's nice. And cheaper than others. Also nice. Actually, every seat sold is heavily subsidised by the South African taxpayers. Also nice. But the big subsidy means the planes are always full, full, full. Not so nice if you enjoy an empty seat next to you.

This route is hard. It is a tough trip. You have to spend 15 endless hours jammed into a cramped cattle class seat in an old plane with no power points and a retro seatback TV from the 1980s. Some of the audio points don't work. Tough. Luck of the draw. Some of the TV's don't work. Tough. Live with it. The plane is full - you can't move.

If you are not going to/from NY, but are connecting in the USA, look hard at Delta flying direct Joburg to Atlanta as a better option. The planes are modern, with power at the seats and WiFi and a way better, real, up to date entertainment system. The Delta seats are still horrible, but the flights are not as full.

Title: 9 family members were with me on this epic safari adventure.  The seats were all close together, and each had a neat package of pillow, blanket and headset, plus toothbrush & paste!  Much excitement and hard to sleep as the flight left at 9am.  Food adequate, free wine, & soft drinks, but no coffee (excuse was possible turbulence). Huge list of movies (one of us watched 6!) games, music, etc. Attractive attendants from all ethnicities and announcements made in Afrikans as well as English.  Planes almost full in each direction.  Beautiful sunrise on eastbound leg, and perfect landing - could not feel the "touch down"!On the westbound, the trip seemed shorter as it was night and we all managed to snooze, as well as to walk round the enormous plane a couple of times to get the circulation going...It's still a miracle to me that such a massive machine can fly so effortlessly for 15+hours quietly and safely.  Attendants pleasant & helpful.  I worked for 3 other airlines and this one is excellent!

Please understand that I was grateful to be able to actually lay down and sleep on a 10 1/2 hour flight and for once, not in economy for a long flight.  I'm just reviewing the flight.  I awoke about 7 hours after take off and was a little hungry and just wanted a little something to eat, just to tied me over until breakfast was served. My husband was already awake and had been for the last two hours.  I rang the call button and ask the flight attendant if I could have a cup of tea and maybe a cookies or a snack.  I was informed that the seatbelt sign was on and they couldn't help me at the moment.   Funny thing.  I'm usually really good at noticing that sort of stuff.  I missed that. But, when I told my husband what the FA had said, he started laughing because he said the seatbelt sign had been on for the last 2 hours and there hadn't been a stitch of turbulence. 20min later, the seatbelt sign was finally turned off and the FA did return.  The tea was not a problem, but I couldn't get any snacks because they didn't have any.  They wouldn't give me any food from the dinner I didn't eat and even the tea was a clear inconvenience to her because "I'm setting up for breakfast!" (But I did get the tea) and thank god I always travel with my own snacks otherwise I would have chewed my left arm off as I was so hungry.   Breakfast was . . . ok. Nothing to write home about, but it was food and satisfied the hunger.  The guy across the aisle from me gave the cooked breakfast back saying it was not good. Entertainment is old school tv's and so during descent, they will not let you continue watching.  Also, personal devices are not allowed to be watched during descent, even if you have it in airplane mode.If you plan on travelling with South African Airlines, be wary.  The business class is not up to the standard of some of the other airlines out there.  Go with low expectations . . . and your own snacks.

Title:
As a frequent flier it's always fun to join an SAA flight at a foreign airport and hear familiar accents.
We're all proud of our national carrier but also aware of the difficulties it is facing
For a passenger the issue of safety is a given but the things that make a journey pleasant are catering, entertainment and service.
On this flight only two boxes were ticked for me.
Box 1, we got home safely.
Box 2, meals were good and offered more choices than one expects in economy class.
Box 3, entertainment was very poor.My arm rest handset was not functioning. The picture and sound quality made it impossible to watch anything and the touch screen was a nightmare. On a long journey this is unacceptable.
Box 4, as far as service levels are concerned the flight was full and the staff had to focus to get their job done. In our compartment two staff managed each side.
Three of them were great in all respects but one spoiled it for his colleagues and the passengers.
Haughty to the point of rudeness he managed to put everyone's back up.
In my case I asked for a second bottle of wine to keep for the dinner service and was told I hadn't finished my first one as he walked away from me.
Later in the early hours I walked down to the aft galley and asked for a bottle of water. The look I got from this chap was not attractive.
So the point I make is that little things can make or break our airline experience and, things being as they are, SAA really needs to raise the bar if it is to outshine its rivals.

Title:
Well where do I start.

When I tried to board my flight from Nairobi, I learned that South African Home Affairs purposely did not lift a travel restriction which expired in January of 2018. I even had the documents to prove my eligibility to travel but SAA was having nothing of it. So I wasn´t allowed to fly.

Now the Kenyans working in Nairobi did contact Home Affairs, and I was cleared to travel the follow day. The manager even rebooked my flight for free, which must have made somebody angry, for when I arrived at Immigration, I was purposely detained so I missed my flight to Cape Town. Obviously Home Affairs and SAA were working together to ruin my trip.

The next day when I went back to the airport, SAA in OR Tambo airport claimed they have nothing to do with Home Affairs, and unlike the staff in Nairobi, they refused to rebook my ticket, and insisted I buy a new ticket.

At that point I refused to spend any additional money in South Africa and caught a flight to Windhoek, Namibia.

So I have made a formal diplomatic complaint to the US Embassies in Johannesburg and Windhoek, and am in the process of filing lawsuits against SAA, whilst reporting them to the Kenyan, South African, and US Civil Aviation Authorities. I am also preparing a lawsuit against South African Home Affairs.

Lesson: Do not travel to South Africa, and certainly do not fly SAA.

South Africa is a country which simply rips off tourists to such a degree, and has such contempt for foreign visitors I have to say I will never go there again, as it is basically a country where the laws simply do not matter, and government officials regularly use their power to pursue personal vendettas.

Title:
I am usually extremely wary of SAA as they are known for their bad service but this time on both the outgoing and incoming leg of the flight, I was absolutely flipping delighted. The staff smiled and laughed and on the way back Helen Smit took a passenger to task for not listening to the rules and putting her blanket away. The passenger tried to laugh it off but for Helen it was not a laughing matter. Safety of the passengers and all of us was paramount.

Nothing was too much trouble and the aircraft was shiny and new as well as clean. The seats could have been further away from the front but all airlines are going the route of more people less space. The captain was friendly and kept us informed of what was happening and the check in and checkout was smooth and without incident.

I order Vegetarian when I travel alone in case of food poisoning no matter which airline I travel and I have visited 82 countries on more than 20 airlines and trust me they all order food from the same source so you can never be too careful. My food arrived and was piping hot and absolutely delicious. I couldn't fault anything on the plate. Not for breakfast or for dinner.

When I arrived at the boarding gate, there was a supervisor showing the staff how to greet passengers and reminded them to smile and be nice and that was a welcome change. When I had to change my ticket from one date to another, the call centre was just fabulous. She heard my tears as the visa people were awful and I had had a terrible experience with VFS Visas. They waived the change fee and charged me only the change in ticket price.

To all the staff at SAA Well done and I will be doing a review with photos and story in the latest print copy of Anytime Magazine which is distributed to South Africans worldwide.

PS My ticket was paid for in full by myself in my personal capacity as I visited my children.

Title:
I have flown well over 3,000,000 miles in my life and on countless airlines.
In all the years, and all the flights, I can honestly say I have NEVER encountered such mediocre food, abysmal service, and such a rude and unfriendly flight crew as I did on my business class flight to Johannesburg on May 29, 2018 out of JFK.

Not one of the flight attendants ever smiled or was helpful or friendly – and I am not exaggerating-NOT ONE. Anytime I asked for something, they acted like they were doing me a favor. From the moment we embarked, the service was poor.
No food or wine menus were distributed. In lieu of studying what was available for meals, one of the flight attendants read the choices to us in such a low voice that we had to ask her 3 times to repeat. She was not only impatient, but insolent when we politely asked her to repeat.
I was traveling alone, but the gentleman sitting next to me was South African and he was furious at how we were treated. He told me he had never experienced the unfriendly and nasty atmosphere that prevailed on our flight.
Unfortunately, for my business class return flight home to JFK from Johannesburg on June 6th, while we did receive menu’s, this time the entertainment system wasn’t working properly. In addition, only one of the flight attendants smiled.
You can be sure that I will do whatever I can to avoid flying South African airline again. For what I paid for my seat , it is a travesty.

Title:
This was my first experience booking a flight with SAA and I will NEVER purchase anything from them again.I wish I could give them zero stars. I never show up to flights late and I always plan for heavy traffic. Which is why when I left my house 5 hours before my scheduled flight (mind you, it only takes 45 minutes to get to the airport from my house) I thought I would be okay. Little did I know, it would take 3.5 to get to the airport. When I got to the airport, SAA ticket counter was CLOSING and they refused to offer me a refund, change my flight, or help in any way at all (even though, according to them, the flight wouldn't be taking off for another 1.5 hours since I didn't show up 2 hours before flight departure they couldn't do anything). Instead they gave me the airline number and said I should contact them to book a standby flight for tomorrow for $300 plus a $600 for the ticket difference. I thought this was a rather gross penalty for being 30 minutes late to a flight but I agreed to pay the fine and called the airline. When I called the airline they said they said my best option was to go back to the airport and ask them to book a standby flight instead for cheaper. By the time I got back to the airport all of the phone lines were dead (SAA doesn't have a 24 hour call center so good luck getting help for ANY flight after 5:00pm) and there was no one at the airport to talk to. I called again the following morning and before I even got out a word, the SAA call center supervisor was extremely rude and informed me there was nothing she could do to help me. Mind you, I hadn't explained the situation or said hardly three words. I had to actually talk over her to get a single word in as she was intent on screaming at me. When I finally explained the situation they said I had to now pay $600 in addition to the $600 ticket difference. They said it was because I was a "no show". I tried explaining that I was not a no show - that in fact I was at the airport 1.5 hours before the flight departed and even returned to the airport when they told me to. The customer service was so bad that they actually HUNG UP on me while I was on the other line telling them I still needed help. All in all, SAA willfully tried to scam me into paying $1200 ONTOP of the $1100 I had already paid for my flight. Their call center was verbally abusive, snarky, and dismissive cutting off every sentence I uttered and droning over and over again that there was no way they could help.

SAA is a thief and a monster. This is my first and last time giving them any money and to the day I die I will never use this airline again. As God is alive, I know they will plummet for the evil they are doing and the money they try to steal from people will be taken from them 10 fold.

Title:
The flight leaves early on Saturday as it returns the same day from St Helena. Landing on the island before the wind gets too strong is also a good idea as the airport has characteristic wind shear.
Get to Jhb airport early as the departure gate is very far from checkin, too far for comfort. There is the opportunity to buy coffee and a croissant at the departure gate, thank goodness. A small duty free is also there. The plane is especially selected to handle this flight ( short landing ) with 25 rows of four seats. You land in Windhoek on the way there to ensure the tanks are full in case you are unable to land on the island. Our rear toilet had blocked and was fixed in Windhoek, thankfully. There are multiple snacks served in flight, but we had to stay on board, without air conditioning, in Windhoek. Leaving Namibia, over the 'skeleton coast' was an especially rewarding view.

The island comes out of the cloud and looks as precipitous and gnarly as you'd come to expect. Everyone is on tenderhooks as you make your approach, wing flaps fully extended. As the plane crossed over the cliff it bucked and skew to one side with some passengers overreacting, of course. I had my heart in my mouth I must admit as we slammed down hard and applied full brakes.
It's a quick walk to the airport terminal which is lined with locals just out to watch the landing and they clapped as we entered the terminal. The return flight is uneventful and you don't land in Windhoek on the way home.
dmrsr: Johannesburg - St Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha
qwuub: Flight to St Helena was well catered and lived up to expectation.

Title:
A few months ago, my mom and I flew to South Africa to visit family on South African Airways, a partner of United. We booked and paid through United and spent about $12,000 total. The flight there was fine. On our way back, while waiting in the airport, we found out that our flight was cancelled due to bad east coast weather. It took us hours to get out of the terminal with no assistance from SAA personnel. By the time we got to the ticketing booth, we were told that the flight for the next day was full, but we had a confirmed seat on the flight the day after that. They put us up in a hotel but would only pay for one night, so we had to pay an extra $1000 out of pocket.
We returned to the airport two days later. We had been in South Africa for about a month, and we wanted to get home. The lady at the check-in counter checked us in, told us we were in first class, and gave us our boarding passes. Out seats were 7A and 7B, first class seats.
We got to the gate to board our plane, and as they scan our ticket they tell us to step aside because there was a problem. At this point, we had waited 3 days to get on this flight, and they were not letting us on.
As it turns out, the flight the day before had been cancelled also, and our seats were given to people who were on that flight instead of making them wait as were forced to. We had our tickets and seats assignments, but it did not matter to them. They gave up our seats. We were told that we could either fly coach or wait until we could get another first-class ticket which could be days (and, as we learned from this experience, would not be guaranteed.) This was a 16-hour flight, I am very tall, and we were not prepared to be flying coach. Neither of us had pillows, water, or food, but we got on the plane after we were assured that we would be seated together. We, of course, were not seated together.
Because our flights were originally cancelled, we had to cancel our connecting flights through united, which we cannot get a refund for, and we had to pay for new flights. All of this amounted to a loss of $4000 as well as the $6000 from the first-class ticket.
We contacted United and South African Airways right away and were told that a request to refund the $6000 would take a few weeks. So, we waited and called weekly. We would be happy with the difference between the first-class tickets we purchased and the coach ticket we were forced to use. Today we found out that United and SAA denied our refund request and we will be getting no money back from them. I have been travelling my entire life since I have family all over the world and I have never experienced anything this traumatic while traveling, and it does not seem fair to not even receive the money that we are owed.
crvsd: Samantha G wrote a review May 2018
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.
