Title: This is the worst check-in I have ever experienced. I arrived well before my departure time. I had checked in on line. I was assisted in self ticketing my baggage and then I had to join a queue to drop off my bag. SAA share a bag drop with Air India. I had to join the queue. After an hour I explained to the Lady walking around that I was on the SAA flight which departed before the Air India flight and still had to get to my gate. She told me to wait and this is the procedure the airline wanted. I pointed out that there was no one at the SAA business check in and asked if I could use that. Again I was told to wait. I spoke to her twice more and got the same answer. An hour before my departure I was still in the queue. She then called for any SAA passengers. I said I was one. She then said " Anyone else before this lady travelling on South African Airways". I was then allowed to use the business class check in as I was in jeopardy of  missing my flight. Why should I have to queue for over an hour to drop off a bag? If my flight leaves before Air India why should I be delayed by having to queue with them. I rushed to the gate which took me nearly 30 minutes to go through the x-rag and luggage check and walk to the gate. Boarding of my flight was announced. They made me wait another 20 minutes to board, as my seat was near the front of the aircraft and they board from the last rows first. Again I had to sit and wait. The flight was ok and on time. But getting onto the plane was a very unpleasant experience which I do not want to repeat again.

Title:

we were greeted on board to champagne. There was a choice of meals which were individually served on proper plates with proper cutlery and even a tablecloth on your meal tray. Title:
We chose South African Airways because at the time we booked they had a good special on flights from Australia. I have to say I won't hurry back.

The plane interiors are tired. Clean enough, but a feeling of being worn.
The economy section did have *just* enough room for my legs. Sadly the seat width was so narrow my poor wife was pinched between the armrests for the whole trip. Unfortunately the arm didn't fold up out of the way so I could share some of my space.

The entertainment system is very slow, with small grainy screens. The range of choices was also really bad. The newest movie was more than six months old and is available in the supermarket in Australia. Not all the screens were working either. On the way over my wife's screen was missing all the yellow, and quite a few screens didn't work at all within sight of my seat.

Dinner was a choice of Beef stroganoff or Chicken curry. I went the chicken, my wife went the beef. I regretted it, as the curry sauce was chemical tasting and the chicken dry, while the beef was lovely.

Breakfast the next morning was just really bad all round. Rubbery eggs that had been kept warm 10+ hours at that point, stale bread, and everything tasted vaguely plasticky. The Tea was actually really good. Fresh, not stewed, not contaminated with coffee and not too strong.

I had an aisle seat, and during the night I was full on bumped awake by several different cabin crew on at least six occasions. Now I may be tall and wide, but not a single passenger managed to knock me awake on a 11+hour flight. Just the cabin crew.

We booked some months before the flight, and at the time I thought it passing strange I wasn't asked about food allergies. Closer to the date I checked my online details and couldn't find anywhere to communicate my allergy to Sesame. When we checked in online, still no questions about food requirements.
Now I may have missed that part of the booking process, but I am fairly careful about these things because if I make a mistake I have a wretched 24 hours of gut pain. It may also have been missed because we used a 3rd party booking system.

O. R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg at the end of the journey is a shocker. It was 5:30am local time, but the arrivals terminal looked like the airport in the Zombie movie 'Warm Bodies'. There are dozens of cleaners, staff members and security guards standing around, but very few of them actually doing anything. Slow queues and slower service. One security guard spent five minutes we were stuck in a queue in front of him energetically excavating his nostrils and wiping it on his pants.
Everything in the airport is dirty and lots of things like doors, escalators and ceiling panels are broken.

To transfer to a domestic flight we had to collect our luggage and then recheck it, even though our flight was supposedly with the same airline group.
qwuub: Average food, bad entertainment, revolting airport
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:
We flew South African Airways flight 346 from Capetown to Johannesburg on an Airbus 346 widebody. We arrived at the boarding gate about 15 minutes before the boarding time printed on our boarding pass and saw that boarding was already underway.

Possibly because we were flying an A346, this was a bus gate. That means we all had to cram into the bus with our carry-on for the ride over to the plane. It was crowded but not too terrible of a ride.

Since this was a remote gate, there was no jetway and you needed to use the stairs to board.

The flight itself was fine -- plenty of overhead space, decent enough legroom and a fairly clean plane. There was no in-flight entertainment but a small sandwich snack was served on this short flight and the flight attendants were friendly and efficient.

Overall, a good, uneventful flight and I wouldn't hesitate flying SAA on this route in the future.
qwuub: Great CPT-JNB Flight for the Money

Title:
This is the story of my most recent experience of travelling with SA Express. It is followed by a brief analysis of the issues the airline is facing and what could be done to improve matters.

Wednesday March 14. I am travelling to Barcelona from Gaborone to attend an educational conference and am reasonably excited as most of my travelling for work is done within Botswana. I check in two hours before take-off, say goodbye to the family, go through security and out onto the warm tarmac to board SA1784, the 17:15 service to Johannesburg. Hand luggage is handed in at the steps and we take our seats and listen to the safety demonstration before being sprayed with insecticide. And that is when the trouble starts.

The port engine refuses to start and we are offloaded. It is then I found out that this Dash-8 has been sat on the apron since it originally refused to start at 11am. By this time, some of the morning passengers have been sprayed with insecticide four times. They are mosquito free but not going anywhere.

Once back in the terminal a flustered SA Express official refuses to answer any questions before saying she is going to the office to ‘make a plan’. We do not see her again. After about 20 minutes I chat with a very pleasant gentleman working for SAX and he tells me those with connection are being put on an unscheduled 18:30 flight. In the meantime, an Airlink CRJ200 arrives, is turned around and departs. Our empty Embraer 190 then lands at 18:10, but it takes half an hour to organise who is flying on it and when we do board at 18:40 one passenger is missing and the manifest is incorrect. The passenger is found but the manifest only arrives at 19:10, meaning it has taken an hour to load 30 passengers. We eventually take off at 19:15.

Arriving at OR Thambo at 20:00, it is 10 minutes before the hand luggage is unloaded and our bus takes us under my departing Swiss Air flight to Zurich before dropping us at the terminal. A spirited sprint to the transfer desk sees me and a fellow passenger arrive five minutes too late for the connection. We are helped by a pleasant gentleman and a very energetic older lady at the transfer desk. I am told that there is a KLM flight that would take me via Amsterdam that evening and there are seats available. However, the ticket office closed at 19:30 and they cannot book the ticket from the transfer desk. Several phone calls are made to the Domestic office upstairs which is supposedly open until 21:00, but no-one answers the phone – meaning that half an hour before closing everyone has gone home. I am told there is no more they can do and to go to the transit hotel where there is a voucher waiting. I go to the hotel and there is no voucher so it is back to the transfer desk to get a new one. I am told to come back at 08:00 to rebook my Swiss flight. I check into the hotel at 21:15 and have a R150 supper, courtesy of SAX. At least I am luckier than my fellow traveller. His flights are on separate tickets so he has to purchase a new ticket via his travel agent.

Next morning, I am at the desk at 08:00 to be barely greeted by the early morning shift who are still applying makeup. Indeed, the girl on the next counter takes a couple of attempts and a comical incident with a wet-wipe to get her lipstick right. I am offered lunch and dinner vouchers as they cannot help at the moment, but I am told I should come back at 12:00.
Lunchtime, I am back at the transfer desk to be told I have been rebooked on that evening’s Swiss Air flight but there is a problem printing the boarding pass so I should come back at 16:00.

Back at the desk at teatime and there is a new shift. Unsurprisingly, they know nothing about me and my flight has not been booked. This takes 15 minutes explanation before the gentleman serving me disappears upstairs to the ticket office and returns half an hour later with a new ticket. I check in with Swiss and eventually relax.

The Zurich flight is very pleasant and, despite only having an hour in between connections, I make the Barcelona gate with some time to spare. I arrive three hours late for the second day of my two day conference, but still I am impressed by my hosts and have a great time. Next morning I have time to visit the Camp Nou before returning to the airport.

The flight to Zurich is again pleasant although we land in a blizzard. Again, despite having only an hour between connections, they are easily made and I am soon on board their Johannesburg flight. It is now snowing heavens high and de-icing means that we take-off 40 minutes late but the captain assures us he will make up the time. True to his word, we touch down twenty minutes early at 10:20 Sunday morning.

I am soon at the SAX gate for SA1767 which is due to leave at 11:30. The boarding is delayed and then starts slowly – not a good sign. Sure enough, I am denied boarding along with another 30 passengers. The reason? The 74 seat Dash-8 has a technical problem and has been replaced by a 30 seat Embraer. We are rebooked on SA1777, a new flight, at 14:30. Many passengers are furious and one is in tears. The SAX member of staff dealing with us tells me that technical issues are a regular occurrence and are becoming even more common.

We are given a R70 voucher for a restaurant where the cheapest sandwich is R69. If you wanted a drink of any sort your meal choices were either a muffin or ice cream. Eventually we board ZU-SOB. As we entered there was a noticeable smell of vomit in the cabin and the source was discovered by the lady in 10A whose seatbelt was covered in traces of the previous occupant’s last meal. We arrived in Gaborone at 15:40 to an ironic round of applause. I was too tired to join in.

Between checking in on Wednesday afternoon and returning Sunday teatime I had missed half of my conference and had spent more time in ORT than actually at my destination. However, my experience really only acts to highlight many issues facing SA Express.

Most concerning is safety. On the departure board on Sunday at ORT more than 40% of the SA and SA Express flights were delayed, several for ‘technical’ reasons. Staff at ORT admitted this was a constant occurrence and one of the technicians at Gaborone described our Dash-8 as ‘finished’.

Some staff I spoke to were hoping that the proposed merger with a slimmed down SAA would help overcome the maintenance concerns. By keeping a smaller fleet of the newer aircraft, their thinking was that service issues would be minimised. It has to be questioned, though, whether merging two failing airlines with similar management problems can lead to success.

Communication and service are problems all companies face and dealing with your customers, even though they are not always right, is key to success. SA Express’ communication with its passengers was almost non-existent. Two members of staff did stand out for offering realistic information, but even then I had to seek them out. In an age when I can book a flight anywhere at any time using my phone, it is unbelievable that SAA/SAX cannot seem to book a flight in its main hub after 7:30pm. The fact that the final flight had not been properly cleaned and still had vomit on one of its seat belts summed up the level of service offered.

If these delays had happened in Europe I would have been entitled to €850 compensations in addition to meals and hotel. Would a SADC system of compensation work? Would it force airlines to improve their service delivery? It would not need to be set at European levels (though given local ticket prices, perhaps it should) but it would both help relieve the anger of passengers and also encourage airlines to fulfil the contract they enter into when they sell a ticket. A voucher for half a meal is not compensation, something SAX appears not to understand.

The one ray of hope for SAX was the professionalism of about three quarters of the staff I met. They were working hard and doing their best in really trying situations and still going the extra mile for the customer. They are very aware that their jobs depend on it. However, they are being betrayed by the other quarter who seem disinterested in their customers and a management that seems to be running the airline into the ground.

Would the world miss SAA and its little sister? Yes, it is an airline with a long pedigree and many people have happy memories. However, those memories seem to belong to an older generation and why the current generation of taxpayers should continue to subsidise passenger flights in a country with so many other needs is a question constantly being asked. If SAA and SAX were to cease operations it would lead to considerable short term job losses, but it would also open up vital routes to real competition and create sustainable opportunities. The whole of Southern Africa could benefit and, as to the question would the world miss SAA, it is doubtful if the world would even notice its demise.

Three weeks later I am still waiting for a response from Customer Service.
qwuub: SA - Operated by SA Express. Horrific.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: I had been told that the service on SAA has deteriorated a lot in recent years, so decided to try it for myself after a break of a few years .Due to my ticket type, I was unable to check in online. However, I was shown to a desk by a very pleasant concierge and checked in very quickly. Boarding of the flight seemed to be a bit chaotic with premium customers pushing and shoving to get to the head of the queue. Apart from that, it went smoothly. The one thing that did bug me, however, was the lack of attention to hand luggage. The airline advertises a strict hand luggage limit of 7kg, yet there were huge bags and backpacks which filled up the overhead locker space. This resulted in passengers having to look for space anywhere on the 'plane. We were  offered a good selection of drinks after take off - all complimentary, followed by the meal service. The meal was surprisingly good. The choice was the normal chicken; beef or pasta! I chose the beef and it was well cooked and tasty. There was a side salad which I didn't eat; a bread roll; dessert and cheese and biscuits followed by coffee, tea or licquers. The service was pleasant, friendly and efficient. I was fortunate enough to have some empty seats next to me, so was able to stretch out and sleep. Having said that, the economy seats had a reasonable amount of leg room.I have had far less leg room on some of the American carriers. The entertainment system worked well and there was a large choice of programmes covering all genres. Bottles of water were readily available as were extra blankets and pillows. The toilets were kept clean throughout the flight - a real bonus!! The breakfast was , again, very palatable. I had the sausage and egg option. My baggage arrived speedily - in fact - it was waiting on the floor next to the carousel by the time I arrived in the baggage hall. All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by the improvement in service and would probably use SAA again.

Title: We were surprised how little legroom there was on a flight taking 18 hours. We had much more legroom on the 2 hour flight from Johannesburg to Cape Town on South African Airways than we did on the 18 hour flight from Washington, DC to Johannesburg. There were plenty of meals served. They also base their meal selections on a percentage basis, saying that they "trust if you don't get your first choice the second one will be equally enjoyable." Um, ok. The in-flight entertainment was poor. It was a struggle to find movies to watch (when you are on an 18-hour flight you have to find some way to fill the time) and any TV shows they had usually only had one episode. The music choices were terrible. I don't even remember what we paid for the flight but if we ever go back to South Africa, which we might, it was fantastic, I would look for another airline before booking with South African Airways.

Title:
Q. What international airline carrier and major national airplane carrier won’t accept credit cards (Australian) as payment direct on website or over the telephone to a sales team
member?
A. South African Airlines - horrendous

While travelling Africa I decided to fly Capetown to Livingston, Zambia and the Livingston to Johannesburg, on South African Airlines.
Booked the flight online, received the email confirmation stating tickets had been reserved but no payment was made. Then tried with 3 other credit cards and all three credit cards from different Australian major banks where rejected.

I then emailed South African Airlines (SAA) reservations to enquirer about tickets and to confirm tickets were still required. 2 weeks later, 3 emails later and still no response from SAA.

Finally my call (4th) to SAA was received, took 1hr21min to explain ticket situation and told tickets where to be renewed (at a greater expense than first reservation) got to the payment/transaction process of this telephone conversation and the sales staff said “your credit card can’t be accepted, we don’t accept international credit cards over the telephone ”. (Could of said/asked/told this at start of sales conversation).

Get to the airport the day we are to fly to Livingstone and the ticket prices jumped to $869usd from the original purchase reservation price of $356usd. Grrrr SAA

Come to check in and I hold Gold Status for Star Alliance, allowing 32kg for baggage allowance. The staff at Capetown and Livingstone tried to charge me 8kg over weight limit when my checked bag was 31kg and Gold Status allows 32kg on international flights. It took a trip out of security checking area to the customer sales team to clear this matter (I wasn’t charged extra $$$), but it took time and was a hassle for all involved.

Now it is time to fly and SAA won’t allow any mb devices to be used as inflight entertainment on flights. WTF. The mb phones are on flight mode, they don’t interfere with electronics of flights and SAA didn’t provide any inflight entertainment in the first place. !!

The business class hostess was the grumpiest, rudest and meanest air hostess I have ever come across (I’ve travelled 73 countries). She had Bulldog aggression, so much to say everything for her was a hassle - no customer service at all.

Feedback to SAA - online credit card bookings to accept international credit cards as you are a international airline carrier.
qwuub: International carrier won’t  accept international credit card

Title:
If ever there was a stunning customer complaint about a flight that actually arrived, this must be it.
This is the letter I sent to SAA, on March 7. They can't even be bothered to reply. Not a word from them.

1. Where is the money?
I booked the 1st SAA Taipei-Bulaweyo flight through Orbitz, using either of these cards mentioned above.
The Orbitz website tells me that my card was rejected. No reservation was issued.
My bank immediately calls me and tells me that an attempt was made to wire 1500usd to 4 different airway-companies/agents
3 payments of around total 700usd did not make it through, because of an instant error code that was sent to the bank.
But, 1 payment of about 800usd was successfully sent and accepted by SAA.
Nothing was issued or refunded.
Orbitz has no record of anything related to this. No data about my payment or my existence.

I then call Orbitz to explain this to them, and they suggested I try again, this time letting the Orbitz operator do my booking. The exact same thing happened.
The Orbitz person tells me that my card was rejected. No reservation was issued.
My bank immediately calls me and tells me that another attempt was made to wire 1500usd to 4 different airway-companies/agents
3 payments of around total 700usd did not make it through, because of an error code that was sent to the bank.
1 payment of about 800usd was AGAIN successfully sent and accepted by SAA. Nothing was issued or refunded.
Orbitz has no record of anything related to this. No data about my payment or my existence.

SAA customer Service in SA could also not find any records, but had me on long-distance telephone hold for 2.5 hours. More money lost.

By now I have lost 1600+usd, which was my holiday spending money, and no way of getting it back from SAA, in time for my flight and holiday.

A third attempt was made to book this flight, and done successfully through another agent. Data above.
Now I have lost 1600usd and spent another 1600usd with barely any money left for this holiday.
Cancelling the holiday was not an option, due to many factors I will not list here.

2. What about my holiday?
With the very vague phone-promise from SAA to investigate the invisible money transfer, I left for Zimbabwe. In the end, SAA released the 2x 800usd, but 2 weeks later.
I spent half my holiday in Zimbabwe within a compound in Bulaweyo, with little or no money to go anywhere.
This was not the holiday I had in mind.

3. The flight(s) et al.

This next part actually involved my partner as well, with whom I flew together. I pushed him hard, convincing to spend more money on a quality SAA flight, rather than a much cheaper/faster Cathay. After all was done, he had no hope of getting any satisfaction from lodging a complaint with SAA. He has moved on, decided to avoid all SAA flights in the future. I do not share his opinion, and trust that SAA normally maintains better standards, and that this was an unlucky exception.

-Exit seats:
The Orbitz SAA tickets I initially paid for included exit seats all the way. 6 planes, 6 exit seats.
Those were now gone, meaning I would be in the cheapest seats in the 6 planes

Before my actual flight, I went to the EVA desk in Taipei, to ensure exit seats on the long haul once more.
I saw she booked those for me.
When I boarded in Hong Kong, no long haul exit seats were available to me.
The comment from SAA staff on the plane: "Sorry, we changed planes last minute, so all seat numbers have been changed"
Needless to say, I was gutted, and gave up on exit seats altogether for the rest of the flights.

-Special meals:
I booked vegetarian meals all around, and confirmed this every step of the way. Naturally, it's on my ticket.
There was 1 meal outbound, and 1 meal inbound, leaving a veggie dinner and a veggie breakfast missing.
More about that later.

-Blankets in the cold:
On the way back from J-burg to Hong Kong the famously temperature-unstable Airbus dove into the lowest possible temperatures in my section of the plane.
While I was still eating the flight's first meal, watching a movie, the other people on the plane silently went on a blanket-collecting spree and left me none.
When I asked staff about that, they couldn't find any blankets anymore.

I was seated right under the extremely noisy main fan of my cabin section with no place to turn for relief.
Icy winds around 15 degrees blew straight onto me, for the better part of 12 hours. The other cabin sections were more bearable, 18-19 degrees, but even there people had even their heads completely covered by blankets
When I asked cabin staff again in despair, telling them I would file a complaint once back at the terminal in Hong Kong, the stewardess brought me a small plastic bottle with hot water, wrapped in some tissues.
"That should keep you warm" , she said. It definitely did not.

A few hours later, when I became desperate, frozen to the bone, I tried to hide from the cold by fitting my 50yr old body on the floor, curled up under the knees of my 3 neighbor passengers, who had at least 6 blankets among them. They would not share their blankets, but allowed me to hide under their legs to shield me from the icy cold.
Naturally, SAA staff was quick to curse me for breaking the rules, forcing me to retake my icy seat once more.
Still polite, but ever so cold, I asked once more for a solution, leading the stewardess to ask the Captain to raise the temperatures, -something I was told all night by SAA staff was NOT possible on an Airbus.
I found the main cabin fan in my face finally switched off, but only for about 5 minutes, when it came on again and continued to torture me.

Finally, crew found a blanket for me, exactly 7 minutes before the night was over, when the lights went back on, and breakfast was served. That was 10 hours too late.
When I thought that a warm meal would help me defrost, I was in for more disappointment when there was no veggie meal, or otherwise anything warm to eat for me.
Chilled fruit, 2 portions, is what they had to offer! Everyone else had warm food.

4. Where is the nearest doctor?
By now I could not see clearly out of my eyes anymore.
Not only was I broken from lack of sleep, but my eyes were hurting from the many hours of none-stop icy breeze in my face, to a point of worry.
When I left the plane, I was clearly sick, and by the time I got home, I had to seek medical help to address a dual eye infection. More money lost.
Since I suffer from Giant Cell Arteritis, normally in remission, I had to start taking high-dose steroids again to avoid the return of the disease, with my immune system down from an eye infection and a serious cold.
Spent a week at home to recover.

5. Where is the SAA ground staff?

I had been patient and polite, all the way, despite all the discomfort and injustice.
When I got out of the plane in HK, I was frozen, sick, tired, eyes hurting, jet-lagged and very, very angry, as far as I am allowed to get angry without my desease causing me to have a stroke.

When I made my way to the airline terminal counters, there were no SAA staff to be found.
Inquiries led me to understand there were SAA staff, but on the other side of the airport.
With nobody responsible on site, there was nobody to assist, and I walked for 30 minutes to reach the other side, just to hear from other staff there that there are no SAA staff in the airport for another 10 hours.
Disillusioned, I walked back another 30 minutes to make my way to the EVA check-in counter for my last leg to Taiwan.
Then, EVA asked for my working permit for Taiwan, to allow me back into Taiwan without an exit ticket.

6. Where is my luggage?
I traveled very light, with only 1 small suitcase. Where EVA/SAA staff in Taipei had insisted I take my small 9.8KG suitcase with me as hand luggage to Zimbabwe, instead of checking it in, it was different on my return to Asia.
The SAA staff in J-Burg surprisingly forced me to check in that same case, same weight, on my way back to Taiwan. No discussion possible.
This was unexpected, and forced me to quickly remove my laptop while people behind me were pushing the queue at the counter.
Since I had prepared to take this as hand luggage, all my further belongings were in that case, including my work permit.
I now find myself in Hong Kong, trying to get to Taiwan, with my suit case/work permit now already in the cargo space of my EVA flight to Taiwan.
With the help of EVA ground staff now began a lengthy procedure of getting my bag out of cargo, a many step program that included having to leave transit and physically enter Hong Kong through Customs, do all kinds of stuff, pick up my bags from the conveyor belt and go through Customs again to return into transit.
I removed my permit and checked in my bags again.
It is not hard to imagine I did not need all that additional drama in my poor condition, getting worse by the hour.
Again, at no point was I unkind, impatient or otherwise displeasing in my manners, even though the SAA cabin crew was often irritated, impatient and almost unkind to passengers on both SAA long hauls.
---------------------------------
This so-called holiday has been a disaster from beginning to end.
With 1600usd stuck in SAA bank accounts for 2 weeks, I lost half my holidays in Zimbabwe due to a lack of funds.
Could not even bring any decent souvenirs for my family.
The flights, especially the return flight, was as horrible as they come, bar an actual crash in cold waters.

Consider the trouble I went through when I specifically chose SAA, paying 500usd more then Cathay Pacific fees, trusting to enjoy a much better flight.
That turned out to be a horrible miscalculation.

I trust you will fully compensate me for all this mayhem.
Since there is no way to compensate me for the additional loss of quality holiday time, surely this is not too much to expect.
qwuub: South African Airways. First freezing your assets, then freezing you.

Title:
We are from Canada and accustomed to flying either Air Canada & Westjet from one coast to the other, or, when travelling south to either the Caribbean or Mexico we fly on the charters - Air Transat or Sunwings. Occasionally, we will fly with Alaska Airlines to Mexico through Seatac.

Title:
This flight is in 2 parts, you fly to Senegal and stop over for an hour for refueling and then continue onto the USA. It’s a little inconvenient because people get off and on the plane and security comes on and searches everything... all at 2:30 am in the midst of 16 hours of travel. That’s just an inconvenience of this flight which you know going in. Planes are newer, entertainment is good. Food is decent although breakfast left me nauseated (I think just being tired).

On my last trip, there had been a snow storm on the east coast and flights to JFK (the JNB to JFK) had been canceled with lots of people redirected onto the JNB to IAD flight. So SAA goes and cancels all previously booked seats and reassigns them in the process of shuffling passengers. So if you booked a flight 6 months ago, specifically chose and paid for your seat, you’re out of luck. And you’re also now going to get your seat switched (read pack up, move yourself and even your overhead luggage) in the middle of the flight. The passengers next to me and I all asked the flight attendants about this at the initial gate, on the flight and again as we were being herded from place to place like cattle. They couldn’t be bothered. They change over crew in Senegal so they really couldn’t care less if you’re a little inconvenienced. And the new crew getting on just says you can always just get off in Senegal.

All that would have been required was some politeness, or some coordination. But instead all we got was rudeness. I realize that rerouting a lot of travelers is hard, but they just made it harder. I think next time I’ll take a different airline. It’s too long of a flight to deal with a rude crew.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:
Where to start? Well... the staff. Utterly rude, unhelpful and just useless. I cant put it any other way. The plane? Old, old and broken...

Let me start at the beginning......

Upon boarding our flight to Johannesburg, we got a little surprise, over the PA our pilot informed us that the plan had run out of blankets and water (it was a 1-hour wait to get more) so he will turn the heat up so that everyone is comfortable.... it was not comfortable. 10 hours in what felt like 40 degrees heat was not enjoyable for starters. Because we where leaving Perth at midnight (from Sydney its 3 hours difference) so my body already thought it was 3 am, I decided to try and get a little sleep, I did for about 2 hours, the bad thing was that i missed out of dinner service. I asked the host if I could please have something to eat, i got the reply "dinner service is over" again I asked her if I could have something to eat as I was very hungey and I was asleep druing the meal service, again I got "meal service is over" once again I had to ask for some food, I got an eye roll back and "ill see what is left over" form that remark I felt as if it was going to get binned left overs and half ate food, but what I got was the left over side portions of un-used salads, bread rolls and a cake. I couldn't do much about it as they are the ones serving the food. I went on to watch a movie on the seat back screen, it felt like I was using first generation LCD screens form the 1990s, the image was so grainy and poor that you couldn't even enjoy the movie let alone any other service on the console. Apart from the lack of food, blankets and water, the poor service and the most uncomfortable economy class seats, I have ever been in.. we got to Johannesburg in one peice, not looking forward to the flight home on South African Airways five weeks later.

When we boarded to fly home, out the plane was delayed for 3 hours (while we sat on the plane) as one of the toilets was not working. The maintainer staff could not fix it, and we had to fly with one less bathroom. while maintenance was repairing the toilet I had felt something moving under my seat, I reached down and found that a computer panel had fallen out of place (almost looked like it was ripped out) we had to wait another hour for the maintenance to fix what was a control piece. Not having very much confidence in South African Airways again, we did get home safley. And this time I made sure I was served dinner and breakfast!

Title:
Once again....we are SOOOOO DISAPPOINTED with our experience we had with SAA. One can truly understand why they are in such financial difficulty....because they do NOT deliver service of standard at all. One can only wonder....based on WHAT or WHO did they EVER got 'voted' as the 'Best airline in SA'...because they surely are NOT!!! They don't care about their personal and even worse...they don't care about their passengers at all. They just 'try' and make money....no matter what...even if it means giving their passengers the worse flight experiences ever. This is exactly what this review is about:
For some reason, SAA did not have a SAA labelled plane available on the flight from PE to CPT. It was just a white plane with no name on it. We have booked an exit seat, but ended up sitting in a different seat(because they apparently may do that according to their 'discretion'...(so why pre-book a seat at a cost at all then??) Anyway...once on the plane, one could see that they've tried to SQUEEZE as many people people into the plane as they could. The seats weren't even all the same look(some high back chairs and some even so low one could look into the neck of the person in front of you). The space between the seats were RIDICULOUSLY small...and we REALLY mean RIDICULOUSLY... Literally 27cm between the seat in front of you)...We know it for a fact, as we've measured it. The flight was so over-filled that people didn't have place to put their bags in overhead storage. A lady had to give her hand-bag(with all her personal belongings etc in) to the flight attendants, as she was not allowed to keep it with her...because ....and we quote the flight attendant, 'there is not enough space to put it at your feet mam'....Really???
Needless to say...everyone complaint about the flight...but the attendants honestly didn't care. Everyone got a snack....but whether you are in the front or back...you did not have a choice...you will will ONLY get what they have and apparently they didn't have an option, hence the reason why they didn't ask.
As we got to CPT airport we obviously wanted to get home as quickly as possible, as it was already 22:10 the evening.
We got to the carousel to fetch our bags....and here it comes....we waited almost 40 minutes for the bags to arrive.
Now...if that is what you want to experience when paying a lot of money for a plane ticket...then please go ahead and buy one again from South African Airways...but surely there are Greener pastures or even Orange ones or Pink and Blue one that you can truly rather consider...and you know what...they are NOT in financial difficulty like SAA.

Title:
I travel frequently for business, usually with Emirates, so flying to New York with SAA gave me a good opportunity to compare airlines.

In most areas Emirates came out well on top. Their seats are softer and more comfortable, they have a better entertainment system with more options, their staff are better trained, and their airplanes are newer and felt cleaner.

However there were a few area where I felt SAA edged them out. Firstly the food (in my opinion) was far superior. The meals felt more personal, rather than the bulk produced food served by Emirates. There were also rolls served during the "night", rather than the small bags of pretzels offered by Emirates.

And Secondly, (perhaps obviously) the journey was a far shorter with SAA since it was a direct route rather than passing through Dubai. This on it's own can be worth changing airlines for.

Title: I love to travel. After 2 round trip flights, this year and last, to and from Johannesburg from JFK I have come to the conclusion that this airline is a good example of how little coach travelers are valued. who doesn't look to the movies to make the time pass? Last year, no video for a large portion of coach, on a 15 hour flight.  What did they tell us? "A problem with the system".  this time, the video system worked, but the quality was terrible.  poor image, often had to be restarted many times, outdated selection.  The legroom?  I am only 5'8" and I had the seat on my knees when the person in front reclined.  If you are lucky enough to have an empty seat next to you, the middle arms cannot be moved fully out of the way.  On the most recent return flight, the temperature in the cabin was very hot.  After asking flight attendants if it could be cooled down, was told, "that is the default", "we told the crew and nothing can be done", and "I'll let the captain know".  It never cooled down.  the food?  about the worst I've ever had, particularly ironic because their inflight magazine had an article about how they consult with famous chefs and think their food is among the best.  over night - snacks are cheese sandwiches and crackers, water and orange juice.  The cheese sandwiches are a slice of orange cheese on a role with wilted lettuce, mayonnaise, and a slice of unripe tomato.  they were out of many beverage choices.The flight attendants appear at best uninterested, and often mildly hostile.  Although there was one who seemed to enjoy talking to two travelers in Afrikaans, frequently coming by to chat with them ignoring the rest of us.  They are quick to tell you to return to your seat when trying to stand and stretch a bit on the 15 hour flight.  And at least one seems to think it is ok to slather himself with aftershave that lingered for many minutes as he walked the aisle.  The bathrooms were not maintained at all overnight.  the smell was awful.Boarding is a free for all ,no attempt at any order or efficiency.

Title: This review cover the outward and return journeys from Durban via Johannesburg and return - I paid R37.500 for my ticket supposedly in business class - first problem was at check in Durban - due to SAA's mismanagement over many years they have canceled probably 50% of local flights - there were no suitable SAA connecting flights so I was booked Mango who only have economy class - I wanted to check my bags priority through to Hong Kong - no can do I was told - eventually after some negotiation with the manager I was given an SAA tag for Mango to use - as it was a businesses class booking I wanted to use the lounge - no can do I was told even though I also hold a Gold Star Alliance card (not with SAA) - again eventually I was allowed access - the flight onto Hong Kong was good - food, service and extras were ok - coming back no such luck - menu was wrong or was it the food that was loaded? pasta turned out to be risotto - the cheese in my fridge is better - service tacky - then - oh no! - my seat ceased to function halfway to making the lay flat bed  - a handy captain manged to get it working after some delay but try as he may the entertainment system in both cabins was dead and buried - not a squeak from start to finish - I slept uneasy for the passengers at the back staring into space for 13+ hours - and then there was the Mango horror show to follow - same story with priority baggage tags and lounge access - the gate opened 10 mins late - we were made to wait in a steamy bridge for another 10 mins and then eventually when all were on board and seated we were informed (sorry about this he said) that the plane was not technically allowed to fly because of a malfunction / lack of a deicing system - he phoned home for advice - no go so up we all got and changed planes - the cabin attendant clearly said gate C6 which is at the opposite end of domestic departures but this was wrong as it was D6 two gates away - more delays whilst everyone found the right gate - we left 90+ minutes late - a horrific end to a nightmare journey - at this rate even the most supportive customers will be jumping  ship if you get my drift.

Title: South African Airways is the worst airline I have ever traveled.  I'm sure there are worse but I have not experienced them. My outbound flight from JFK was long especially since the video screen was not working.  I asked three times for someone to check it but nothing was done.  However; the return flight (15 hours) from Johannesburg to JFK was excruciating!  Not only did my video not work, I got into an argument with a flight attendant over the video not working. She did not understand my frustration when she offered to move me to another seat.  It was in the middle of the flight.  Everyone was sleeping. I am nearly six feet tall and I had a fractured ankle. How could she move me to a different seat with no guarantee that the new seat's video would work?  The video not working was not the biggest problem.  This stewardess would not give up arguing with me.  I told her to go away.  Later in the flight she returned with her supervisor to report me.  I reiterated my complaint and explained that she did not understand me.  She and her supervisor continued to argue with me.  I proceeded to tell her supervisor that on this 15-hour flight I was never offered water and I was not allowed to use the lavatory two feet from my seat.  I had to go ask a stewardess when we boarded for a small bottle of water.  She said it was reserved for the premium class.  I was sitting in the bulk head seat in the middle of the plane. I had two fractured bones in my ankle and was wearing a medical walking boot. The lavatory for economy class was at the back of the plane.  There was a lavatory two feet from my seat but the stewardess, Carol Meyer, would not allow me to use it.  She said it was reserved for the premier passengers only.  I begged her and showed her I had a broken ankle.  She ignored my plea and waved her hand to go to the back of the plane.  The entire 15-hour flight, both lavatories - two feet from my seat were locked.  I believe I was "blackballed" by all the stewardesses half way through the flight.  They would walk by without offering me a sandwich or a beverage. About 1 1/2 hours before we landed at JFK, they brought breakfast.  I had to "flag down" someone for my breakfast.  After about 45 minutes, with a dirty try on my lap, they returned and offered tea or coffee.  Again, no water. Several minutes later, someone finally came to collect the trash.  For a 15-hour flight, they collected the trash twice!!!!!  I felt as though I was being treated like cattle.  Totally unacceptable and terribly poor customer service.
dmrsr: New York City - Cape Town Central
qwuub: I will never fly South African Airways again!

Title:
On September, 2017, I bought three tickets from Port Elizabeth to Johannesburg for me, my girlfriend and her godson (12 years old).

I informed, on the same day that I bought such tickets, that there was a little error in the passenger name, and I asked what would be the procedure in this case.

It was a material and irrelevant error, I just had written his middle name with a plus “r”.

In the e-mail dated 26 September 2017 sent by the Reservations Service Recovery team as described herein, they confirmed that the error in the name would not be a problem and also informed the occurance of a schedule change on our flight, as transcribed below:

“Kindly be advised that we have endorsed on the system for the airport to allow passenger to board.
Please note that there has been a schedule change on your flight from Port Elizabeth to Johannesburg.”

Unfortunatelly, on flight’s day when I tried to do the kid's check in at the airport, I was informed that his ticket was cancelled, although his seat was still booked in the system. We know that because I did my check in and my girlfriend's check in online one day before the flight and kid's seat was there.

South African employee informed us that his ticket was cancelled, because the name was wrong and the company policy sets forth that the ticket must be automatically cancelled.

However, I did not receive any e-mail about such cancellation. And also we confirmed five months ago with the company if the error in kid’s name would represent a problem and the answer was NO, as I mentioned above.

The airline employee at the airport said that the ticket was cancelled and refunded and she could not do anything about it.

The wrong information of South African Airways employee, and the lack of cancelation notice cost us 3.281,89 rands, almost four times more than the ticket that I originally paid for the kid to travel with us.

I still want to understand why his ticket was cancelled and once cancelled why I did not receive a notice about it.

We were on vacations and we booked two days in Sun City Hotel. So I did not have other choice than buy another ticket to the kid by a huge price.

I look foward to their return. The ticket was arbitrarily cancelled. We were badlly guided by South African's team regarding the error in the kids name and the cancelation of his ticket. It cost us more 2.465,80 rands.

I really expect to have such value fully refunded. It is our first flight with your company and we are very disappointed with the way that we have been treated by their employees since the beginning.
crvsd: Fabricio M wrote a review Feb 2018
qwuub: Cancellation without previous notice cost us a fortune

Title:
We flew on the 1050 SA40 flight.

Jo'berg airport is busy, modern and well equipped. I couldn’t understand why so many people were late and asked to be let through to the front of the security queue.

However, Gate A06 was not a long walk, has toilets very close and a coffee bar.

Perfect.

Nice Airbus 300. Two, four and two.

Plenty of premium economy seats, much room in economy.

The plane was delightfully clean and looked relatively new. Who knows?, certainly not me.

All four of us commented on how lovely the colours were, muted browns, beige with a few other stripes thrown in. It took us all by surprise.

The IFE looked fairly new, it didn’t work on this short flight but looked nice.

The trays did three things. Fold down once, unfold again and then pull out to you, three positions and a pen rest!
Independent of that was a cup or glass holder.

The seats reclined a long way, there was plenty of legroom. The headrests could be raised and the wings folded out to rest one's head against.

Brilliant.

And then they handed out cheese filled croissants and fresh fruit. On a one and a half hour flight! Bonus.

Then tea or coffee, then bottles of water and the OMG YES, THEN ALCOHOL, FREE.

I couldn’t believe it. 187ml of lovely red wine later for free and we were descending.

Staff were excellent, friendly and helpful.

I would highly recommend this airline.

I have three flights with them in the next week!
qwuub: Wow, who knew they were this good?

Title: A trip to South Africa and the obvious choice of carriers is the local one. That way we can link all the flights together and it will all be plane sailing (pun intended). Sadly not. Let’s start with the flight out... it was on a Airbus 330, which is a bit small for a 9 hour flight, but it still managed 8 seats across! Seat A being next to seat C, same with H & J, seats B & I missing. The leg room is ok for a long haul flight, but not overly generous. The entertainment system plays films, and games, or at least should, mine was broken completely and I heard other passengers complaining of the same... not good for a 9 hour flight. The choice of films is not vast but included many “classics”. If you want to watch a recent block buster you will be disappointed. Also the entertainment system was not turned on until after takeoff and we had reached cruise altitude and shut off before descent, taking an hour out the schedule. The food was ok, but they had limited choice of options, so by the time the last few were served it was a case of being thankful for any food! There were no individual air nozzles so you had the temperature as it was, which on our flight was too cold for comfort, we did get a blanket and pillow. The seats after 9 hours were not good, and for the slightest turbulence the seatbelt sign went on, which meant no tea or coffee for health and safety reasons! We arrived at Jo’burg and thought our bags would be transferred to our onward flight as the tickets said it was all with South African Airlines, but no we had to retrieve our bags and recheck-in, only now did we discover that our connecting flight with a SA flight number was actually South African Express and we were sent to a different checkin. The baggage porters, expecting people to be bewildered when turned away from the SAA desk now pounce on you, snatch your bags, march you to SA Express, then demand R200 per porter (about £13)  for the privilege.... welcome to your first sanctioned mugging in SA. Would I travel with SAA again.... only if there was no better option.... but since the return flight is today I may well be posting a sequel to this sorry tale tomorrow!
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: Just a warning ... I was recently on a flight from Maputo to Johannesburg.  At check-in, I specifically asked about my carry-on which is my camera case with my professional equipment.  I have always been allowed to take it onboard.  The case is smaller than the cases most people bring on-board.  As I was getting on the plane, the flight attendant stopped me and said I couldn't take it on the plane.  I would have to gate check it.  I tried to explain, but she refused to listen and told me check it or you are not getting on board.  After over 2 weeks in Africa of doing humanitarian work, I wanted to get home to see my family.  The flight attendant was beyond rude about it, and could not tell me where I would collect my bag.  As we were landing, I and several other passengers were told we could get it from the transfer area so we wouldn't have to go out of immigrations.  Well, this was wrong.  After 30 minutes, they finally figured out our bags were in the baggage area.  We went to go claim them but they were now with SA office.  I was in a rush cause now I had to go back out and back through immigration and security which in Johannesburg can take 10 minutes or 60 minutes depending on the day.  My lock was still on my camera case so I didn't think to check it.  I got home and I was prepping my case for the next trip and I open it up my camera is missing along with lens and a few other items.  $2,000 worth of equipment stolen.  SA Airways is making it just about impossible for me to make a claim.  They are telling me I need to fill out a police report in South Africa which they KNOW is not feasible.  I now have to fill out the claim and hope they at least process it so I can get my insurance to pay for the lost equipment.  This was not isolated ... during that trip several members of our party had stuff stolen from their bags from a laptop to computer cords to many other items.  I had seen a report that theft was high in JNB, but as many of 5 people reported stuff stolen on this trip.
qwuub: Be Wary Theft Is Still High in Johannesburg Even with TSA Locks

Title: Living in SA, one gets accustomed to people slagging off state owned companies, and usually for good reason. South African Airways also gets stick for leaning heavily on public funding and in spite of this benefit, failing to make a profit. That said though, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of this flight home from Maputo. It's only an hour and a quarter in the air but still enough to give one a good idea of the quality of service on offer. Unlike Kalula (which screws every cent out of passengers) there was this stuff on board called food. And would you believe it was free! And there was liquid too. Also free. Whatever will they think of next. On so short a flight, I wouldn't normally care too much about refreshments, but I reckon it was a real pleasure going back to SAA. The flight itself was as smooth as silk in what seemed like an almost new A300. The pilot (a woman) delivered us to our destination with barely a ripple of turbulence. The on board stewardesses worked the cabin with ready smiles. Fantastic. Pity that the Home Affairs staff at Johannesburg's Immigration let the side down so badly. As residents we've been coming in and out of the country for 15 years without difficulty. This time, I had the misfortune of encountering an obnoxious woman who treated me like a criminal because I was not carrying a 15 year old letter from Home Affairs confirming my residency. When I asked (twice) to see DHA guidance on this matter she refused to show it. Had she been able to read, she would have seen the Resident stamp in my passport. Had she been able to think, she would have realised that my ID would not have been issued had I not been a resident. Instead, and without a word of explanation, she insisted on finger printing all fingers and thumbs. Welcome to the new South Africa.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

On board live announcements are incoherent. Service with a smile? No, a grunt is more likely. Seldom are pre-set out drinks and snacks available in the galley during the flight. One has to interrupt the book-reading attendant with a specific request for what you don't know they have so that it can be, reluctantly retrieved! In flight, the incessent and loud personal chatter amongst the crew in the galley makes sleeping in the back 5 rows a challenge. Then there is the temperature!!! I am guessing but on average it must be in the low teens. The objective seems to be to keep you in your seat and  under the blanket so as not to bother the crew for service. All in all, not a happy experience. There is the odd shinning exceptions who provide real service. These are few but they all have something in common ~ they are senior in age and experience, not young and arrogant. My advice; not SAA but faa, i.e. find another airline until SAA gets its act together again.
crvsd: Bruce G wrote a review Jan 2018
qwuub: Not the SAA I used to be proud of.

Title: So we flew SAA to JFK return from Johannesburg in South Africa.  When an airline starts to become problematic when dealing with them is guaranteed to cause extra stress, especially when one is away from home.  So while at our hotel in New York, I decided to go on line to confirm our return flights. (And to select seats).  Every time I tried to get on-line, I got the, "Website unavailable" message, obviously some maintenance issue.  So I found them on Facebook and indicated what I wanted to do and the response was to contact their number in the USA which was supplied.  So I called the number and waited an inordinate amount of time until a lady called Nyra answered.  She was a consumate professional, she explained that she was in Fort Lauderdale and while she was sympathetic, her computer system did not allow her to allocate seats. (So why did they suggest this route one might ask).  At this stage,instead of being out enjoying NYC, I was in my hotel room trying to arrange seating for the return flight.  I got a return message on Facebook later in the day offering to help.  However, they obviously got their website up and running, and we managed to book seats for the return flight.We boarded the plane and took our seats, and sat and waited.  Eventually the announcement came about some fueling issue and we were told it was going to take some time to rectify. (This I worked out to be 71 minutes).  But eventually we were cleared  and departed.  Once in the air, there was an announcement about the infotainment system in economy being problematic and were told it would be a 20 minute exercise to re-boot it.  I also discovered that my seat-back was not locking and if I leaned back, it went into recline mode.  Eventually it became apparent that my infotainment screen was not functional so I elected to read.  I discussed this with a cabin attendant who offered to move us, but as we were settled and had our luggage stowed away, I declined.  On the outbound flight from Johannesburg the previous week, the catering was unexpectedly good, but on this flight it was exactly the opposite.  The options were limited, (I ordered the curry it was dry) and my companion ordered the vegetarian option, which was also substandard.  Breakfast was even worse, if such a thing could be imagined.  The two choices (Fritatta with broccoli where the broccoli was not in evidence in any way.) and a waffle which was patently pathetic to be blunt.  The only thing which was reasonable was the coffee.  The other interesting thing was all of the announcements ran behind the actions. We were already being served when we were told what was of offer.All in all, what the state of the aircraft on both recent flights tells me that the maintenance is sub-standard, and for a company with a (previous)good reputation this is worrying.
crvsd: Roger Paul M wrote a review Jan 2018
qwuub: General experience wish leave you uneasy

Title: Being a journalist shooting TV news around the globe, I have done a fair bit of air travel. And I have to say that SAA has been one of my preferred carriers, although, it has been reportedly going down in recent years.  Knowing this was going to be a long flight we chose seats by the over wing exit on this aircraft (Airbus 340 - 600) for the extra legroom. Well firstly I found the crew were very helpful and pleasant.  The flight had it's plusses and minuses, I will start with the plusses.  The catering on outbound flights from Johannesburg was better than I expected and the food options were well considered, having a fish option was a bonus for my companion as she is a pescatarian.  And while it not fine dining, the food was quite palatable. The morning breakfast offerings were also good and between the two of us we fared quite well. On the minus side, firstly I always find bread on flights somewhat un-appetizing and as for the croissants (Not a term I would use for this confection as presented) well, perhaps the less said the better.  On the trip the infotainment system was troublesome, my partners screen didn't work at all and mine was so problematic, I eventually gave up. I read my book.All in all it wasn't a bad flight,I have had far worse. The flight on the way back is an example.

Title:
We travel to South Africa twice a year, in Business Class, usually with South African Airways.The first leg of our return journey to the UK, Cape Town to Johannesburg, was brilliant. First class food, wine and service.
Surprisingly, in Johannesburg, even the security and passport queues for our onward flight to London were small and fast moving.
We arrived at the South African Airways lounge to find there were no vacant seats.
When we boarded the aircraft there were two lines for pre-boarding document checks, and later two lines for boarding. At neither was priority boarding being put into practice and long queues were encountered.
On board, the seats were uncomfortable, and back breaking when put into the horizontal sleeping position. The "mattress" provided was thin and completely ineffective.
The crew, as is common on overnight flights, were not really interested in providing good service. The food was poor and the cheese course consisted of three thin slices of dried up cheese. Food was served on trays, with no table cloth and thin paper napkins. Certainly not up to any Business Class flight I have been on previously.
For breakfast, I chose to have the stale cornflakes and "dish-washer" coffee (image attached).
Sleep was impossible with crew back and forth for much of the time, bumping into seats and leaving the curtains open.
There was no opportunity, that I could find, on the SAA website to submit customer comments.
Whatever happened to "premium travel" in Business Class?

Title: I have flown all over the world on all kinds of airlines from the cheapos like Ryan Air to the deluxe Singapore Air but I have never flown on a worse airline.  I'll start with what they did right.  They loaded the back rows 1st.  There were small amenity kits & headphones were free.  That's it.  The voices on the video were scrambled & they needed to reboot the system.  It was 2 hours before they bothered.  Neither of ours worked even then but many others did start working.  The food was edible but not much above that.  We didn't have the curry chicken because we don't like curry.  However the "beef stew" also had curry.  There was no mention of that in the announcement.  Thankfully it was fairly light.  The veggie lasagne had some type of white sauce like an alfredo.  It was ok but not lasagne.  The b'fast egg frittata was good but the chicken sausage was mealy like the British bangers.  However both the food & the video could be overlooked.  What couldn't be ignored was the abysmal service.  Basically there was none.  They fed us 1 meal right after we took off & another 2 hours before we landed.  The flight was ALMOST 15 HOURS.  I've had more food on every 6 hour transatlantic flight to Europe & the transpacific flights to HI & Asia.  They never came thru the cabin with water or juice during the night.  They never came thru & picked up trash.  You could go to the back & pick up stuff (which we did) but no one announced that option.  Thankfully we had packed some snacks & we ended up eating most of them.  One of our party happened to see sandwiches sitting in the galley & asked if he could have some.  However they were on the same par as the meals.  The chicken curry wasn't too bad (altho it tasted like deviled ham) but the veggie spread was just nasty.  Other items of annoyance were you weren't allowed to have a blanket in your lap during take off or landing. The plane was very cold.  Luckily we were leaving from NYC in Jan so had our coats.  Most of the aisle seats weren't allowed to put a bag under the seat in front of it. There were no USB ports. None of the flight attendants were especially friendly.  They all seemed to be more interested in standing in the galley talking to each other or sleeping in their quarters.  However 1 was just barely civil.  He was Sixollie Macody.  I'm not sure I have the name right because it was hard to read as he went by.

Title: My bleary eyed son and I had just woken from our over night flight. My young son needed the toilet and we headed for the nearest one. After waiting for 4 minutes I knocked on the door. After another 3 minutes, my son was getting desperate and so I knocked loudly on the door. A member of the airline crew opened the door, scowled at us and said "excuse me" in a very loud voice and slammed the door to continue with putting on her make up. Another staff member came and told us off for trying to use the business class toilet. I told him my son was desperate, he told me to go to the back and queue for the economy toilet. When I discussed the incident with the bursar, she apologised, but the apology did not come across as being sincere. She told me I should not lock loudly on toilet doors. Perhaps if a member of staff is more concerned with completing her make-up than helping a child, she is in the wrong profession. I have watched SAA decline now for years. Their actions towards economy passengers make a point of reminding you that they are there to enforce safety measures rather than make your flight comfortable. Poor entertainment, cheap headsets, poor food and now poor service. Two members of staff were concerned by the incident and I acknowledge them both, but the two that were rude to me were not asked by their bursar to apologise. I have frequent flier miles expiring annually, because I cannot use them for an upgrade unless I buy the most expensive economy class ticket, and pay more in taxes to use airmiles for an economy ticket than to purchased their cheapest economy ticket. Nothing left to entice me back I am afraid.

Title:
I was super excited to try out the new Airbus with their flat seats and the luxury space for putting my things. And some of it was indeed wonderful but as with most airplanes, not all things were equal.
I found that the staff was nice but they didn't check seat belts properly and thus I ended up landing once without a seat belt. This was due to the short end going under the cushion every time the bed went flat. I eventually saw someone else lift their bottom cushion to find the missing short end of the seat belt and so learned what to do the next time!
I loved the place on the side to put my things and spread out. The tray table was one of the best I have experience and easy to use. However, I couldn't get flat without the button becoming awkward; as once I started to lower the seat, it in fact went forward first which put the button behind me. The seat itself hooked a lot as the leg area is so small under the seat in front that it was impossible not to get the duvet tangled in it. But the most unpleasant experience was the fact that when the seat goes down, it feels like I was being put into an MRI machine feet first. Now if you understand that there are many of us that need to be sedated to even go near an MRI machine, you would understand the dilemma! Having said that, I loved the fact that I could spread out on the side with no one next to me. So I slept but just couldn’t move much from the knee downwards. As I’m short, this might be more for longer bodied people.
The entertainment screen was large with good colour sound and plenty of movies. However, when I turned off the entertainment system to sleep, it didn't hold the movie I was watching, so I would have to find it again and fast forward to the place where I had stopped. This has never been a problem on older aircraft so I found it disappointing. But the screen itself was big and thankfully I could reach it to use my hand as I couldn't figure out how to use the hand control at all, although I looked in the magazine to perhaps find some help. On my way out of JHB, the staff didn't even know there was a hand control, which could have been a problem as it was the only way to turn on and off the overhead light! I would really like to suggest that SAA needs to train their staff more carefully on any new aircraft that has different features.
The food wasn’t anything to rave about but was ok. Having written all of this I wonder why I gave it 4 stars, but flying business class is always such a huge step up for the cramped economy! I am writing this as I do believe that if you know what you’re getting into, then there is less disappointment with expectations.
qwuub: Business class on the new Airbus 330-300

Title:
First of all, this was a SA Express flight, not SAA, but Trip Advisor does not list SAX in their list of choices. SAX is a feeder line to SAA and part of the South African Airways stable.
The experience was awful. Flight was delayed for 4.5 hours, for" technical" reasons, which is not a surprise, given the old age of their planes. Apart from the usual lame excuses, nothing was done to assist passengers in any way. No updates, no meal vouchers, nothing. After we eventually boarded, we were made to sit 45 minutes on the plane, as in their wisdom, they decided to combine the morning flight (our flight) with the afternoon flight and we had to wait for all the passengers of the latter to arrive. When someone asked one of the air hostesses why we were waiting, he got a rude response: "didn't you hear what the captain announced".
The flight was rough in an old Dash 8 - Q400 plane, with an even rougher landing. If I could, I would not fly with them again, but unfortunately there are not many choices on this route.
In summary: there is nothing "Express" about this airline. This is not the first time it happenened and will not be the last. It is not surprising that they are technically bankrupt and are only kept alive through huge Government subsidies! Avoid if you can!

Title:
Flight SA053 was scheduled to leave Kotoka Airport in Accra, Ghana at 22:30 on Saturday 02/12. At 21:30, we were told that the flight was cancelled and all passengers would be put up in a hotel for the night, to depart the next day. A few minutes later we were told that after careful calculation, 97 people would be allowed to board the plane to go to South Africa. Apparently there was a mistake with the aircraft and this particular plane that we were being put into was over-fueled and as such, too heavy to land in SA with a full load of passengers. Please explain to me how this happens? Also, we were told that this was a problem that had been realised early that same day. Why then would they not tell us this at check-in? Or maybe a few hours before check-in, since that is when it came to the attention of the airline? Also, again, how do you over-fuel a plane and then make it the passenger's problem????
I was fortunately part of the 97 'chosen ones' who were able to board- but it gets better....
Upon landing in SA, we were told that our luggage had been left in Accra and we would each have to place a baggage claim. Again- plane too heavy- cant bring luggage. So off we go- all 97 of us, to the baggage claim area, where we find ONE person to assist with the paperwork. Lovely! This ONE person assured us that she had requested assistance, and that her manager was on the way to help. An hour and a half later- still no manager!
So I place my claim- a whole 90 minutes after I got into the queue. I am told by that one lonesome consultant that there was a plane coming in from Accra that very evening at 17:30, but as there were no delivery vehicles at night, I would receive my luggage the next day- which happens to be today. So today I call the baggage claims department and request an update. I am then told that only 5 bags were received yesterday, and the next flight is only coming in tomorrow- and then too, there is no guarantee that I would receive my luggage, because who knows which bags will be loaded? FANTASTIC! So I request to speak to a manager- and that's when the consultant cuts my call. So basically, I do not have my checked-in luggage after the airline erroneously put too much fuel into the plane- so now I am inconvenienced because of their poor project management. And I am not allowed to speak to anyone about it because they don't care. Am I upset? Hell yes!
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: My husband and I are tall.  I have very long legs.  When I say looong, I mean it.  So when we decided to tour America, actually to try and see Kip Moore in Concert, we booked Business class SAA.Sadly by the time Kip Moore had pinned his schedule, we had already booked ours, and we were in Portland while he did his gig in Spokane.SAA is fabulous in Business Class.  Great food, coffee and snacks anytime.  Lots of space.  I slept at least 10 hours of the 16 hour flight.  The seats fully recline, you get a mattress, a duvet, two pillows.  It was fabulous.  We had only ever before flown to Europe, also business class.  So on deciding to tour America, see our daughter, we decided to look on this journey with delight instead of dread, and SAA came through with flying colors. Pardon the pun.  I know some airlines give you some amazing first class flights with showers etc, but that just costs a billion bucks.  SAA Business is affordable.  So, 5 stars for a great flight, great food SAA.  You only realize how good SAA is when we flew a 6 hour flight from JFK to Las Vegas and there was no food and you could only buy a soft drink.  American Airlines of all sorts suck.  We flew on many of them, and they are really bad.We were lucky we flew one way on a newly refurbished cabin in the A340-600.  It was really nicely done for these now aging planes.  I suggest SAA gets some A380’s or some Dreamliners to cater for the larger demand for trips to Europe and America.  Who the heck is running, or rather running SAA into the ground, I do not know.  Hey guys WE NEED SOME NEW PLANES ORDERED NOW, CAUSE IT TAKES YEARS TO GET THEM.

Title:
We flew the round trip with SAA, and I have to say one of the worst flying experiences I have had.
At check-in, we had arrived extra early to be able to relax and not have to rush around in the airport. We had checked in online and wanted to drop off the luggage, only to be told that luggage drop off was from 2 hours before departure- something I have never heard of before, even on domestic flights. Very inconvenient. We were forced to stay on the commercial side until we could drop off our luggage and only then go through security.

We were boarded by bus (on a A330) which I have to say wasn't the fastest but they seem to have the hang of it. My partner visited the toilet just after boarding and noted that the floor and rim of the toilet were covered in urine. The cabin itself looked like it hadn't been properly cleaned either, and there were bits of panelling above the passenger seats that were hanging loose.

On one of the legs, the senior flight attendant seemed to love the sound of her own voice and was doing extra long announcements, one just after gear up which went on for at least 5 minutes up until the cabin crew were released. We were also delayed on this leg and there were "18" passengers with a short connection, and the rest of the cabin were told to allow them to deboard the aircraft first. This was all very well and good, but in fact, several other passengers (including ourselves) had very short connecting times too. It was incredibly unprofessionally handled.

The service itself was poor, the whole cabin received drinks then had to wait at least 20 minutes for the snack. A hot meal is offered, but the choice was chicken or beef, not exactly a great choice for a vegetarian. They also had sandwiches, but they looked rather poor.

To top off the bad food, the use of electronic devices is prohibited at all times on board! This includes even with flight mode on. This is also actively checked by the flight attendants, so don't expect to be able to take photographs of the stunning approach into Capetown- because you're not allowed! I heard of this 10 years ago but in the modern age where airlines now have Wifi on board, this is a huge disadvantage- especially as the IFE and personal screen were not usable. During one of the legs were offered a short "video" on the forward screens on how to do stretches- I use the word video lightly as it was more a series of pictures on loop. Very disappointing on a 2 hour flight.

The one saving grace were the flight attendants themselves who didn't fail to have a smile on their face the entire flight, and provided a nice atmosphere with the terrible food - kudos!

Unfortunately for a frequent traveller in the Star Alliance network, I have to say this Airline is far away from the standards expected on board a star alliance flight.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.
