Title: Well, what can I say. Going to South Africa is a dream come true. Flying on a small airline: if things go well it's all good. If not, it can be really bad.The biggest problem with this airline is their HORRIBLE lack of communication. We had a relatively uneventful flight over. We paid for exit row seats. When we got there, the plane had been reconfigured and we were in the row behind the exit row. We were able to wrangle seats in the center of the plane but we went from having just the two of us in the row to sharing the row with a very large man--not fat, just Shaq O'Neill large. He took up more than his share of room(we were in the center of the row) but tried hard to stay on his side. The flight attendant was sort of like "oops" sorry about that, but did let us stay in the exit row in the center through to Johannesburg. (the flights stops in Ghana--more about that later.) We switched planes in Johannesburg. That flight was great!My bag was destroyed on our flight from Capetown to Hoedspruit--despite filing a claim I have yet to hear anything from them in anyway since MAY. Will they pay: who knows?My biggest complaint was about our flight home. We had an aircraft issue that was discovered on our stopover in Ghana. Are we happy they found the issue: yes. Are we happy with how they treated us after: no. We had to stay overnight to get a repair part. They kept up on the plane for a couple of hours. They let the business class off to get visas. They kept us on and fed us (so they didn't have to feed us on the ground, I'm sure.) They told us they would let us off a few at a time to get visas and would have a representative on the ground to assist us with the process of getting to the hotel and getting through customs. NOPE no representative anywhere. The people in customs were overwhelmed: it was late, they didn't expect a plane full of people, they were frustrated, we were frustrated, it wasn't pretty.  My passport was gone for quite some time. It made me more than a little nervous.  Strange country, no passport, no cell service, no real knowledge of where we were going and when. They told us we would be staying at one hotel: we actually ended up in another hotel. The problem with that? The 2nd hotel didn't get any information on when we would be leaving. They kept telling us to check back in an hour. What that meant was that we got absolutely no sleep because we didn't know if they were going to tell us to gather our stuff and be in the vans to get to the airport.  We got to take a shower, they provided us with lunch at the hotel and we had a bed that we could lie on but that was the best rest we could get. We were finally told to get to the lobby at 4:30 PM to leave at 7:00. The lines at the airport were horrible--hot, sweaty people lined up for a block outside.  Our passports were checked by armed guards at least 4 times and we were examined more than 3 times before boarding. No dinner. They put us in a waiting room that was like a prison waiting room. (If you left you had to go through screening again-since we didn't know when we were leaving we were afraid to leave the room.) Angry, frustrated people and tired children everywhere and no information about why the 7:00 depart time had passed. Later we were told we would be boarding at 8:30, then 9:30 when that time passed a near riot took place when a representative told us to please be patient and wait a few more minutes. Finally over 24 hours after we were first supposed to leave we were finally boarding--at 11:00 PM. We found out that the people in the first hotel were told fairly early that we wouldn't be leaving until evening (so they slept) We got nothing. Even trying to call the airline resulted in a voicemail that said is was full.  We obviously all missed our connecting flights out of Dulles and were told that they would get us another flight...our trust was nil at that point.Turns out if you were on a Star alliance plane they did get you hooked up with a new seat on a new connecting flight but none of us knew that til we touched down in Washington DC.  All told a very stressful 45 hours with little to no sleep and NO communication.
qwuub: Great location: airline, not so much

Title:
The good: Customer service over the phone is courteous and helpful. The flight attendants were amazing, friendly, and went above and beyond to make sure everyone was taken care of at all times. This was a 15.5 hour flight, so that was no easy task. The in-flight entertainment was standard.

The bad: The food was subpar, with one particular dish being sent back uneaten by many people. And they ran out of the edible dish, so many people went without. So the staff (the one redeeming quality of the airline) passed out extra snack boxes which were wonderful (one box was an assortment of cheeses and crackers, and another was filled with a delicate assortment of fine chocolates). The seat divider between the seats does not go all the way up. So if you're lucky enough to have an empty seat next to you, you still can't really stretch out as the divider stays in your way.

The ugly: The pilot needs to be sent back to training. The takeoff was too steep, turns were not coordinated (step on the ball, man!) and he hopped on the landing. It was bad enough that people screamed and I thought he was going to porpoise (where the hops become steeper and worse until something gives - usually the front nose wheel).
To be fair, the pilot that needs to be sent back to school was on the flight to Johannesburg. The other pilots were fine.

We also used South African Airways to get from Johannesburg to Cape Town (the overhead bins were very small and the seats seemed smaller with less legroom); Cape Town to East London (a flight without issue); and then East London to Johannesburg (no issues), and Johannesburg back to the states. Throughout all flights, the attendants remained the shining star of the airline, the seat dividers cumbersome, and the food left much to be desired.

Title:
Old but well-kept and clean Airbus Industrie A340-600 aircraft.
South African Airlines is a member of Star Alliance and the Star Alliance policy since quite some years is that cell phones and tablets may be used in flight mode during take off and landing, but SA wants all electronics to be switched off.
In business class old and hard chairs. Possible to recline to almost a flat position, but these are no proper flat-bed chairs. The chairs are also quite short especially if you are taller than 6 feet. Difficult to sleep as the reclined chairs are extremely hard and uncomfortable.
Good information from the flight deck. Cabin crew quite nice but the service was poor, e.g. wine for dinner was first served to some passengers with the dessert.
A late dinner was served. OK but not more. Quite good South African wines.
Small, old screens with low resolution. Limited selection of movies and TV-shows available in the in-flight entertainment. No wifi. Power outlets that functioned on and off during the flight.
Small restrooms without the usual business class amenities such as toothbrushes, razors and so forth. Restrooms were not cleaned during this 11 hour flight. Most airlines clean their business class restrooms these days.
Departure 10 minutes delayed due to disorganized boarding and extremely slow passport control. Arrival 20 minutes late.
Next time I fly to Johannesburg I will look for another carrier with modern aircrafts with more comfortable beds.

We offered $1,550 each, one way, and our bid was accepted.  We bib the same for the return and got upgraded in both directions.  It's a lot of money but remember it's a 15+ hour flight and well worth the extra if you can afford it.   Forget trying to get your travel agent or the airline involved. The refueling stop was very efficient: we were 1 hr. 15 minutes in Dakar for refueling, cabin cleaning, and disembarking and embarking passengers.  Johannesburg-bound passengers simply remained on board during the stop.The business class seats reclined fully, but felt a little narrow when lying down, with not much room for your feet.  They supply a pillow and blanket.  The cabin temperature was a little cool, but I was comfortable with my windbreaker on.  They served a full dinner en route to Dakar, and then two snacks en route to Johannesburg.  The cabin crew was pretty lax in enforcing the seat belt sign when it was on, and we periodically encountered some reasonable turbulence.

Title:

Title:
I chose to travel Business class because of medical issues and paid nearly $6,000. for my ticket. I could do a lot of travelling with 6 grand, instead I wasted it on SAA.
The trip over was uneventful but sleepless. I left my Kindle on the plane and it was never retrieved even though I was back at the airport later and filed an in-person loss claim. I know. I left it.
My troubles began with the return trip. We got to the airport very early and checked 3 bags. 1 in business, 2 in econ. Although we boarded in time I was never offered champagne and by the time the FA responded it was too late. Also, her accent was so thick I had to ask for repeats throughout the flight. It was terrible. As sleeptime approached the foot part of my seat would not lift. I had a window and my seatmate was asleep. After way too much disturbance I said "Leave it. I'll deal with it." I should have demanded better service as I barely slept.
We disembarked and waited 50 minutes to find out we had no bags.
The lost bag attendant never smiled, never apologized and when asked for her full name would not give it! We were given a claim form with a number that did not pick up for the next 12 hours. When a person did respond we were given no reassurance that the bags would be located. Five days later I got my bag. The clerk doing the forwarding could NOT understand why my bag did not go with the other two. It took 2 "cutoff" calls and my insistence that the address be repeated until correct, (3 tries,) that this could even BEGIN to happen. In the meantime I had no bathrobe, no clean clothes, no other shoes and no coat in New York in November. I paid $6000. for this kind of treatment.
Since the trip over wasn't bad and the return was a disaster for days I believe that South Africa Airline owes me an apology and $3000. It is with deep regret that my flight experience so overshadows my trip.

Title: We travel to South Africa a lot and have regularly used SAA, in fact their internal flights are some of the best we have used around the world. Always on time, friendly staff and good quality food and snacks and again on our recent trip we could not fault them. However the same could not be said for their international flights. On our last trip we did have a few issues on the plane but because of their good past record decided to give them another go.Booking and check in was easy and straight forward, and we settled into our seats for the 11 hr flight. However most of the plane were unable to use their TV monitors ( this is what happened before on our previous flight!) despite the issue being raised by most of the passengers and several attempts to re-load the screens, nothing happened , so we were entertainment less for the whole flight. We were a group of 7 and after a week 3 flew back to the UK with SAA whilst the other went onto Cape Town to extend the trip. On the first groups return again half the plane had no entertainment system and again it remained unresolved after several attempts to re- boot the system. The other issue was the heating of which there was none! It was absolutely freezing even with 2 blankets you could not get warm. Our group returned to the UK 5 days later, again on our flight half the TV monitors were not working , there was one token attempt to reboot but then nothing happened not even an apology. The airline staff were terrible speaking in their own language the whole time and almost ignoring the passengers, dishing out drinks and meals without any eye contact or attempt to make conversation with passengers again just talking to each other. Then overnight again the cabin was absolutely freezing , but again no help was offered by the staff or apologies.  I really felt sorry for the young babies that were on the seats in front of us.In the morning when they were serving breakfast almost the entire plane were wearing jumpers and coats, when we commented about the heating the stewardess said " Why are you cold?" when we explained it had been freezing overnight ,she just turned away and just carried on serving meals. To add insult to injury when we were coming into land another stewardess strapped into her seat and shivered saying she was so cold sitting there, as we said you should have been here all night!! Just shocking that there was no explanation or apology for an 11 hr journey from hell. Will never use SAA again and will recommend that no'one else does. They may be cheaper than other airlines but now I can see why!
qwuub: Will never travel with them on an international flight again!

Title:
My husband and I were recently in Africa on a 7 week holiday, while we were there we flew South African Airways 8 times going between our different destinations and it was great.
We only had 2 x 1 Hour delays, this is nothing as we encounter this when you fly within Australia and I am sure this would happen in other countries as well.
My husband is a tall man and he had heaps of leg room, we were actually amazed at how much we had as you do not have any in the Australian planes, his knees always hit the chair in front, unless you pay extra and get an exit seat.
The Stewards and Stewardesses were very polite, very friendly, impeccably dressed and nothing was too much trouble.
But the best part was the food, every flight you had a choice of 3 hot meals (Beef, Chicken & Vegetarian), along with this you got a salad, bread roll, desert, chocolate, cheese & crackers, tea or coffee and alcohol. They always asked if everything was okay and if we wanted a refill. I was actually so impressed I took a photo of the food and sent it back to family saying that Australian Airlines need to take a leaf out of the SAA book. When we actually got back and took our flight form Sydney to home the food was dismal, you have to pay for the alcohol and we were both saying we wish were back on the SAA planes.
I am shocked to read the other reviews as we never had anything but great service, great food and a comfortable ride, keep up the great work SAA, we will only ever book with you guys when we come back.
By the way we were so impressed we decided to do this review.

Title:

Comfort for sleeping was good, staff did not wake you any earlier than they had to (some airlines seem to wake you to suit the staff rather than the passengers - I mean 3.5 hours for breakfast before you arrive!). Food was generally good and of course local SA wine was welcome. Movie selection was down on other airlines but still plenty of options. Lighting was fine (we have been on some incredibly bright light flights with some Asian carriers). Staff were efficient and calm without being rushed and were happy to have a chat.
The only incident we had was in Business JBurg to Nairobi where the senior staff person said there was no in flight entertainment on board only to find out otherwise 10 minutes later when her assistant brought out tablets for viewing.
Apart from ex Perth to Jburg (1+ hour late with a big rush to the connecting flight) all flights were on time with smoothe landings.
We would use them again although unless you go the African continent it is difficult to get other locations seeing we depart/arrive from Australia.

Title: We booked a flight from DAR to GEORGE departing 20th September 2017, in July 2017. On Friday 15th September we recieved a call from Expedia informing us that the flight from DAR to JNB was cancelled. We were offered two options a) a later flight on the same day, which would mean no connection to our final destination, and no offer of a hotel overnight, or the same flight route on the 21st or 22nd September, again due to commitments on the 20th this offer was also not suitable. After long discussions with Expedia who were trying their  best to accommodate us, and by this time I had probably spent more than $100.00 on phone calls, we asked if they would change the original flight to either the 19th or 18th September they had no luck contacting South African Airways to make the changes, and had no policy in place to authorize the change without approval. So On Saturday afternoon still without answers I started trying to contact South Airways directly, after several attempts, speaking to various agents who did not have any solutions we eventually had an agent who after speaking to a supervisor agreed we could travel on the 19th, the flights were not very convenient with a seven hour layover in JNB but at this stage what could we do? She confirmed all our details, and after some long hold on the phone (again at my expense) she came back to tell us she could not confirm this booking as the connecting flight was South African Express, and they had no agreement in place with them. So we started again, and asked for our last resort Monday the 18th, after long waits on hold again we were told this was not possible as it was more than two days prior to our original departure, so the final solution from South African Airways was for us to cancel the original booking with a 100% refund which will be refunded in 7 to 21 days and re book the flight ourselves for the 18th September. Which we did with an additional $108.00 fare difference! so thank you South African Airways YOUR CANCELLED FLIGHT  has cost YOUR CUSTOMER and additional $208.00 ....
qwuub: What happens when the airline cancels your flight !
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: The last time I flew SAA was a return trip from CPT to JNB on my Kruger holiday.  I have flown SAA many times over the years, and probably done this return journey at least 50 times, so I have a base of reference on how the airline has evolved over the years. Overall SAA has maintained a good standard of service over the years, but I have felt recently, and particularly on this trip, that standards were fraying on the edges. Its difficult to point out exactly what it is....maybe its the greeting at the door of the plane that feels more perfunctory than genuine (even on relative Airline standards) or maybe its the sometimes robotic onboard service. Whatever it is, against a broad global and regional comparison, it feels like there is some tiredness creeping in. It remains my preferred airline for internal travel in South Africa, but no longer a preferred alternative for long haul travel.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: This was the 1st time in years that I flew with SAA and was pleasantly surprised with the service on board. Friendly, attentive staff. Little was too much trouble for them. Title: I have experienced traveling internationally on South African Airways for more than 3 decades and it continues to deteriorate. I will comment on both our international and in-country recent experiences. Our business class flight from US to Johannesburg was not bad and one of the flight attendants, Brian, was particularly good. Others were acceptable if not particularly attentive. Return flight from Jo'burg to US lacked any top notch flight attendant, but at least it was mostly benign neglect. Our flight, again business class, from Jo'burg to Cape Town was awful! Herded around like sheep to slaughter and flight attendants who couldn't be bothered and were surly when you did request something. With all the fine wines in RSA how is it that they had NO WINE to offer in business class on this flight??? Return flight from Cape Town to Jo'burg in Economy was a better experience - at least they had wine to offer. ALL flights were late departing.  Also, don't bother to respond to SAAs request for your flight experience, after 5 months NOTHING from them! There are better local carriers in-country and you should use them. I have lived and worked in Africa, particularly southern Africa and have experienced better, ESPECIALLY from SAA!
crvsd: William R wrote a review Sep 2017
qwuub: disgrace and if traveling internationally take another carrier to RSA

Title:
I had to fly SAA to Victoria Falls in July 2017. I had been warned not to carry valuables on my person in case of theft. So I packed my cell phone in my checked luggage. It was stolen on the return trip to South Africa. I filed a claim by email. I got an automated response with a name of Customer Service agent, and nothing since. My travel insurer will not cover unless the carrier has investigated. It clearly was someone with an xray machine as nothing else was missing. It was a targeted theft.

Beyond that, I found the staff unresponsive on the flight--entertainment wasn't working. Their partner, Mango Airline, had even worse service.
qwuub: No customer service for missing baggage

Title: It was the first time I have flown with SAA. Having heard a lot of negative feedback about their service delivery and quality of service, I thought to try them out for myself. We took off on time and the flight was magnificent - smooth sailing until we touched down. Although one hostess must have been having a bad day, another was quick to apologize and treat me like a king. I paid about $15 more for my ticket, compared to the local low budget airlines, but unlike on the cheaper airline, I got lunch and refreshment for free! Now, this is a big deal if you are a student like me and free stuff is just about as good as a scholarship... The colour scheme of the interior is inviting and warm and makes you feel at ease. Seats are comfortable and I had no discomfort whatsoever. I'll buy a ticket on SAA again!
qwuub: Great for Domestic travel in South Africa

Title: Required to purchase a new ticket for my partner as her original ticket was in her SA Passport Name. The passport she is legally required to use when departing  South Africa for an overseas destination. Her Esta for Canada is listed on her Italian passport which is in her maiden name as all European countries use this procedure. The same Italian passport has a cross reference to her married name(same as on her SA Passport). No amount of debate could persuade the SAA  officials to reverse their decision and a new ticket had to be purchased at the airport in the name on her Italian Passport. Now we have travelled extensively together utilising British Airways to the USA, Singapore and Qantas to Australia where an Esta is issued by these countries in her maiden name as listed on her Italian passport. All these trips were without any hassle from the airlines concerned. The last such trip was undertaken in December 2016 without mishap. SAA would not budge, yet when we left Vancouver to return to SAA the Lufthansa agent queried why her ticket was in her maiden name and not the name on her South African passport, suggesting that there was no need to have purchased a new ticket upon leaving South Africa....Officiousness or desperation to fleece another customer. Needless to say, our experience will result in never making the same mistake twice and flying SAA.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:

Food, seating, comfort, service is generally of a good standard, and the longest flight I've taken is around 8 hours, usually with a stopover somewhere from West Africa to Johannesburg.

Flying from Mauritius as my departure point, there is little choice to get to West or East Africa, but there is nothing wrong that with either.

Title: Flying Lufthansa Vancouver to Munich.  Arrived Munich 2pm and departure screen listed my South African Airways flight to Jo'burg as being "on time" at 21:05.   So, 7 hours to kill, walked the length of the terminal,  read a book, then 2 1/2Hrs before departure, still posted a being "on time" went to the gate.  Could not see a flight info screen from this gate.  After a while, another passenger arrived to tell us the flight was cancelled and we should all go to the Lufthansa desk.  The flight was cancelled as the aircraft had not taken off from Jo'burg.  It was in fact, cancelled already when I arrived at 2pm!   SAA did not advise Lufthansa.   Consequently, the single person at the Lufthansa desk was suddenly mobbed by over 200 passengers!   Extra help arrived, but it took 4 hours to clear everybody.  We were sent to a hotel near the Airport.  where I arrived after midnight.  Next day, an SAA flight arrived in the morning and we all boarded.  There was a delay of over an hour due to congestion, so we arrived in Johannesburg late, and about half the passengers missed their connection flights - me included.  However, when we cleared immigration and customs, there was not an SAA representative to be found!  After about an hour, a local fellow said that SAA usually used a hotel (told us the name , but I have forgotten it) and suggested we just go to the bus terminal outside and go to that hotel.  Sure enough, a big coach turned up, took us to the hotel.  SAA had advised the hotel, but no advice given to passengers!   A second unexpected night in a hotel!   The SAA flight crew and check-in desk staff were all excellent, but sadly let down by incompetent management!!

Title: The flight from southern Africa to the US is a tough decision as it is a long one. I flew back from Africa on SAA's direct flight from JNB-IAD which has a stop in Accra to refuel and swap passengers. While it was nice to stretch my legs, I found the stop more of an annoyance than anything. From my experience, there  is no way that they ever could do it in the scheduled one hour. It took way longer, and is disruptive to sleep as it is in the middle of the night. We left JNB on time but with the extra long stop ended up late to IAD, which made my layover very very tight. Baggage claim in IAD was chaotic as well, with 2 baggage claims and it was unclear what was where. In the end they put transit bags on a separate carousel, most but not all of the time--and for some reason these came out at the end/last! [I made my connection by literally 5 seconds, they were closing the door-and I ran the whole time. United wasn't helpful at all at radioing to hold it etc.] The SAA flight itself was ok. The staff were nice. The food was ok but repetitive after a while. I would've appreciated one of the meals being more of a snack than another chicken or beef dish. The breakfast was awful and noone ate it (pancakes).  Wine was good. Seats aren't great but are average/typical size for this day and age. Would have definitely paid for economy plus, but sadly they do not offer it.  That would make a huge difference on this flight. My seat location (53 aisle ) was good.  Movies were good but my screen stopped working in the middle of the night. A final note--in JNB, you had to go through security again at the gate--and they made you toss liquids including water that you had bought in the terminal. They should advertise this so you don't spend $5 on water that you then have to throw away--and so you can leave time for this in your planning.

Title:
To be fair, I'm going to post the same review on Air Namibia, between the airlines,they need to review and understand what a client is, including how an airline should treated any client.

We arrive early at Windhoek airport. My colleague is flying back to JHB in 2 hours and I'm flying in 4 hours back to Cape Town. We're sharing a rent a car.

At check in, Air Namibia asks me if I would like take an earlier unscheduled flight. Nobody tells me that it's with another airline, less luggage KG allowance and a very small plane. So as a client, I get excited and say yes.

I'm directed to Air Namibia client service where they manually write my name down on a sheet. We gather and then the lady that helped me, leads all the volunteers to SAA and a special queue. So far, everything working.

And so begins the client nightmare.

I get to the check in counter and I'm now 2kg overweight for the SAA small plane. If I stayed with my original flight on Air Namibia (an airbus), I would be within the allowance with a kg to spare. SAA says I must pay, I don't argue (I just want to get home as quick and smoothly as possible). I get a luggage printout and told to go to the counter and pay excess. My suitcase is dispatched.

I arrive at the Air Namibia client counter and she tells me that I must go to the SAA counter, which I do. The lady at the SAA counter says she can't let me pay because I don't have a computer system ticket for that flight (I've been manually added to this flight at the specific request of Air Namibia).

I go back to Air Namibia, they can't do anything, the lady at SAA now walks over to Air Namibia and in front of the client (me). Aggressively asks why they are sending Air Namibia clients to her without a ticket.

At this stage, I ask that I be put back onto my original flight with Air Namibia. They took me off the list and after two attempts to retrieve my suitcase, they find my suitcase after a long time and I check in with Air Namibia, exactly how I started 1 hour and +/- 30 minutes before.

So now I think it all done and over.

After shopping at duty free, I walk into the waiting area and hear my name announced. Apparently SAA still has had me on their list even though my boarding pass says Air Namibia and a different flight. I walk to Air Namibia boarding counter and they say, go to SAA.

At the SAA counter, the gentleman is angry, aggressive and as I approach to inform him that I'm actually not on their flight (I'm being courteous), he asks my name and as soon as I confirm, he merely states twice and aggressively (and I mean aggressively) that I've been offloaded from their flight, which I'm not on. I didn't need to inform another airline that there records are wrong and that my bags are not on their flight. I was expecting a thank you for informing them. It just goes to show, that I was never considered as a client or traveler.

If any friend asked me, how's the best way to fly to Namibia from South Africa, without hesitation I would say, consider BA, I fly them locally all the time, they don't consider you as a client, you are the client. It seems Air Namibia and SAA, don't have clients, merely irritations using their services.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title: Absolute worse experience of my life.  My friend and I were on our way home from a wonderful trip to Cape Town and we first had a layover in Johannesburg.  From Johannesburg, we initially thought we were flying directly to Washington D.C. but we didn't realize that we were going to have to stop in Accra Ghana.  Our first leg of the trip was fine.  We landed in Accra, the team stripped the plane and made sure that it was ready for the Accra passengers to have a place to sit.  An hour later they told us they had a leak and could not fix it because the Accra airport did not have the supplies or was fit to fix the plane.  Another hour later they said we would be spending the night.  5 hours after sitting on the plane they finally deplaned us and got us visas for Ghana.  We were all upset because no one had the proper vaccinations to be in Ghana and our phones did not work.  We were also told the entire time we would have a customer representative at our hotel to arrange flights once we arrived in Washington.  They shipped us off to hotels and that was the last we heard from the airline.  We ended up sitting at the hotel for 12 hours and had no idea when we were going to leave and how we were going to rebook our flights once we arrived in Washington.  Once I found out an estimated time of departure, I called my connecting carrier in Washington to rebook my flight and paid the $200 change fee for each of our tickets to ensure we would have a flight home.  SAA never compensated us for our change fee and the only compensation that they gave us for taking away 24 hours of our lives was 25% off our next SAA flight.  I will never EVER fly SAA again and advised all of my friends my terrible experience.

Title: I fly often and this was my first time flying SAA and it'll definitely be my last! It's the worst airline when it comes to customer service and being helpful. When we arrived the following day at the airport counter, they told us the price had changed and it'll be $733 each now. They knew we were desperate to get to Ghana for a funeral and decided to squeeze more out of us. We called the SAA customer helpline again and wanted an explanation on the price change and they were just appalled as we were but once again, they couldn't help us although they admitted that wasn't right. So after paying an extra 733$ for this flight, the ride was a disaster as the seats were extremely uncomfortable, the meal was disgusting and their flight attendants not courteous or respectful. If you think flying Spirit is bad, you're in for a rude awakening with SAA. Please avoid SAA if you can. You're welcome!

Title: At the airport the gate is changed with no announcement - you see other travellers starting to stream somewhere else and discover the change (yes, you can get the notice on your cellphone IF your service provider allows it - NOT ALL OF THEM DO!!!). At the new gate two airline hostesses stand silently until the display above them changes to Flight Cancelled - and of course there is a rush of Serengeti proportions toward them. Eventually we all hear the plane has "developed technical difficulties yesterday and the parts will not arrive in time for the scheduled flight departure". Must have been some serious difficulties if they had to specially order the parts, but what do we know. We then stream down to stand in line for an hour or so to get on a bus and be taken to a hotel where we are to be accommodated. All of us only in possession of our on-board luggage, as our checked bags are held for the next day. Rooms are not ready so everybody (300, 400?) claims a seat (mostly on the floor) in the hotel lobby and another wait begins. We eventually get a room at half past three (been waiting for the flight since nine am after flying from Seattle the previous evening) so all we want is to shower and get clean. We have to dress in yesterday's clothes again for dinner, and again the next morning, when we manage to finally get on to the plane. By the time we get home after the fourteen hour flight, we solemnly swear to stick to our resolution of years ago NOT to fly SAA. Will not break it again.

Title:
I chose to fly with South African Airways to Johannesburg as they offered the most convenient and cost effective option for my trip.

Starting at Heathrow, because I hadn't checked in online, I had a positive experience with the check in staff who helped me to choose my seat and sort out my baggage. Everyone I encountered in Heathrow terminal 2 was efficient and friendly.

The plane itself was an A330-200. It was clean and comfortable on board. For the outward leg of the journey I was in seat 65A and had two seats to myself. On the way home I was in 60A and there was someone next to me - although I noted those further back had two seats to themselves (a consideration if you have a choice and it's a night flight - you might want to spread out a bit!).

I didn't make much of the inflight entertainment myself, so can't really comment. There is a touchscreen where you can play games, choose to watch tv shows or films (many of which were dated 2017), look through duty free shopping items, look through the menu for the flight, or - my favourite option - look at various different map screens to see the progress you're making on your journey. As others have commented, there are no ports for charging devices in economy. There is no on board wifi.

The drinks service was quite frequent, including alcohol and tea/coffee. The cabin crew made it clear at several points that you could ask for drinks at other times as well if you wanted to - although I never did.

The food - I don't consider myself an especially fussy eater, but on the way out the options were lamb, fish or mushrooms - none of which I like! The breakfast wasn't too nice either, perhaps because it was served at 3am I wasn't quite ready for it! The food on the return trip was much nicer - I had spinach and cheese pancakes with tomato sauce, and the breakfast of cheese omelette and bacon was very tasty too. They offered a cold / continental breakfast option for those who didn't want a hot meal.

The seats were comfortable and I was able to sleep a little in the reclined position. The seat pitch was perhaps a little restrictive - I am only 5'6" and couldn't put my legs comfortably straight. In economy class they supply a blanket and a pillow, plus a little amenity set including eye mask, flannel and toothbrush / toothpaste.

The toilets were relatively clean and there wasn't often a queue.

There was mild turbulence en route, but the flight crew had told us to expect this in advance. The take off and landing were some of the smoothest I've ever had, and the flight as a whole was great. The pilot and captain kept us well informed throughout.

The cabin crew were the highlight - so friendly and helpful, nothing was too much trouble. They really seem to enjoy their job and like working with people. It makes everyone so much more relaxed on the flight.

We arrived slightly early both on the outbound trip to Johannesburg, and the return to London. It was seamless, really. I was very impressed with the airline and would have no hesitation recommending them to others. I'd also be very happy to fly with them again myself, should a South African flight be an option on my route.

Title:
I had forgotten how bad South African Airways (SAA) could be. Between 2009 and 2011, I worked in Africa and flew SAA many times. They regularly lost my baggage, although credit must be given to the fact that they always found it and delivered it 24 hours later. I missed connections twice because of how inefficient their transit was. But I had forgotten about it all after 6 years without flying SAA. But I remembered it all yesterday when I was denied boarding in Washington, DC for a minor technicality.
I have several middle names which were listed in the reservation correctly, but there was one space separating my middle names from my last name (e.g., my name was written like (MM_L) instead of (MML), where M=middle name, and L=last name. Note that all names were properly spelled and included in the reservation in the correct order. There were not typos or any missing information. There was no doubt about my identity. I have flown in numerous other airlines over decades with the same spelling without any problems. This has never been a problem anywhere anytime. But as the SAA manager said, "SAA is different!" He also informed me that I was not the only one with this problem as a university professor on the counter next to me argued the same case. He added later that it happens every day. Naturally, this is evidence of a problem with the airline policy.
After being denied boarding, my travel agent called SAA to reissue the ticket. SAA did not allow the ticket to be re-issued with the requested name change, but agreed to waive the fees if we bought a new, last minute ticket -- for a significant price increase, of course. Furthermore, cancelling the ticket would make me lose my seats and fall back to the end of the wait list. As a result, there were no seats available for the next 2 days and all return flights were sold out on the date of my return as well as +/- 2 days around the expected date of my return.
I was left with a very bitter taste. How many times will SAA screw me? A piece of advice: avoid SAA if you can.

I am a relatively short person so leg room for me was not a great issue unless you are seated next to someone who is taller and they want to spread their legs over to your side so clearly leg room is not design for all heights. I am not over weight but the seat between me and my partner was extremely annoying as it would not go all the way down and rubbed on my thigh.

I was not too impressed with the food so it was hard for me to eat at all they are vegan friendly you just need to state this on your flights when booking. I came prepared with snacks on the plane to get me through the flight.

My screen on the back chair was not working and I understand that being so high up the sky these things are not going to run 100% so I was prepared with bringing my ipad and of course a pillow (this has saved comfort on so many flights) also if you can afford it invest in some sound cancellation headphones.

The customer service is pretty good and the few times that I have flown with SAA I have never had an issue. They will attend and provide the best they can for you I guess you need to be prepared for what a flight is like and keeping to yourself as other people will need more attendance.

Title: My husband & I were delayed when severe weather cancelled a flight from Cape Town to Johannesburg. Had we known the truth, we could have potentially made alternate arrangements & certainly wouldn't have sprinted through the airport with our carry on in tow. We were lead in circles back & forth to several counters before an airport employee finally walked us to the right place to figure out what to do next. They weren't sure where our luggage was & blandly sent us on our way with a ticket for a hotel/meals (which were decent).  We did find our luggage & were re-scheduled for 24 hours later on another flight which meant  both a missed connection in the statues and missed work. No offer was made to upgrade seats, offer future travel vouchers, or anything of that nature. We had trouble contacting our connecting airline from Johannesburg so got up early & went right back to the airport to try to figure that out. We were assured by SAA hat this had already  'been sorted out' for us so we relaxed in our seats and enjoyed the flight back. (We would have slept in had they said this the night before) The planes are very comfortable and kept up nicely, & the staff is friendly. When we arrived in Washington DC, we were told that nothing had actually  been done with our connecting flight at all so we were 'no shows'. We did find another flight & worked this out fine---but had another 6 hours in an airport after traveling for about 50 hours total. We realize the weather obviously couldn't be controlled, & these things do happen when you travel. We'd just like honest information & an attempt to make things as comfortable & convenient as possible given the circumstances.

Title: I must first admit that, as a South African, I have chosen not to fly on our national carrier, certainly never domestically. The reasons are that I cannot support a parastatal that hemorages tax payers money and whose board is chaired by a corrupt incompetent. Any ticket price is huge when I consider the loss of my taxes into the bottomless pit that is SAA. However, our recent trip from Johannesburg to New York using SAA made economic and time sense: we could find cheaper tickets but SAA flies directly and we needed to maximize our time in NYC. So let's begin with the negatives. The SAA website is counterintuitive and gave me, who flies often, a sense that my booking had been lost when I tried to check in slightly earlier than the 24 hours required. Instead of a clear statement informing me that 'checkin in not yet available, try again within 24 hours of your departure time' I was greeted by a red warning sign and icon stating that 'No record if this traveler is on the Database!" This forced me to phone the airline to confirm that I was still in the system and that I still had a flight. This all seemed rather stressful and unnecessary for a first-time SAA traveler. We received confirmation emails of our boarding passes on the out leg but NOT any communication and digital boarding passes for our return journey. This meant that more time was needed to check in at JFK as I could provide no proof of pre-check in. Given the delays in passing through USA ports security this was unwelcome. There is no possibility of ordering or changing your meal as this is not provided for on the website and, to ensure that my wife and I sat together, an extra fee of R500 was charged - just to sellect seats. I consider this a cheek given the high costs of the seat you pay for in the 1st place. The seats on this long haul flight are appalling and I needed to place 2 cushions on the seat to help me cope with what felt like a plate of metal with a piece of thin foam on top. Clearly the seats have passed their expiration date as have the screens and hardware which are decades old and difficult to manipulate. Given that we had flown Delta inside the USA whose entertainment touch-screen hardware is state of the art, I can see that my taxes and expensive flight costs are not finding their way to fleet maitainance. My wife's handset did not function and the old touch screen technology and time lag was frustrating. On both our legs to and from the USA no flight pack was provided and this sloppiness added to the sense that SAA long haul is operating by the seat of its pants. But there are upsides. Our flights left on time and we arrived ahead of schedule coming home. Our vegetarian menus were catered for timeously, the flight crew and attendants were friendly and helpful with all our needs and requests. The selection of in-house entertainment was surprisingly wide - although hampered by the aforementioned old technology. There were no major problems and everyone on the flight seemed comfortable and catered for. SAA ground crew boards passengers from the back of the plane first, thus avoiding too much cramming of the isles. USA crews could learn from thus and avoid the frustrating jam in the isles upon boarding.
qwuub: Mixed experiences and feelings on SAA
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:
As SAA is the only airline that offers direct flights between Perth and South Africa you are stuck with them and they know it. This is plainly obvious when looking at the costs. It cost me more to fly the 10 hours to Johannesburg in March this year than it costs me for my 23 hour flight to LA last month and if you try and book over the peak periods it will cost you even more.

Check in is slow at Johannesburg International - although I will not blame SAA for this - as the customs queues take forever.

There is a great selection of duty free items for sale in the departures terminal and at reasonable prices.

I must compliment about half of the staff on my recent flight as they really went all out to ensure the customers (passengers) were as comfortable as possible and appeared to enjoy assisting no matter what time they were approached. Unfortunately the other half of the crew were definitely not in the same class and made you feel like they were doing you a favour by just being on the plane. They definitely let their counterparts down.

The seats are you average economy class size but are extremely hard which really hurts after a few hours in the air. I ended up sitting on my travel (neck) pillow to soften the ride.

The entertainment is up to standard with a good selection of both recent and hit movies to choose from as well as interesting documentary's on areas in SA to visit.

The flight was smooth as was take off and landing.

Another positive was that all my luggage was on the carousel with nothing missing.

Title:
I have taken this up extensively on Twitter and eventually forced a phone call out of SAA.
SAA, as a state owned enterprise, that is regularly bailed out by government, is a national disaster. Owing to government protection, SAA doesn't have to worry about markets or customers - and it shows.
Our flight was due to board at 13h25. By 14h00 (departure time) we were still standing the in the queue, with none of the passengers any the wiser as to the delay, until someone notice there was a problem with the plane's front wheels...
After the crowd starting grumbling, we were advised that the flight was delayed...
We were told that boarding would not likely take place before 15h00. Note, please, that OR Tambo is a silent airport and there are limited flight information announcements.
We went off for something to eat and returned to the boarding gate at 14h45 only to find that the flight had departed!
We found ourselves, along with several other passengers, stranded.
We were able to get ourselves booked on another flight, after much palaver and argument, particularly with the particularly abrasive ground crew member who'd been at the centre of the debacle. Luggage retrieval, given luggage had been offloaded, was another ridiculous and unpleasant mockery.
The Australian couple who also missed the flight and who we assisted where dumbfounded and horrified.
I took to Twitter and received the brush off until I resorted to including others in my tweets and retweeting to Star Alliance and Voyager partners. The apology, when it came was an "however" sort of apology, which resulted in another bout of tweeting, at which point I was finally asked for my phone number and received a call from one of the social media managers, who was good enough to listen to my complaint, concur that all had gone wrong, and apologised.
But honestly, to go to that length to extract an apology - no compensation offered - is nothing short of dismal.
It also created an unpleasant end to what had been a great holiday.

As an aside, food on SAA is awful. Flight attendents are generally good.

The only good experience in the whole horrible experience was the incredibly lovely lady at the check in desk, when we were obliged to re-check in. Top marks to her for an outstanding attitude. The rest of the SAA ground crew could well learn several lessons from her.

If you can avoid flying SAA, do so.
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

This turned out to be far from true and the first we knew was from our flight app and only later courtesy of an SAA email!!  Initial delay was one and a half hours and on boarding there was another delay due to missing connecting passengers!  Arrived in London over 2hrs late in the end.  The onboard service was sadly lacking and the food average - the senior? Attendant in business - David - saved the day by his efforts and so he dragged my score up 1 - so good on him!  There was absolutely no communication from staff at the airport and when I heard all the other grumbles from customers on their experiences with SAA it's no wonder they're bankrupt.  All in all a complete shambles but at least we were able to lay out and sleep - I felt sorry for those in economy.  I'll think twice before flying SAA in the future,  which is a shame and purely due to what I can only call staff incompetence - or maybe they just don't care?
xcjrc: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.

Title:

Title: Flew business Perth to Jo'burg.  When it was announced in the lounge (SAA business passengers have use of the Qantas lounge which was very busy and in need of a refurb but staff did a great job clearing tables and replenishing food etc) that the aircraft was boarding we headed for the gate and were last to board - so no queuing!  Aircraft left slightly ahead of schedule and landed early.  Departure was around midnight so a long overnight haul of 11hrs or so - I slept most of the way so didn't notice the time. Business seating was 2-2-2 configuration so better than BA which has 4 in the middle.  Beds are almost fully flat but feet can dangle a bit off the end if you're around 6 foot.  Ideally you need more than one duvet to lay on as the seats were hard when extended (not a problem as business was only about half full).  Food menu wasn't extensive but being a late flight most passengers would have already eaten.  Service was attentive and staff friendly.  So far we've only flown business on SAA - this is our 5th since February and currently transiting in Jo'burg for 15hrs (staying in the transit hotel which is quiet and comfortable - superior rooms are larger and also have a bath plus shower) until the connection to London.
